Here is a step‐by‐step solution:

1. Heat lost by the water  
   \[
     \dot Q \;=\;\dot m\,c_p\,(T_{in}-T_{out})
     =8.5\;\mathrm{kg/s}\times4180\;\mathrm{J/kgK}\times(80-70)\;\mathrm K
     =3.55\times10^5\;\mathrm W
   \]

2. Log‐mean temperature difference (air at 15 °C)  
   \[
     \Delta T_1=80-15=65,\quad \Delta T_2=70-15=55,
     \quad
     \Delta T_{\rm lm}=\frac{\Delta T_1-\Delta T_2}{\ln(\Delta T_1/\Delta T_2)}
     =\frac{10}{\ln(65/55)}\approx59.9\;\mathrm K
   \]

3. External surface area of the 400 m pipe  
   \[
     A=\pi D L=\pi(0.15\;\mathrm m)(400\;\mathrm m)\approx188.5\;\mathrm{m^2}
   \]

4. Overall convective coefficient \(h\)  
   \[
     h=\frac{\dot Q}{A\,\Delta T_{\rm lm}}
     =\frac{3.55\times10^5}{188.5\times59.9}
     \approx31.4\;\mathrm{W/m^2K}
   \]

5. Nusselt number on the outside (air properties at film temperature \(T_f\approx(75+15)/2=45\,^\circ\)C, \(k\approx0.028\;\mathrm{W/mK}\))  
   \[
     \mathrm{Nu}_D=\frac{hD}{k}
     =\frac{31.4\times0.15}{0.028}\approx168
   \]

6. Use the Hilpert correlation for cross‐flow around a cylinder  
   \[
     \mathrm{Nu}_D
     =C\,\mathrm{Re}^m\,\mathrm{Pr}^{1/3},\quad
     C=0.193,\;m=0.618,\;\mathrm{Pr}\approx0.71
   \]
   \[
     \mathrm{Re}^{0.618}
     =\frac{\mathrm{Nu}_D}{C\,\mathrm{Pr}^{1/3}}
     =\frac{168}{0.193\times0.71^{1/3}}
     \approx987
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \mathrm{Re}\approx7.1\times10^4
   \]

7. Finally, the wind speed  
   \[
     v=\frac{\mathrm{Re}\,\nu}{D}
     =\frac{7.1\times10^4\times1.7\times10^{-5}}{0.15}
     \approx8.1\;\mathrm{m/s}
     \approx29\;\mathrm{km/h}
   \]

Final answer (brief):  
Average wind velocity ≃8.1 m/s ≃29 km/h.

Here is the step‐by‐step calculation of the theoretical density  
\(\rho\) for each metal in terms of its crystal structure, atomic weight \(M\),  
atomic radius \(r\), and the appropriate lattice constant \(a\).  In every case  
we use  
\[
\rho = \frac{\text{mass in unit cell}}{\text{volume of unit cell}}
     = \frac{Z\,M/N_A}{V_{\rm cell}}
\]
with \(N_A\) the Avogadro constant and \(Z\) the number of atoms per cell.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1)  Lead, Pb  (fcc, \(Z=4\))  
   
   – Lattice constant:  
     \[
       a = 2\sqrt{2}\,r
     \]
   – Volume of fcc cell:  
     \[
       V = a^3 = (2\sqrt{2}\,r)^3 = 16\sqrt{2}\,r^3
     \]
   – Mass in cell:  
     \[
       m = \frac{4\,M_{\rm Pb}}{N_A}
     \]
   – Density:  
     \[
       \rho_{\rm Pb}
       = \frac{4\,M_{\rm Pb}/N_A}{(2\sqrt{2}\,r_{\rm Pb})^3}
       = \frac{4\,M_{\rm Pb}}{N_A\,16\sqrt2\,r_{\rm Pb}^3}
       = \frac{M_{\rm Pb}}{4\sqrt2\,N_A\,r_{\rm Pb}^3}.
     \]
   Plugging in \(M_{\rm Pb}=207.2\rm\ g/mol\), \(r_{\rm Pb}=175\rm\ pm\)  
   (i.e.\ \(1.75\times10^{-8}\) cm), one finds  
   \[
     \rho_{\rm Pb}^{\rm theory}
     \approx 11.35\;\rm g/cm^3
     \quad
     (\rho_{\rm Pb}^{\rm exp}=11.34\;\rm g/cm^3).
   \]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2)  Chromium, Cr  (bcc, \(Z=2\))  

   – Lattice constant:  
     \[
       a = \frac{4\,r}{\sqrt3}
     \]
   – Volume of bcc cell:  
     \[
       V = a^3 = \Bigl(\frac{4r}{\sqrt3}\Bigr)^3 = \frac{64\,r^3}{3\sqrt3}
     \]
   – Mass in cell:  
     \[
       m = \frac{2\,M_{\rm Cr}}{N_A}
     \]
   – Density:  
     \[
       \rho_{\rm Cr}
       = \frac{2\,M_{\rm Cr}/N_A}{(4r_{\rm Cr}/\sqrt3)^3}
       = \frac{2\,M_{\rm Cr}}{N_A\,\frac{64\,r_{\rm Cr}^3}{3\sqrt3}}
       = \frac{3\sqrt3\,M_{\rm Cr}}{32\,N_A\,r_{\rm Cr}^3}.
     \]
   With \(M_{\rm Cr}=52.00\rm\ g/mol\), \(r_{\rm Cr}=125\rm\ pm\), one obtains  
   \[
     \rho_{\rm Cr}^{\rm theory}
     \approx 7.19\;\rm g/cm^3
     \quad
     (\rho_{\rm Cr}^{\rm exp}=7.19\;\rm g/cm^3).
   \]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3)  Copper, Cu  (fcc, \(Z=4\))  

   – Lattice constant:  
     \[
       a = 2\sqrt2\,r_{\rm Cu}
     \]
   – Density formula is identical in form to Pb’s:
     \[
       \rho_{\rm Cu}
       = \frac{M_{\rm Cu}}{4\sqrt2\,N_A\,r_{\rm Cu}^3}.
     \]
   Using \(M_{\rm Cu}=63.546\rm\ g/mol\), \(r_{\rm Cu}=128\rm\ pm\), gives  
   \[
     \rho_{\rm Cu}^{\rm theory}
     \approx 8.88\;\rm g/cm^3
     \quad
     (\rho_{\rm Cu}^{\rm exp}=8.96\;\rm g/cm^3).
   \]

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4)  Cobalt, Co  (hcp, \(Z=6\), \(c/a=1.623\))  

   – In hcp: \(a=2\,r_{\rm Co}\), \(c=1.623\,a\).  
   – Conventional hexagonal cell volume (6 atoms):  
     \[
       V = \frac{3\sqrt3}{2}\;a^2\,c
         = \frac{3\sqrt3}{2}\;a^2\,(1.623\,a)
         = \frac{3\sqrt3\,(1.623)}{2}\;a^3.
     \]
   – Mass in cell:  
     \[
       m = \frac{6\,M_{\rm Co}}{N_A}.
     \]
   – Density:
     \[
       \rho_{\rm Co}
       = \frac{6\,M_{\rm Co}/N_A}{\frac{3\sqrt3\,(1.623)}{2}\;a^3}
       = \frac{4\,M_{\rm Co}}{\sqrt3\,(1.623)\,N_A\,a^3}.
     \]
   With \(M_{\rm Co}=58.93\rm\ g/mol\), \(r_{\rm Co}=125\rm\ pm\),
   \(a=2r_{\rm Co}=250\rm\ pm\), one finds
   \[
     \rho_{\rm Co}^{\rm theory}
     \approx 8.84\;\rm g/cm^3
     \quad
     (\rho_{\rm Co}^{\rm exp}=8.90\;\rm g/cm^3).
   \]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary of final theoretical vs.\ experimental densities:

  • Pb: \(\rho_{\rm th}=11.35\), \(\rho_{\rm exp}=11.34\) (g/cm³)  
  • Cr: \(\rho_{\rm th}= 7.19\), \(\rho_{\rm exp}= 7.19\) (g/cm³)  
  • Cu: \(\rho_{\rm th}= 8.88\), \(\rho_{\rm exp}= 8.96\) (g/cm³)  
  • Co: \(\rho_{\rm th}= 8.84\), \(\rho_{\rm exp}= 8.90\) (g/cm³)

Here is a step-by-step solution.

1. Geometry and path difference  
   Let us place A at x=0, B at x=120 m, and Q at x=160 m.  
   Then  
   \[
     d_{AQ}=160~\rm m,\qquad d_{BQ}=40~\rm m,
   \]  
   so the path difference is  
   \[
     \Delta d = d_{AQ}-d_{BQ} = 160-40 = 120~\rm m.
   \]

2. Condition for destructive interference  
   Destructive interference occurs when the path difference is a half-odd multiple of the wavelength:
   \[
     \Delta d =\Bigl(n+\tfrac12\Bigr)\,\lambda,\quad n=0,1,2,\dots
   \]
   Hence
   \[
     \lambda = \frac{\Delta d}{n+\tfrac12} = \frac{120}{n+\tfrac12}\ {\rm m}.
   \]
   The longest wavelength corresponds to the smallest \(n\), namely \(n=0\):
   \[
     \lambda_{\rm destr,max} = \frac{120}{0.5} = 240~\rm m.
   \]

3. Condition for constructive interference  
   Constructive interference requires the path difference to be an integer multiple of the wavelength:
   \[
     \Delta d = m\,\lambda,\quad m=1,2,3,\dots
   \]
   so
   \[
     \lambda = \frac{\Delta d}{m} = \frac{120}{m}\ {\rm m}.
   \]
   The longest wavelength corresponds to the smallest nonzero \(m\), namely \(m=1\):
   \[
     \lambda_{\rm const,max} = \frac{120}{1} = 120~\rm m.
   \]

Final answers (in brief):

(a) \(\displaystyle \lambda_{\rm destr,max}=240\text{ m}\).  
(b) \(\displaystyle \lambda_{\rm const,max}=120\text{ m}\).

Solution:

1.  Let a water drop of radius \(r\) and density \(\rho\) fall through air of viscosity \(\eta\) under gravity \(g\).  At terminal speed \(v_t\), the downward gravitational force equals the upward viscous drag (Stokes’ law):

   Gravitational force (weight minus buoyancy is often approximated by weight if air density is negligible):
   \[
     F_{\rm grav}\;=\;m\,g
     \;=\;\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3\,\rho\;g\,.
   \]

   Viscous drag (Stokes’ law for a sphere):
   \[
     F_{\rm drag}\;=\;6\pi\,\eta\,r\,v_t\,.
   \]

2.  At terminal velocity,
   \[
     F_{\rm grav}\;=\;F_{\rm drag}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3\,\rho\,g
     \;=\;6\pi\,\eta\,r\,v_t.
   \]

3.  Solve for \(v_t\):
   \[
     v_t
     = \frac{\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3\,\rho\,g}{6\pi\,\eta\,r}
     = \frac{2\,r^2\,\rho\,g}{9\,\eta}
     \;\propto\;r^2.
   \]

4.  Conclusion:  \(v_t\) depends on
   - the radius \(r\) of the drop,
   - the fluid viscosity \(\eta\),
   - the density difference \(\rho\) and \(g\),

   but not on the drop’s electric charge, its temperature (except indirectly via fluid properties), or the speed of light.

Final Answer (in brief):

(A) Radius of drop.

Step 1:  Choose 1 g of alloy.  Then  
  – mass of Ge:  
    \[
      m_{\rm Ge}=0.15\times1~{\rm g}=0.15~{\rm g},
    \]  
  – mass of Si:  
    \[
      m_{\rm Si}=0.85\times1~{\rm g}=0.85~{\rm g}.
    \]

Step 2:  Compute the partial volumes using the pure‐element densities,  
  \[
    V_{\rm Ge}=\frac{m_{\rm Ge}}{\rho_{\rm Ge}}
             =\frac{0.15}{5.32}\;\text{cm}^3,
    \qquad
    V_{\rm Si}=\frac{m_{\rm Si}}{\rho_{\rm Si}}
               =\frac{0.85}{2.33}\;\text{cm}^3.
  \]  
  Hence the total volume of 1 g alloy is  
  \[
    V_{\rm tot}
     =V_{\rm Ge}+V_{\rm Si}
     =\frac{0.15}{5.32}+\frac{0.85}{2.33}
     \approx0.394\;\text{cm}^3.
  \]  

Step 3:  The alloy density is  
  \[
    \rho_{\rm alloy}
     =\frac{1~\text g}{V_{\rm tot}}
     =\frac{1}{0.394}
     \approx2.54\;\text{g/cm}^3.
  \]

Step 4:  Number of Ge atoms per cm³.  In 1 cm³ of alloy the mass of Ge is  
  \[
    m'_{\rm Ge}
      =\rho_{\rm alloy}\times0.15
      =(2.54\;\tfrac{\text g}{\text{cm}^3})(0.15)
      =0.381\;\text g.
  \]  
  The number of moles of Ge in 1 cm³ is  
  \[
    n_{\rm Ge}
      =\frac{m'_{\rm Ge}}{M_{\rm Ge}}
      =\frac{0.381}{72.64\;\text{g/mol}}
      \approx5.25\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol},
  \]  
  so the number of Ge atoms per cm³ is  
  \[
    N_{\rm Ge}
     =n_{\rm Ge}\,N_{\!A}
     \approx(5.25\times10^{-3})(6.022\times10^{23})
     \approx3.16\times10^{21}\;\text{atoms/cm}^3.
  \]

Final answers (brief):

• ρ_alloy ≃ 2.54 g/cm³  
• N_Ge ≃ 3.16×10²¹ atoms/cm³

Below “normal” means 
 A†A = AA†. 

1. Unitary matrices  
By definition U is unitary ⇔ U† = U⁻¹.  Hence  
\[
U\,U† = U\,U^{-1} = I
\quad\text{and}\quad
U†\,U = U^{-1}U = I
\;\Longrightarrow\;
U\,U† = U†\,U.
\]  
Thus U is normal.  

2. Orthogonal matrices  
If O is real‐orthogonal, Oᵀ = O⁻¹.  Then  
\[
O\,Oᵀ = O\,O^{-1} = I
\quad\text{and}\quad
Oᵀ\,O = O^{-1}O = I
\;\Longrightarrow\;
O\,Oᵀ = Oᵀ\,O,
\]  
so O is normal.  

3. Symmetric and antisymmetric (real)  
Let A be real.  Then A† = Aᵀ.  
– If Aᵀ = A (symmetric),  
\[
A\,A† = A\,A = A^2
= A\,A = A†A.
\]  
– If Aᵀ = -A (antisymmetric),  
\[
A† = Aᵀ = -A,\quad
A\,A† = A(-A) = -A^2
= (-A)A = A†A.
\]  
In both cases A A† = A† A, so A is normal.  

4. Hermitian and anti‐Hermitian  
By definition for a general (complex) matrix H,  
– Hermitian: H† = H ⇒ H H† = H^2 = H† H.  
– Anti‐Hermitian: H† = −H ⇒ H H† = −H^2 = H† H.  
Hence both are normal.  

Final brief answers (all satisfy A A† = A† A):  
• U unitary,  
• O orthogonal,  
• A symmetric,  
• A antisymmetric,  
• H Hermitian,  
• H anti‐Hermitian.

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.  Coordinate and sign conventions  
   Let r be the coordinate measured radially outward from the turn‐center.  In the rotating (non‐inertial) frame the centrifugal “body‐force” per unit mass is  
   a⃗ = aₙ ê_r  
   with magnitude  
   aₙ = 4 g = 4·9.80 m/s² = 39.2 m/s²  
   pointing outward.

2.  Hydrostatic (centrifugal) pressure gradient  
   In a fluid at rest in this rotating frame the pressure satisfies  
   ∇P = ρ f⃗ = ρ a⃗  
   Since a⃗ is purely radial, this becomes in 1D  
   dP/dr = ρ·aₙ.  

3.  Relate pressures at heart and brain  
   Let rₕ be the heart’s position, Pₕ its gauge pressure (120 torr).  
   The brain is Δr = 0.30 m radially inward ⇒ r_b = rₕ − Δr.  
   Integrate dP/dr from rₕ to r_b:  
   ⎧  
     P_b − Pₕ = ∫_(rₕ)^(r_b) ρ aₙ dr  
             = ρ aₙ (r_b − rₕ)  
             = ρ aₙ (−Δr)  
   ⎭  
   ⇒  
   P_b = Pₕ − ρ aₙ Δr.  

4.  Numerics  
   ρ = 1.06×10³ kg/m³  
   aₙ = 39.2 m/s²  
   Δr = 0.30 m  
   ⇒ ΔP = ρ aₙ Δr = (1.06×10³)(39.2)(0.30) Pa  
               ≃ 1.246×10⁴ Pa  
   Convert Pa → torr  (1 torr ≃ 133.322 Pa):  
     ΔP ≃ (1.246×10⁴ Pa)/(133.322 Pa/torr) ≃ 93.5 torr  
   ⇒  
   P_b = 120 torr − 93.5 torr = 26.5 torr.  

 Final answer (gauge pressures):  
   • P_heart = 120 torr  
   • P_brain ≃ 26.5 torr.

Here is a step‐by‐step comparison, followed by a concise summary.

1. Definitions  
   – A comet is a small icy body orbiting the Sun, developing a coma and tail when near perihelion.  
   – A meteor is the luminous streak produced when a meteoroid enters and ablates in Earth’s atmosphere.

2. Size  
   – Comet nucleus diameter:  
     \[1\ {\rm km}\;\lesssim\;D_{\rm comet}\;\lesssim\;60\ {\rm km}.\]  
   – Meteoroid (meteor) diameter:  
     \[10^{-3}\ {\rm m}\;\lesssim\;D_{\rm meteor}\;\lesssim\;1\ {\rm m}.\]

3. Distance from Observer  
   – Comet visible range (heliocentric distance):  
     \[0.3\ {\rm AU}\;\lesssim\;r_{\rm comet}\;\lesssim\;2\ {\rm AU},\quad 1\ {\rm AU}=1.496\times10^8\ {\rm km}.\]  
   – Meteor visible altitude above Earth’s surface:  
     \[80\ {\rm km}\;\lesssim\;h_{\rm meteor}\;\lesssim\;120\ {\rm km}.\]

4. Visibility Duration  
   – Comet: remains visible for months as it sweeps through perihelion,  
     \[t_{\rm comet}\sim10^6\text{–}10^7\ {\rm s}\quad(\sim10\text{–}100\text{ days}).\]  
   – Meteor: flash lasts only seconds or less, estimated by  
     \[
       t_{\rm meteor}\approx\frac{\Delta h}{v}
       \sim\frac{10^4\ {\rm m}}{2\times10^4\ {\rm m/s}}
       \approx0.5\ {\rm s}, 
     \]  
     so typically  
     \[t_{\rm meteor}\sim10^{-1}\text{–}1\ {\rm s}.\]

Final Answers (brief)

• Size:  
  – Comet nucleus: \(1\text{–}60\ {\rm km}\)  
  – Meteoroid/meteor: \(10^{-3}\text{–}1\ {\rm m}\)

• Distance from observer:  
  – Comet: \(0.3\text{–}2\ {\rm AU}\)  
  – Meteor: \(80\text{–}120\ {\rm km}\) altitude

• Visible time:  
  – Comet: \(10^6\text{–}10^7\ {\rm s}\) (weeks–months)  
  – Meteor: \(10^{-1}\text{–}1\ {\rm s}\) (fractions of a second)

Below is a step‐by‐step solution.  At the end, the numerical answer is restated briefly.

1. Data and symbols  
   • Mass of coffee: \(m_c=300\;\mathrm{g}=0.300\;\mathrm{kg}\)  
   • Initial temperature of coffee: \(T_{c,i}=90^\circ\mathrm C\)  
   • Final equilibrium temperature: \(T_f=60^\circ\mathrm C\)  
   • Initial temperature of ice: \(T_{i,i}=-20^\circ\mathrm C\)  
   • Specific heat capacity of water: \(c_w=4186\;\mathrm{J/(kg\cdot K)}\)  
   • Specific heat capacity of ice: \(c_i=2100\;\mathrm{J/(kg\cdot K)}\)  
   • Latent heat of fusion of ice: \(L_f=3.34\times10^5\;\mathrm{J/kg}\)  

2. Heat lost by coffee as it cools from \(90\) to \(60^\circ\mathrm C\):  
\[
  Q_{\rm lost}
  = m_c\,c_w\,(T_{c,i}-T_f)
  = (0.300)\,(4186)\,(90-60)
  = 0.300\times4186\times30
  \approx3.77\times10^4\;\mathrm J.
\]

3. Heat gained by an ice mass \(m_i\):  
   (a) Warm ice from \(-20\) to \(0^\circ\mathrm C\):  
   \(\Delta Q_1 = m_i\,c_i\,(0 - (-20)) = m_i\,c_i\,(20)\).  
   (b) Melt at \(0^\circ\mathrm C\):  
   \(\Delta Q_2 = m_i\,L_f\).  
   (c) Warm meltwater from \(0\) to \(60^\circ\mathrm C\):  
   \(\Delta Q_3 = m_i\,c_w\,(60 - 0)\).  

   Total absorbed:  
\[
  Q_{\rm gained}
  = m_i\Bigl[c_i\,(20)+L_f+c_w\,(60)\Bigr].
\]

4. Energy balance (\(Q_{\rm lost}=Q_{\rm gained}\)) and solve for \(m_i\):  
\[
  m_c\,c_w\,(T_{c,i}-T_f)
  \;=\;
  m_i\Bigl[c_i\,(20)+L_f+c_w\,(60)\Bigr]
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  m_i
  = \frac{m_c\,c_w\,(T_{c,i}-T_f)}
         {c_i\,20 + L_f + c_w\,60}.
\]
Substitute numbers:  
\[
  m_i
  = \frac{0.300\cdot4186\cdot30}
         {2100\cdot20 + 3.34\times10^5 + 4186\cdot60}
  \approx \frac{3.77\times10^4}{6.27\times10^5}
  \approx6.0\times10^{-2}\;\mathrm{kg}.
\]

Final answer (brief):  
Mass of ice required \(\displaystyle m_i\approx6.0\times10^{-2}\,\mathrm{kg}=60\;\mathrm g\).

Here’s a clear, step‐by‐step solution, with all equations in LaTeX, followed by the brief final answers.

1.  Speed just before impact  
   From energy (or from kinematics)  
   \[
     v^{2} = v_{0}^{2} + 2gh
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     v = \sqrt{2gh}
     = \sqrt{2\,(9.8\rm\ m/s^{2})\,(0.50\rm\ m)}
     = \sqrt{9.8}\approx3.13\rm\ m/s
   \]

2.  Average deceleration on landing  
   Use the kinematic relation for stopping over distance \(d\):  
   \[
     v^{2} = 0 + 2\,|a|\,d
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     |a| = \frac{v^{2}}{2d}
     = \frac{(3.13)^{2}}{2\,(0.02)}
     = \frac{9.8}{0.04}
     =245\rm\ m/s^{2}
   \]
   Since this is a deceleration,  
   \[
     a_{\rm avg} = -245\rm\ m/s^{2}.
   \]

3.  Average stopping force  
   Newton’s 2nd law in the vertical direction:
   \[
     \sum F = m\,a
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     F_{\rm patio} - mg = m\,a
     \]
   so
   \[
     F_{\rm patio}
     = m\,(a + g)
     = 80\bigl(-245 + 9.8\bigr)
     \approx -80\times235.2
     = -1.88\times10^{4}\rm\ N.
   \]
   The negative sign shows the force is upward; its magnitude is 
   \(|F_{\rm patio}|=1.9\times10^{4}\rm\ N.\)

Final Answers (brief)  
(a) \(a_{\rm avg} = -2.45\times10^{2}\rm\ m/s^{2}\)  
(b) \(|F_{\rm patio}| = 1.9\times10^{4}\rm\ N\)

Step 1: Newton’s law of universal gravitation  
The magnitude of the gravitational force between Earth (mass \(M_E\)) and Moon (mass \(M_M\)) separated by distance \(r\) is  
\[
F \;=\; G\,\frac{M_E\,M_M}{r^2}\,,
\]  
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

Step 2: Action–reaction pair  
By Newton’s third law, the force with which Earth pulls on the Moon,
\[
\mathbf{F}_{E\to M},
\]
has exactly the same magnitude as the force with which the Moon pulls on Earth,
\[
\mathbf{F}_{M\to E}\,.
\]
Hence
\[
\bigl|\mathbf{F}_{E\to M}\bigr|
\;=\;
\bigl|\mathbf{F}_{M\to E}\bigr|
\;=\;
G\,\frac{M_E\,M_M}{r^2}\,.
\]

Step 3: Newton’s second law and acceleration  
Each body’s acceleration is its net force divided by its mass.  Thus  
– Acceleration of the Moon due to Earth:  
\[
a_M
\;=\;
\frac{|\mathbf{F}_{E\to M}|}{M_M}
\;=\;G\,\frac{M_E}{r^2}\,.
\]  
– Acceleration of the Earth due to the Moon:  
\[
a_E
\;=\;
\frac{|\mathbf{F}_{M\to E}|}{M_E}
\;=\;G\,\frac{M_M}{r^2}\,.
\]

Step 4: Compare accelerations  
Since \(M_E\gg M_M\),  
\[
a_M = G\,\frac{M_E}{r^2}
\quad\gg\quad
a_E = G\,\frac{M_M}{r^2}\,.
\]  
Therefore the Moon’s acceleration toward Earth is much larger than Earth’s acceleration toward the Moon.

Final brief answer  
The gravitational forces are equal in magnitude, and the Moon accelerates more.  

Answer choice: (f) Both the same; the Moon.

Solution:

1.  Decay constant and survival probability  
   Let the half‐life be \(T_{1/2}\).  The decay constant is  
   \[
     \lambda = \frac{\ln 2}{T_{1/2}}.
   \]  
   The probability that a single nucleus survives up to time \(t\) is  
   \[
     P(\text{survive to }t) = e^{-\lambda t}.
   \]

2.  Probability to decay in an interval \([t,t+\Delta t]\)  
   The probability that it decays between \(t\) and \(t+\Delta t\) is  
   \[
     P(t < T \le t+\Delta t)
     =P(\text{survive to }t)\bigl[1-e^{-\lambda\Delta t}\bigr]
     =e^{-\lambda t}\bigl(1-e^{-\lambda\Delta t}\bigr).
   \]

3.  Memorylessness and independence  
   a)  Given it has survived up to \(t\), the conditional probability to decay in the next \(\Delta t\) is  
   \[
     P(T\le t+\Delta t\mid T>t)
     =1-e^{-\lambda\Delta t},
   \]  
   which depends only on \(\Delta t\), not on \(t\).  This is the memoryless property of the exponential distribution.  
   b)  Decays of two different nuclei are statistically independent Poisson processes.  What happens to one nucleus does not influence the other.

4.  Numerical example (\(\Delta t=1\) min)  
   If \(T_{1/2}=1\) min then \(\lambda=\ln2\) min\(^{-1}\) and  
   \[
     P(\text{decay in next 1 min})
     =1-e^{-\ln2}=1-\tfrac12=\tfrac12.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

- The decay of the first nucleus at \(t=1\) min has no effect on the second nucleus.  
- The probability that the second nucleus decays in the next minute remains  
  \[
    1 - e^{-\lambda\,(1\,\text{min})}
    =1-e^{-\ln2}
    =\tfrac12.
  \]  
- The events are random and independent, not cause–effect.

Solution.  
Let \(I_0\) be the initial amount of impurity.  In the first stage we remove  
\[
R_1=\frac{1}{n}\,I_0.
\]  
By hypothesis, each subsequent stage removes one-\(n\)th of the impurity removed in the previous stage, so  
\[
R_2=\frac{1}{n}R_1=\frac{1}{n^2}I_0,\quad
R_3=\frac{1}{n}R_2=\frac{1}{n^3}I_0,\;\dots
\]  
Hence the total impurity removed after infinitely many stages is the geometric series  
\[
R_{\rm tot}
=\sum_{k=1}^\infty R_k
=\sum_{k=1}^\infty\frac{1}{n^k}\,I_0
=\frac{I_0}{n}\,\frac{1}{1-\frac1n}
=\frac{I_0}{\,n-1\,}\,.
\]  
Thus the fraction of impurity removed is 
\[
\frac{R_{\rm tot}}{I_0}
=\frac{1}{n-1},
\]
and the fraction remaining is
\[
\frac{I_{\infty}}{I_0}
=1-\frac{1}{n-1}
=\frac{n-2}{\,n-1\,}\,.
\]

Case \(n=2\):
\[
\frac{I_{\infty}}{I_0}
=\frac{2-2}{2-1}=0,
\]
so no impurity remains—water can be made arbitrarily pure.

Case \(n=3\):
\[
\frac{I_{\infty}}{I_0}
=\frac{3-2}{3-1}=\frac12,
\]
so at least one-half of the impurity remains no matter how many stages are used.

Final answers (brief).  
1. Total removed: \(\displaystyle R_{\rm tot}=I_0\sum_{k=1}^\infty n^{-k}=\dfrac{I_0}{n-1}.\)  
2. Residual fraction: \(\displaystyle I_\infty/I_0=(n-2)/(n-1).\)  
3. For \(n=2\), \(I_\infty=0\) (perfect purity).  
4. For \(n=3\), \(I_\infty/I_0=1/2\) (one-half remains).

Solution Outline  

1. Let  
   L₀ = 10.50 m  (initial cable length at 20.0 °C)  
   D₀ = 0.350 m  (initial sphere diameter at 20.0 °C) ⇒ R₀ = D₀/2 = 0.175 m  
   h₀ = 2.00 mm = 0.00200 m  (initial clearance)  
   αₛ = 1.20×10⁻⁵ K⁻¹  (steel)  
   α_b = 1.90×10⁻⁵ K⁻¹  (brass)  

2. Let H be the fixed distance from pivot to floor.  Initially,  
   H = L₀ + R₀ + h₀.  

3. At temperature T = 20.0 °C + ΔT,  
   L = L₀(1 + αₛ ΔT),  
   R = R₀(1 + α_b ΔT),  
   clearance h(ΔT) = H – [L + R].  

4. The sphere just brushes the floor when h = 0, so  
   0 = H – [L + R]  
   ⇒ H = L₀(1+αₛΔT) + R₀(1+α_bΔT)  
   ⇒ L₀ + R₀ + h₀ = L₀ + L₀αₛΔT + R₀ + R₀α_bΔT  
   ⇒ L₀αₛΔT + R₀α_bΔT = h₀  
   ⇒ ΔT = h₀ / (L₀αₛ + R₀α_b).  

5. Numerically,  
   L₀αₛ = (10.50 m)(1.20×10⁻⁵ K⁻¹) = 1.26×10⁻⁴ m/K  
   R₀α_b = (0.175 m)(1.90×10⁻⁵ K⁻¹) = 3.33×10⁻⁶ m/K  
   ⇒ L₀αₛ + R₀α_b = 1.2933×10⁻⁴ m/K  

   ΔT = 0.00200 m / 1.2933×10⁻⁴ m/K = 15.5 K  

6. Therefore the contact temperature is  
   T = 20.0 °C + ΔT ≃ 35.5 °C.  

Final Answers (brief)  

• ΔT =  
\[
\Delta T \;=\;\frac{h_{0}}{L_{0}\,\alpha_{s} \;+\; R_{0}\,\alpha_{b}}
\;\approx\;\frac{0.00200}{(10.50)(1.20\times10^{-5}) + (0.175)(1.90\times10^{-5})}
\;=\;15.5\;\text{K}.
\]

• Temperature at which the sphere begins to brush the floor:  
\[
T = 20.0\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C} + 15.5\,\mathrm{K} \approx 35.5\,^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step outline of why the first‐row transition metals (Z = 21–30, i.e. Sc to Zn) show very similar chemistry:

1. Electronic configuration  
   Each atom has the general valence configuration  
   \[
     \text{M: }[\text{Ar}]\,3d^n\,4s^2,\quad n=1\;\text{to}\;10.
   \]

2. Incomplete 3d‐subshell  
   Because the 3d‐orbitals are only partly filled, these elements can lose various numbers of d‐electrons as well as the two 4s‐electrons, giving rise to multiple, but characteristic, oxidation states (especially +2).

3. Poor shielding by d‐electrons  
   The (n–1)d electrons do not shield the nuclear charge as effectively as s‐ or p‐electrons.  Hence the effective nuclear charge  
   \[
     Z_{\rm eff}\approx Z - S
   \]  
   changes only slowly across the row.  As a result the atomic and ionic radii vary little from Sc to Zn.

4. Nearly constant ionic radii  
   Because the radii of M²⁺ ions remain close in size, their lattice energies, solvation energies, and hence chemical behaviour are very similar.

5. Similar ionization energies and electronegativities  
   A slowly changing \(Z_{\rm eff}\) ⇒ similar 1st and 2nd ionization energies ⇒ similar tendencies to form M²⁺.

6. Common coordination chemistry  
   Partly filled d‐orbitals of comparable energy promote the formation of octahedral (and other) complexes, yielding analogous ligand‐field effects, colours and catalytic properties.

Final brief answer  
All first-row transition metals have the valence configuration \([\mathrm{Ar}]\,3d^n4s^2\) with an incomplete 3d subshell.  Their (n–1)d electrons shield poorly, so the effective nuclear charge and ionic radii change little across the series.  Consequently they exhibit very similar oxidation states (especially +2), ionization energies, complex‐forming and catalytic behaviour.

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1. Volume of the cylinder  
   Let the length be \(L=1.50\) m and the diameter \(d=0.900\) m, so the radius is \(r=d/2=0.450\) m.  
   \[
     V = \pi r^2 L
       = \pi (0.450\,{\rm m})^2(1.50\,{\rm m})
       \approx 0.9545\;{\rm m^3}.
   \]

2. Convert pressure and temperature to SI  
   \[
     P = 21.0\;{\rm atm}\times(1.01325\times10^5\;{\rm Pa/atm})
       =2.1288\times10^6\;{\rm Pa},
   \]
   \[
     T = 22.0\,^\circ{\rm C} = 22.0 + 273.15 =295.15\;{\rm K}.
   \]

3. Number of moles from the ideal‐gas law  
   \[
     PV = nRT
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     n = \frac{P\,V}{R\,T}
       = \frac{(2.1288\times10^6\;{\rm Pa})(0.9545\;{\rm m^3})}
              {(8.314\;{\rm J/(mol\;K)})(295.15\;{\rm K})}
       \approx 8.28\times10^2\;{\rm mol}.
   \]

4. Mass of the oxygen  
   Molar mass \(M=32.0\;{\rm g/mol}=0.0320\;{\rm kg/mol}\).  
   \[
     m = n\,M
       = (8.28\times10^2\;{\rm mol})(0.0320\;{\rm kg/mol})
       \approx 26.5\;{\rm kg}.
   \]

Final Answers (brief)

(a) \(n\approx8.28\times10^2\;{\rm mol}.\)  
(b) Mass increase \(\approx26.5\;{\rm kg}.\)

Let x₍b₎(t) and x₍c₎(t) be the displacements of the bike and car from the overtaking point at t=0.  Take the positive direction of motion as +.  

1. Initial data at t=0  
   • Bike: starts from rest ⇒ v₍b₎(0)=0, x₍b₎(0)=0  
   • Car: constant speed v₍c₎=40 m/s, and x₍c₎(0)=0  

2. Motion of the bike  
   – Uniform acceleration a from t=0 to t₁=18 s  
     v₍b₎(t)=a t, x₍b₎(t)=½ a t², 0≤t≤18  
   – Then constant speed vₘₐₓ=v₍b₎(18)=a·18 from t=18 s to t₂=27 s  

3. At t₂=27 s the bike overtakes the car ⇒ x₍b₎(27)=x₍c₎(27).  
   • Car: x₍c₎(27)=40·27  
   • Bike:  
     x₍b₎(27)=x₍b₎(18)+vₘₐₓ·(27–18)  
               =½ a·18² + (a·18)·9  
               =½·a·324 + 162 a  
               =162 a +162 a =324 a  
   ⇒ 324 a = 40·27 =1080  
   ⇒ a =1080/324 =10/3 m/s²  

4. Maximum speed of the bike  
   vₘₐₓ = a·18 = (10/3)·18 = 60 m/s  

5. Separation at t=18 s  
   • Car: x₍c₎(18)=40·18=720 m  
   • Bike: x₍b₎(18)=½·(10/3)·18² =540 m  
   ⇒ Δx(18)=720–540=180 m  

6. Maximum separation before overtaking  
   The separation Δx(t)=x₍c₎(t)–x₍b₎(t) grows while v₍b₎<v₍c₎ and then decreases once v₍b₎>v₍c₎.  
   Solve v₍b₎(t)=a t =40 ⇒ t=40·3/10=12 s.  
   At t=12 s:  
   x₍c₎(12)=40·12=480 m,  
   x₍b₎(12)=½·(10/3)·12²=240 m  
   ⇒ Δxₘₐₓ=480–240=240 m  

7. Matching with Column‐II  
   (A) vₘₐₓ=60 m/s ⇒ (2)  
   (B) a=10/3 m/s² ⇒ (3)  
   (C) Δx(18)=180 m ⇒ (4)  
   (D) Δxₘₐₓ=240 m ⇒ (1)  

Final Answer (in brief):  
A–2, B–3, C–4, D–1

Here is a step‐by‐step argument, followed by the brief answers.

1.  Transverse waves on a string  
    – Let the transverse displacement be \(y(x,t)\).  For small slopes \(\bigl|\partial y/\partial x\bigr|\ll1\) the net vertical force on an element comes from the tension \(T\) at each end:  
    \[
      T\sin\theta\big|_{x+\Delta x} - T\sin\theta\big|_{x}
      \;\approx\;
      T\,\frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial x^2}\,\Delta x.
    \]  
    – Newton’s second law gives  
    \[
      \mu\,\Delta x\,\frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial t^2}
      \;=\;
      T\,\frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial x^2}\,\Delta x,
    \]  
    so the wave equation is  
    \[
      \frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial t^2}
      \;=\;
      \frac{T}{\mu}\,\frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial x^2}.
    \]  
    – A sinusoidal solution \(y=A\sin(kx-\omega t)\) yields  
    \[
      \omega^2 = \frac{T}{\mu}\,k^2
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      c=\frac\omega k=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}.
    \]

2.  Longitudinal waves in a rod (or sound waves in a fluid)  
    – Displacement \(\xi(x,t)\) obeys  
    \[
      \rho\,\frac{\partial^2\xi}{\partial t^2}
      =E\,\frac{\partial^2\xi}{\partial x^2}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      c=\sqrt{\frac{E}{\rho}}
      \quad(\text{or }c=\sqrt{\tfrac{B}{\rho}}\text{ in fluids}),
    \]  
    where \(E\) is Young’s modulus (or \(B\) the bulk modulus) and \(\rho\) the density.

3.  Why no amplitude dependence?  
    – In each case the governing PDE is linear, with coefficients (\(T/\mu\), \(E/\rho\), …) independent of the wave’s amplitude \(A\).  
    – As a result the dispersion relation \(\omega^2= c^2k^2\) yields a constant \(c\), regardless of \(A\).

Final Answers (brief)

•  For all the small‐amplitude (linear) waves in this chapter  
   \[
     c \text{ does \emph{not} depend on the amplitude }A,
   \]  
   because the wave equation is linear and its coefficients do not involve \(A\).

•  Examples of the speed formulas:  
   \[
     c_{\rm string}=\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}, 
     \quad
     c_{\rm rod}=\sqrt{\frac{E}{\rho}},
     \quad
     c_{\rm fluid}=\sqrt{\frac{B}{\rho}}.
   \]

Step 1:  Draw free‐body forces on the block of mass m (spring constant k) when it carries charge Q and sits a distance y above the charged sheet.  

Above the sheet it feels  
• spring force (upward if stretched by y):  
   \(F_s=-k\,y\)  (we take y positive downward)  
• gravity (downward):  
   \(F_g=mg\)  
• electrostatic force due to the uniformly charged infinite sheet (field \(E=\sigma/(2\varepsilon_0)\) upward if both sheet and block are positively charged):  
   \(F_e=Q\,E=\frac{Q\,\sigma}{2\varepsilon_0}\)  

Step 2:  Find the equilibrium position y₀.  At equilibrium  
   \(-k\,y_0 + mg - \frac{Q\sigma}{2\varepsilon_0}=0  
   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad k\,y_0 = mg - \frac{Q\sigma}{2\varepsilon_0}\).  

Step 3:  Write the equation of small oscillations about y₀.  Let x=y−y₀ be the displacement from equilibrium.  Then  
   m d²y/dt² = −k y + mg − Qσ/(2ε₀)  
but substituting y=y₀+x and using the equilibrium condition gives  
   m d²x/dt² = −k x.  

Step 4:  Identify the angular frequency ω and period T.  
   d²x/dt² + (k/m) x = 0  
   ⇒ ω = √(k/m),   T = 2π √(m/k).  

Notice that Q (and hence the constant electrostatic term) enters only into y₀, not into the coefficient k/m of the restoring term.  Hence the time period is unchanged by charging the block.  

Final answer (brief):  
The time period remains the same,  
   \(\displaystyle T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}\)  
so choice (A).

Solution Outline:

1.  Differential magnetic force on a current element  
    \[
      d\mathbf{F} \;=\; I\,d\mathbf{L}\times\mathbf{B}\,.
    \]

2.  Work done in moving the element \(I\,d\mathbf{L}\) through displacement \(d\mathbf{l}\):
    \[
      dW_1 \;=\; d\mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{l}
               \;=\; \bigl(I\,d\mathbf{L}\times\mathbf{B}\bigr)\cdot d\mathbf{l}
               \;=\; I\,(d\mathbf{L}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{l}\,.
    \]

3.  Likewise, force on element \(I\,d\mathbf{l}\) is \(I\,d\mathbf{l}\times\mathbf{B}\), so moving it through \(d\mathbf{L}\) does
    \[
      dW_2 \;=\; \bigl(I\,d\mathbf{l}\times\mathbf{B}\bigr)\cdot d\mathbf{L}
               \;=\; I\,(d\mathbf{l}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{L}\,.
    \]

4.  Use the scalar triple‐product identity
    \[
      (a\times b)\cdot c \;=\; (b\times c)\cdot a
                      \;=\; (c\times a)\cdot b
                      \;=\; -\,(b\times a)\cdot c\,.
    \]
    Then
    \[
      dW_1
      = I\,(d\mathbf{L}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{l}
      = I\,\mathbf{B}\cdot(d\mathbf{l}\times d\mathbf{L})
      = -\,I\,\mathbf{B}\cdot(d\mathbf{L}\times d\mathbf{l})
      = -\,I\,(d\mathbf{l}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{L}
      = -\,dW_2\,.
    \]

5.  Hence
    \[
      dW_1 = -\,dW_2\,.
    \]

Final Answers (brief):

\[
  dW_1 \;=\; I\,(d\mathbf{L}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{l},
  \quad
  dW_2 \;=\; I\,(d\mathbf{l}\times\mathbf{B})\cdot d\mathbf{L},
  \quad
  dW_1 + dW_2 = 0\,.
\]

Step 1. Define the two functions  
\[
f(x)=\ln\frac{1+x}{1-x},  
\qquad  
g(x)=\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}\,.  
\]

Step 2. Compute their derivatives.  
\[
f'(x)
=\frac{d}{dx}\Bigl[\ln(1+x)-\ln(1-x)\Bigr]
=\frac1{1+x}+\frac1{1-x}
=\frac{2}{1-x^2}\,,
\]
\[
g'(x)=\frac{d}{dx}\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}
=\frac{1}{1-x^2}\,.
\]

Step 3. Observe that  
\[
f'(x)=2\,g'(x)
\;\Longrightarrow\;
f(x)=2\,g(x)+C.
\]
Since \(f(0)=0\) and \(g(0)=0\), we get \(C=0\). Hence  
\[
\ln\frac{1+x}{1-x}=2\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}\,.  
\]

Step 4. Equivalently,  
\[
\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}
=\frac12\ln\frac{1+x}{1-x}
=\operatorname{arctanh}x.
\]

Final Answers (in brief):  
\[
\boxed{
\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}
=\frac12\ln\frac{1+x}{1-x}
=\operatorname{arctanh}x,
\quad
\ln\frac{1+x}{1-x}
=2\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dt}{1-t^2}.
}
\]

Step 1.  By (11.4) 
\[
\tanh w \;=\;\frac{e^w-e^{-w}}{e^w+e^{-w}}
\]
so with \(w=i z\) 
\[
\tanh(i z)
=\frac{e^{i z}-e^{-i z}}{e^{i z}+e^{-i z}}\,. 
\]

Step 2.  By (12.2) and (12.3) 
\[
\sin z=\frac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{2i}, 
\qquad 
\cos z=\frac{e^{iz}+e^{-iz}}{2},
\]
hence
\[
\tan z=\frac{\sin z}{\cos z}
=\frac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{2i}\;\Big/\;\frac{e^{iz}+e^{-iz}}{2}
=\frac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{i\,(e^{iz}+e^{-iz})}\,. 
\]

Step 3.  Comparing the two expressions,
\[
\tanh(i z)
=\frac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{e^{iz}+e^{-iz}}
=i\,\frac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{i\,(e^{iz}+e^{-iz})}
=i\,\tan z\,.
\]

Final answer (in brief):

\[
\tanh(i z)=i\,\tan z\,. 
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.  Definitions and given formulae  
   In intrinsic Si the free‐electron charge density (negative) and hole charge density (positive) are given by  
   \[
     \rho_{h}=-\rho_{e}
     =6200\,T^{1.5}\,e^{-7000/T}
     \quad\Bigl[\mathrm{C/m^3}\Bigr],
   \]  
   and the mobilities by  
   \[
     \mu_{h}=2.3\times10^{5}\,T^{-2.7}
     ,\qquad
     \mu_{e}=2.1\times10^{5}\,T^{-2.5}
     \quad\Bigl[\mathrm{m^2/(V\,s)}\Bigr].
   \]

2.  Conductivity of intrinsic Si  
   The conductivity is the sum of the electron and hole contributions,
   \[
     \sigma
     =e\,n\,\mu_{e}+e\,p\,\mu_{h}
     \;=\;\rho_{h}\,\mu_{h}+|\rho_{e}|\,\mu_{e}.
   \]
   Since \(\rho_{h}=|\rho_{e}|\), one finds
   \[
     \boxed{
     \sigma(T)
     =\rho_{h}(T)\,\bigl[\mu_{h}(T)+\mu_{e}(T)\bigr]
     =6200\,T^{1.5}e^{-7000/T}\,
     \bigl(2.3\times10^{5}T^{-2.7}+2.1\times10^{5}T^{-2.5}\bigr).
     }
   \]

3.  Numerical evaluation  
   We put \(T\) in kelvins and calculate  
   \[
     \sigma(T)
     =e^{-7000/T}\Bigl[1.426\times10^{9}\,T^{-1.2}+1.302\times10^{9}\,T^{-1}\Bigr]
     \quad[\mathrm{S/m}].
   \]

   (a) At \(0^\circ\mathrm C\), \(T=273\) K:
   \[
     e^{-7000/273}\approx7.32\times10^{-12},\;
     T^{-1.2}\approx1.20\times10^{-3},\;
     T^{-1}\approx3.66\times10^{-3},
   \]
   \[
     \sigma(273)
     \approx \bigl(1.426\times10^{9}\cdot1.20\times10^{-3}
                   +1.302\times10^{9}\cdot3.66\times10^{-3}\bigr)
             \times7.32\times10^{-12}
     \approx4.7\times10^{-5}\,\mathrm{S/m}.
   \]

   (b) At \(40^\circ\mathrm C\), \(T=313\) K:
   \[
     e^{-7000/313}\approx1.96\times10^{-10},\;
     T^{-1.2}\approx1.01\times10^{-3},\;
     T^{-1}\approx3.20\times10^{-3},
   \]
   \[
     \sigma(313)
     \approx\bigl(1.426\times10^{9}\cdot1.01\times10^{-3}
                   +1.302\times10^{9}\cdot3.20\times10^{-3}\bigr)
             \times1.96\times10^{-10}
     \approx1.1\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{S/m}.
   \]

   (c) At \(80^\circ\mathrm C\), \(T=353\) K:
   \[
     e^{-7000/353}\approx2.46\times10^{-9},\;
     T^{-1.2}\approx8.79\times10^{-4},\;
     T^{-1}\approx2.83\times10^{-3},
   \]
   \[
     \sigma(353)
     \approx\bigl(1.426\times10^{9}\cdot8.79\times10^{-4}
                   +1.302\times10^{9}\cdot2.83\times10^{-3}\bigr)
             \times2.46\times10^{-9}
     \approx1.2\times10^{-2}\,\mathrm{S/m}.
   \]

Final brief answers:  
\[
  \sigma(0^\circ\mathrm C)\approx4.7\times10^{-5}\,\mathrm{S/m},\quad
  \sigma(40^\circ\mathrm C)\approx1.1\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{S/m},\quad
  \sigma(80^\circ\mathrm C)\approx1.2\times10^{-2}\,\mathrm{S/m}.
\]

Step-by-step discussion

1. Definition and basic properties  
   – A Giant Molecular Cloud (GMC) is a cold (T≃10–20 K), dense (n≃10²–10⁶ cm⁻³) interstellar cloud, typically  
     • Mass: M∼10⁴–10⁶ M⊙  
     • Radius: R∼10–100 pc  
     • Composition: ≃90% H₂, ≃10% He + dust + trace molecules (e.g. CO)  

2. Gravitational instability and Jeans criterion  
   – A region of density ρ will collapse if its mass exceeds the Jeans mass  
     \[
       M_J \;=\;\left(\frac{5\,k_B\,T}{G\,\mu\,m_H}\right)^{3/2}
       \left(\frac{3}{4\pi\,\rho}\right)^{1/2}\!,
     \]  
     where k_B is Boltzmann’s constant, μm_H the mean molecular weight, G the gravitational constant.  

3. Collapse timescale  
   – The free–fall time for a uniform sphere of density ρ is  
     \[
       t_{\rm ff} \;=\;\sqrt{\frac{3\pi}{32\,G\,\rho}}\;.  
     \]  

4. Fragmentation and protostar formation  
   – Turbulence and magnetic fields cause the GMC to fragment into smaller clumps  
   – Each clump with M_clump > M_J collapses under self-gravity  
   – Collapse leads to dense cores → protostars → eventual ignition of H‐burning  

5. Role in star formation  
   – GMCs are the primary nurseries of stars in galaxies  
   – Their fragmentation regulates the initial mass function (IMF) of newborn stars  
   – Feedback (winds, radiation, supernovae) from young stars disperses the GMC  

Final answers (brief)

• A giant molecular cloud (GMC) is a cold (T∼10 K), dense (n∼10²–10⁶ cm⁻³), massive (10⁴–10⁶ M⊙), ∼10–100 pc–scale complex of H₂ and dust in the ISM.  
• GMCs become gravitationally unstable when M> M_J, with  
  \[
    M_J=\Bigl(\tfrac{5\,k_B\,T}{G\,\mu\,m_H}\Bigr)^{3/2}\Bigl(\tfrac{3}{4\pi\rho}\Bigr)^{1/2}.
  \]  
• They fragment and collapse on a free-fall timescale  
  \[
    t_{\rm ff}=\sqrt{\frac{3\pi}{32G\rho}}\;,
  \]  
  forming protostars and star clusters.  
• GMCs thus serve as the birthplaces of most stars in the Milky Way.

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.  All equations are in LaTeX.

1.  Write the total flux through the ring, \(\Phi\), as the sum of the mutual flux and the self–flux:  
   \[
     \Phi = M\,I_{\rm solenoid}(t)\;+\;L\,i(t)\,.
   \]

2.  By Faraday’s law the induced emf in the ring is  
   \[
     \varepsilon \;=\;-\,\frac{d\Phi}{dt}
        \;=\;-\,M\,\frac{dI_{\rm solenoid}}{dt}
           \;-\;L\,\frac{di}{dt}\,.
   \]

3.  Kirchhoff’s loop law around the ring gives  
   \[
     \varepsilon + R\,i = 0
     \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
     -\,M\,\frac{dI_{\rm solenoid}}{dt}
     -\,L\,\frac{di}{dt} + R\,i = 0
     \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
     L\,\frac{di}{dt} + R\,i = M\,\frac{dI_{\rm solenoid}}{dt}\,.
   \]

4.  Since \(I_{\rm solenoid}(t)=I_0\,t\), we have \(\dfrac{dI_{\rm solenoid}}{dt}=I_0\).  The ODE becomes  
   \[
     L\,\frac{di}{dt} + R\,i = M\,I_0\,.
   \]

5.  The steady‐state (long–time) solution is obtained by setting \(\tfrac{di}{dt}=0\):  
   \[
     i_{\max} = \frac{M\,I_0}{R}\,.
   \]

6.  Hence the maximum current in the ring is  
   \[
     \boxed{\,\frac{M\,I_0}{R}\,}
   \]
   which corresponds to choice (B).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final Answer (brief):  
\[
   i_{\max} = \frac{M\,I_0}{R}\quad\text{(choice B).}
\]

Solution.  
Given a balloon bursts at volume \(V=0.900\;\mathrm L\) and the internal pressure \(P=1.00\;\mathrm{atm}\).  The temperature is  
\[
T = 22.0\,^\circ\mathrm C = 22.0 + 273.15 = 295.15\;\mathrm K.
\]  
We treat the gas as ideal with constant \(P\) and \(T\).  

1.  Number of moles just before bursting  
   By the ideal‐gas law,
   \[
     P V = n R T
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     n = \frac{P V}{R T},
   \]
   where \(R = 0.08206\;\mathrm{L\cdot atm/(mol\cdot K)}\).  Thus
   \[
     n = \frac{(1.00\;\mathrm{atm})(0.900\;\mathrm L)}
              {(0.08206\;\mathrm{L\,atm/(mol\,K)})(295.15\;\mathrm K)}
       = 0.03718\;\mathrm{mol}.
   \]

2.  Mass of air  
   The average molar mass of air is \(M_{\rm air}=28.97\;\mathrm{g/mol}\).  Hence
   \[
     m_{\rm air} = n\,M_{\rm air}
                 = (0.03718\;\mathrm{mol})(28.97\;\mathrm{g/mol})
                 = 1.08\;\mathrm g.
   \]

3.  Mass of helium  
   For helium \(M_{\rm He}=4.003\;\mathrm{g/mol}\).  Thus
   \[
     m_{\rm He} = n\,M_{\rm He}
                = (0.03718\;\mathrm{mol})(4.003\;\mathrm{g/mol})
                = 0.149\;\mathrm g.
   \]

Final answers (3‐significant‐figure):  
(a) \(m_{\rm air}=1.08\;\mathrm g\).  
(b) \(m_{\rm He}=0.149\;\mathrm g\).

Below is a step-by-step derivation for flow in a circular tube of constant surface temperature \(T_s\), followed by the physical interpretation of the logarithmic mean temperature difference (LMTD) and why it must be used instead of an arithmetic mean.

1.  Differential energy balance  
    Consider a fluid of mass‐flow rate \(\dot m\) and specific heat \(c_p\) flowing in a tube of wetted perimeter \(P\).  Over a small length \(dx\), the fluid temperature rises from \(T(x)\) to \(T(x)+dT\) by absorbing heat \(dQ\):
    \[
      dQ \;=\;\dot m\,c_p\,dT
      \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
      dT \;=\;\frac{dQ}{\dot m\,c_p}\,.
    \]

2.  Convective‐heat‐flux at the wall  
    The local heat flux from the wall at \(T_s\) into the fluid is
    \[
      dQ \;=\; h\,P\,[\,T_s - T(x)\,]\,dx,
    \]
    where \(h\) is the convective‐heat‐transfer coefficient.

3.  Ordinary differential equation  
    Equate the two expressions for \(dQ\):
    \[
      \dot m\,c_p\,dT 
      \;=\; h\,P\,[\,T_s - T(x)\,]\,dx
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \frac{dT}{T_s - T} \;=\;\frac{h\,P}{\dot m\,c_p}\,dx.
    \]
    Integrate from inlet \(x=0,\,T=T_i\) to outlet \(x=L,\,T=T_o\):
    \[
      \int_{T_i}^{T_o}\frac{dT}{T_s - T}
      = \int_{0}^{L}\frac{h\,P}{\dot m\,c_p}\,dx
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      -\ln\!\Bigl[\tfrac{T_s - T_o}{T_s - T_i}\Bigr]
      = \frac{h\,P\,L}{\dot m\,c_p}.
    \]

4.  Total heat‐transfer rate  
    Either from the integrated convection or from the enthalpy rise,
    \[
      Q = \dot m\,c_p\,(T_o - T_i)
      = h\,P
        \int_{0}^{L}\bigl[T_s - T(x)\bigr]\,dx.
    \]
    Carrying out the integral gives
    \[
      Q
      = h\,P\,L\;\frac{(T_s - T_i) - (T_s - T_o)}
                      {\ln\!\bigl[\,(T_s - T_i)/(T_s - T_o)\bigr]}
      = U\,A\,\Delta T_{\rm lm}
    \]
    where \(A=P\,L\) and we identify the logarithmic mean temperature difference
    \[
      \boxed{
      \Delta T_{\rm lm}
      = \frac{\Delta T_1 - \Delta T_2}
             {\ln\!\bigl(\Delta T_1/\Delta T_2\bigr)},
      \quad
      \Delta T_1 = T_s - T_i,\;
      \Delta T_2 = T_s - T_o.
      }
    \]

5.  Physical interpretation  
    •  ΔT(x)\(=T_s - T(x)\) decays exponentially along the tube.  
    •  The LMTD is the constant temperature‐difference which, when multiplied by the total area \(A\), yields the exact same total heat‐transfer rate that results from the true varying ΔT(x).  

6.  Why not the arithmetic mean?  
    •  An arithmetic average \(\tfrac12(\Delta T_1+\Delta T_2)\) does not correctly weight the local driving‐force \(\Delta T(x)\) in the exponential profile and would give an inexact heat‐flux.  
    •  Only the logarithmic form emerges from the exact integration of \(Q=\int h\,\Delta T(x)\,dA\).  

Final answers (brief):

1.  The LMTD,
    \[
      \Delta T_{\rm lm}
      = \frac{(T_s - T_i)\;-\;(T_s - T_o)}
             {\ln\!\bigl[\,(T_s - T_i)/(T_s - T_o)\bigr]},
    \]
    is the equivalent uniform temperature difference that produces the same total heat transfer as the true, exponentially varying \(\Delta T(x)\).

2.  We use the logarithmic mean instead of the arithmetic mean because the local temperature‐difference decays exponentially along the tube and the exact integration of heat flux over the surface area yields the logarithmic form.

Here is a systematic solution.  In what follows  
A = 0.12 m²,  
d = 1.2 cm = 0.012 m,  
V₀ = 120 V,  
t = 4.0 mm = 0.004 m,  
K = 4.8,  
ε₀ = 8.854×10⁻¹² F/m.  

1.  Capacitance before inserting the slab  
   C₀ = ε₀ A / d  
   \[
     C_{0} \;=\;\frac{\varepsilon_{0}A}{d}
     \;=\;\frac{(8.854\times10^{-12})(0.12)}{0.012}
     \approx8.85\times10^{-11}\;\mathrm{F}.
   \]

2.  Capacitance with the slab symmetrically in place  
   The system is three capacitors in series: two vacuum gaps of total thickness (d–t) and one dielectric slab of thickness t.  Hence  
   \[
     \frac1C \;=\;\frac{d-t}{\varepsilon_{0}A}
                  \;+\;\frac{t}{K\,\varepsilon_{0}A}
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     C \;=\;\frac{\varepsilon_{0}A}{(d-t)+\tfrac{t}{K}}.
   \]  
   Numerically  
   \[
     C \;=\;\frac{(8.854\times10^{-12})(0.12)}
               {0.008+\frac{0.004}{4.8}}
     \approx1.20\times10^{-10}\;\mathrm{F}.
   \]

3.  Free charge on the plates (before and after insertion)  
   Battery disconnected ⇒ Q is constant:  
   \[
     Q \;=\;C_{0}V_{0}
         \;=\;(8.85\times10^{-11})(120)
         \approx1.06\times10^{-8}\;\mathrm{C}.
   \]

4.  Electric field in the vacuum gaps  
   \[
     E_{\rm vac}
     =\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}
     =\frac{Q/A}{\varepsilon_{0}}
     =\frac{1.06\times10^{-8}/0.12}{8.854\times10^{-12}}
     \approx1.00\times10^{4}\;\mathrm{V/m}.
   \]

5.  Electric field in the dielectric  
   \[
     E_{\rm diel}
     =\frac{E_{\rm vac}}{K}
     =\frac{1.00\times10^{4}}{4.8}
     \approx2.08\times10^{3}\;\mathrm{V/m}.
   \]

6.  New potential difference across the plates  
   \[
     V'
     =E_{\rm vac}(d-t)+E_{\rm diel}\,t
     =1.00\times10^{4}(0.008)+2.08\times10^{3}(0.004)
     \approx88.3\;\mathrm{V}.
   \]

7.  Work done by external agent in inserting the slab  
   Since the battery is disconnected, the external work equals the change in stored energy:  
   \[
     W
     =\Delta U
     =\frac12\,Q^{2}\Bigl(\frac1{C}-\frac1{C_{0}}\Bigr).
   \]  
   Numerically  
   \[
     W
     =\frac12\,(1.06\times10^{-8})^{2}
       \Bigl(\frac1{1.20\times10^{-10}}-\frac1{8.85\times10^{-11}}\Bigr)
     \approx-1.7\times10^{-7}\;\mathrm{J}.
   \]  
   The negative sign indicates the system does work on the slab; the magnitude is  
   \[
     |W|\approx1.7\times10^{-7}\;\mathrm{J}.
   \]

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final Answers (brief)  
(a) C₀ = 8.85×10⁻¹¹ F  
(b) C = 1.20×10⁻¹⁰ F  
(c) Q (before) = 1.06×10⁻⁸ C  
(d) Q (after) = 1.06×10⁻⁸ C  
(e) E₍vac₎ = 1.00×10⁴ V/m  
(f) E₍diel₎ = 2.08×10³ V/m  
(g) V′ = 88.3 V  
(h) |W| = 1.7×10⁻⁷ J

   \]

\]

Here is the solution, step by step, with all equations in LaTeX:

1. Given  
\[
\omega(t)=20-\tfrac12\,t^2\quad\bigl[\mathrm{rad}/\mathrm s\bigr].
\]

2. (a) Time of reversal \(t_r\) occurs when \(\omega(t_r)=0\):  
\[
20-\tfrac12\,t_r^2=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
t_r^2=40
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
t_r=\sqrt{40}=2\sqrt{10}\approx6.324\;\mathrm s.
\]

3. (b) Angle turned between \(t=0\) and \(t=t_r\) is  
\[
\theta
=\int_{0}^{t_r}\omega(t)\,dt
=\int_{0}^{t_r}\Bigl(20-\tfrac12 t^2\Bigr)\,dt
=\Bigl[20t-\tfrac{1}{6}t^3\Bigr]_0^{t_r}.
\]
Substitute \(t_r=2\sqrt{10}\):  
\[
\theta
=20(2\sqrt{10})-\tfrac16(2\sqrt{10})^3
=40\sqrt{10}-\tfrac16\,(8\cdot10\sqrt{10})
=40\sqrt{10}-\tfrac{80}{6}\sqrt{10}
=\tfrac{80}{3}\,\sqrt{10}\approx84.3\;\mathrm{rad}.
\]

Final answers (brief):

a. \(t_r=2\sqrt{10}\,\mathrm s\approx6.32\;\mathrm s\).  
b. \(\theta=\frac{80}{3}\sqrt{10}\,\mathrm{rad}\approx84.3\;\mathrm{rad}.\)

Solution:

Step 1: Convert the angular speeds from rpm to rad/s  
\[
\omega_i = 1200~\text{rpm}
        = 1200\times\frac{2\pi}{60}~\frac{\rm rad}{\rm s}
        = 40\pi~\frac{\rm rad}{\rm s},
\qquad
\omega_f = 4500~\text{rpm}
        = 4500\times\frac{2\pi}{60}~\frac{\rm rad}{\rm s}
        = 150\pi~\frac{\rm rad}{\rm s}.
\]

Step 2: Assume constant angular acceleration \(\alpha\).  The total angular displacement is
\[
\theta = \omega_{\rm avg}\,t
\quad\text{with}\quad
\omega_{\rm avg} = \frac{\omega_i + \omega_f}{2}.
\]
So
\[
\omega_{\rm avg}
= \frac{40\pi + 150\pi}{2}
= 95\pi~\frac{\rm rad}{\rm s},
\]
and for \(t=10\rm\,s\),
\[
\theta = (95\pi)\times 10 = 950\pi~\rm rad.
\]

Step 3: Convert the angular displacement to revolutions:
\[
N = \frac{\theta}{2\pi}
  = \frac{950\pi}{2\pi}
  = 475~\text{revolutions}.
\]

Answer: 475

Brief final answer:
The wheel makes 475 revolutions.

Here is a step‐by‐step study of the series
\[
\sum_{n=1}^\infty\Bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr)^{2n}\,.
\]

1.  Rewrite it as a geometric series.  Set
\[
q \;=\;\Bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr)^2,
\quad
a_n \;=\;q^n,
\]
so that
\[
\sum_{n=1}^\infty\Bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr)^{2n}
=\sum_{n=1}^\infty q^n.
\]

2.  Compute \(\bigl|\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\bigr|\).  Since
\[
|2+i|^2=2^2+1^2=5,
\quad
|3-4i|^2=3^2+(-4)^2=9+16=25,
\]
we get
\[
\Bigl|\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr|
=\sqrt{\frac{5}{25}}
=\frac1{\sqrt5}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
|q|=\Bigl|\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr|^2=\frac15<1.
\]

3.  Conclusion by the geometric‐series test:
\[
\sum_{n=1}^\infty q^n
\quad\text{converges (absolutely) since }|q|<1.
\]
Its sum is
\[
\sum_{n=1}^\infty q^n
=\frac{q}{1-q}
=\frac{\Bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr)^2}
{1-\Bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\Bigr)^2}\,.
\]

—————

Final answer (in brief):

• The series is geometric with ratio 
\(\displaystyle q=\bigl(\tfrac{2+i}{3-4i}\bigr)^2\) and 
\(|q|=\tfrac15<1\).

• Hence it converges absolutely.

• Its sum is 
\(\displaystyle \tfrac{q}{1-q}
=\frac{\bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\bigr)^2}
{1-\bigl(\frac{2+i}{3-4i}\bigr)^2}\).

Here is the mathematical formulation of the transient one‐dimensional heat‐conduction problem in a solid sphere of radius \(r_{o}\) with temperature‐dependent thermal conductivity \(k(T)\), cooling by both convection and radiation at the surface.

1) Governing partial‐differential equation (spherical coordinates, no internal heat generation):
\[
\rho c_{p}\,\frac{\partial T}{\partial t}
\;=\;
\frac{1}{r^{2}}\,
\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\!\Bigl[\,k(T)\,r^{2}\,\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}\Bigr],
\qquad 0<r<r_{o},\;t>0.
\]

2) Boundary conditions

a) Symmetry at the center (\(r=0\)):
\[
\left.\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}\right|_{r=0}=0.
\]

b) Convection and radiation at the surface (\(r=r_{o}\)):
\[
-\,k\bigl(T(r_{o},t)\bigr)\,
\left.\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}\right|_{r=r_{o}}
\;=\;
h\bigl[T(r_{o},t)-T_{\infty}\bigr]
\;+\;
\varepsilon\,\sigma\Bigl[T(r_{o},t)^{4}-T_{\rm surr}^{4}\Bigr],
\]
where \(\sigma\) is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant.

3) Initial condition:
\[
T(r,0)=T_{i}
\qquad\forall\,0\le r\le r_{o}.
\]

——————————————————————————

Brief summary of final answer:

Governing PDE:
\[
\rho c_{p}\,\frac{\partial T}{\partial t}
=\frac{1}{r^{2}}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\Bigl(k(T)\,r^{2}\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}\Bigr).
\]

BC at \(r=0\):
\[
\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}=0.
\]

BC at \(r=r_{o}\):
\[
-\,k(T)\frac{\partial T}{\partial r}
=h\bigl(T-T_{\infty}\bigr)
+\varepsilon\sigma\bigl(T^{4}-T_{\rm surr}^{4}\bigr).
\]

IC:
\[
T(r,0)=T_{i}.
\]

Here is a complete, step‐by‐step solution for the 2‐mass, 2‐spring system shown schematically as

 fixed wall  
 ↓ spring (2k)  
 ↓ mass (4m)  
 ↓ spring (k)  
 ↓ mass (2m)  

We take the displacements from equilibrium of the top mass and bottom mass to be \(x_{1}(t)\) and \(x_{2}(t)\), respectively, both positive downward.

1.  Equations of motion  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
  
  For the top mass (mass \(4m\)):  
  \[
    4m\,\ddot x_1 \;=\;-\,(\text{force from spring }2k)
    \;+\;(\text{force from spring }k)
    \;=\;-2k\,x_1 \;+\;k\,(x_2-x_1)\,,
  \]  
  so
  \[
    4m\,\ddot x_1 \;=\;-3k\,x_1 + k\,x_2.
  \]

  For the bottom mass (mass \(2m\)):  
  \[
    2m\,\ddot x_2 \;=\;-\,(\text{force from spring }k)
    \;=\;-\,k\,(x_2 - x_1)
    \;=\;-k\,x_2 + k\,x_1.
  \]  

  In matrix form:  
  \[
    \begin{pmatrix}4m&0\\0&2m\end{pmatrix}
    \begin{pmatrix}\ddot x_1\\\ddot x_2\end{pmatrix}
    \;+\;
    \begin{pmatrix}3k&-k\\-k&k\end{pmatrix}
    \begin{pmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{pmatrix}
    = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}.
  \]

2.  Characteristic equation  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
We seek solutions \(x_i\propto e^{i\omega t}\).  The secular determinant is
\[
  \det\Bigl(\mathbf K - \omega^2\,\mathbf M\Bigr)
  \;=\;
  \det
  \begin{pmatrix}
    3k - 4m\,\omega^2 & -k\\[6pt]
    -k               & k - 2m\,\omega^2
  \end{pmatrix}
  = 0.
\]
Compute:
\[
  (3k - 4m\omega^2)(k - 2m\omega^2)\;-\;k^2 = 0
  \;\Longrightarrow\;
  2k^2 \;-\;10km\,\omega^2 \;+\;8m^2\omega^4=0
\]
or
\[
  k^2 \;-\;5km\,\omega^2 \;+\;4m^2\omega^4 =0.
\]
This is quadratic in \(\omega^2\).  Solving,
\[
  \omega^2 = \frac{5km \pm \sqrt{25k^2m^2 - 16k^2m^2}}{8m^2}
           = \frac{5km \pm 3km}{8m^2}
  \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
  \begin{cases}
    \displaystyle
      \omega_1^2 = \frac{8k m}{8m^2} = \frac{k}{m},\\[6pt]
    \displaystyle
      \omega_2^2 = \frac{2k m}{8m^2} = \frac{k}{4m}.
  \end{cases}
\]

Thus the two normal‐mode frequencies are
\[
  \boxed{
    \omega_1 = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, 
    \qquad
    \omega_2 = \sqrt{\frac{k}{4m}}.
  }
\]

3.  Normal‐mode shapes  
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
For each \(\omega^2\) we solve
\[
  (3k -4m\omega^2)\,A \;-\;k\,B = 0
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  \frac{B}{A}
  = \frac{3k -4m\omega^2}{\,k\,}.
\]

•  For \(\omega^2=\tfrac{k}{m}\):  
  \[
    \frac{B}{A}
    = \frac{3k -4m\dfrac{k}{m}}k
    = \frac{3k -4k}{k} = -1,
  \]
  so the mode is 
  \[
    (x_1,x_2)\propto(1,\,-1)\quad\text{(masses move out of phase).}
  \]

•  For \(\omega^2=\tfrac{k}{4m}\):  
  \[
    \frac{B}{A}
    = \frac{3k -4m\dfrac{k}{4m}}k
    = \frac{3k -k}{k} = 2,
  \]
  so the mode is 
  \[
    (x_1,x_2)\propto(1,\,2)
    \quad\text{(both masses move in phase, bottom twice amplitude).}
  \]

4.  Final answers (brief)  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Characteristic frequencies:
\[
  \omega_1 = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, 
  \quad
  \omega_2 = \sqrt{\frac{k}{4m}}.
\]
Corresponding normalized mode–shape ratios \(\bigl(x_1:x_2\bigr)\):
\[
  \omega_1:\; (1 : -1),
  \qquad
  \omega_2:\;\bigl(1 : 2\bigr).
\]

Step-by‐step outline

1.  The FLRW metric  
   In a homogeneous, isotropic universe the line element is
   $$ds^2 = -c^2\,dt^2 + a^2(t)\,\Biggl[\frac{dr^2}{1 - k\,r^2} + r^2\,(d\theta^2 + \sin^2\theta\,d\phi^2)\Biggr]\,. $$  
   Here  
   • \(a(t)\) is the scale factor,  
   • \(k\in\{-1,0,1\}\) is the spatial curvature parameter.

2.  Proper distance and Hubble’s law  
   For two comoving points separated by a constant coordinate distance \(\chi\), the proper distance at time \(t\) is  
   $$D(t)=a(t)\,\chi\,. $$
   Differentiating, one finds  
   $$\dot D = \dot a\,\chi = \frac{\dot a}{a}\,D \equiv H(t)\,D\,, $$
   which is Hubble’s law \(v=H\,D\).

3.  “Expanding into” in General Relativity  
   • In GR the metric \(g_{\mu\nu}(t)\) defines distances intrinsically. There is no requirement for an “outside” or embedding space.  
   • If space is infinite (\(k\le0\)), it remains infinite as \(a(t)\) grows. If space is finite (\(k=+1\)), it is a closed 3-sphere with no boundary—still no “outside.”  

4.  Balloon analogy and embeddings  
   • The 2-D balloon picture uses a 3-D embedding to help intuition, but in 3-D GR no higher-dimensional “room” is needed.  
   • Asking what our 3-D universe expands “into” invokes an unnecessary extra dimension.  

Final brief answers

1.  Metric and expansion law  
    • \(ds^2 = -c^2dt^2 + a^2(t)\bigl[\dots\bigr]\)  
    • Proper distance \(D(t)=a(t)\chi\), expansion rate \(\dot D=H(t)D\).  

2.  What is it expanding “into”?  
   No physical “outside” is required or predicted. Space itself stretches; there is neither edge nor external volume into which our universe expands.

Solution:

We work in 1 + 1 dimensions (x, t) with light speed c = 3×10^8 m/s. For two events to be causally connected with A → X, their spacetime interval must be timelike or lightlike:
\[
(\Delta s)^2 \;=\; c^2(\Delta t)^2 \;-\; (\Delta x)^2 \;\ge\; 0.
\]

a. Between A (300 m, 2 μs) and B (1200 m, 6 μs):

1. Compute separations:
   \[
   \Delta x = x_B - x_A = 1200 - 300 = 900\;\mathrm{m},\qquad
   \Delta t = t_B - t_A = 6\,\mu\mathrm{s} - 2\,\mu\mathrm{s} = 4\times10^{-6}\,\mathrm{s}.
   \]
2. Compute \(c\,\Delta t\):
   \[
   c\,\Delta t = (3\times10^8\,\mathrm{m/s})(4\times10^{-6}\,\mathrm{s})
                = 1200\;\mathrm{m}.
   \]
3. Compute the interval:
   \[
   (\Delta s)^2 = (c\,\Delta t)^2 - (\Delta x)^2
                = (1200)^2 - (900)^2
                = 1.44\times10^6 - 0.81\times10^6
                = 0.63\times10^6\;>\;0.
   \]
Since \((\Delta s)^2>0\), A–B is timelike; A could cause B (requiring signal speed \(v = \Delta x/\Delta t = 0.75\,c < c\)).

b. Between A (300 m, 2 μs) and C (2400 m, 8 μs):

1. Compute separations:
   \[
   \Delta x = 2400 - 300 = 2100\;\mathrm{m},\qquad
   \Delta t = 8\,\mu\mathrm{s} - 2\,\mu\mathrm{s} = 6\times10^{-6}\,\mathrm{s}.
   \]
2. Compute \(c\,\Delta t\):
   \[
   c\,\Delta t = (3\times10^8)(6\times10^{-6}) = 1800\;\mathrm{m}.
   \]
3. Compute the interval:
   \[
   (\Delta s)^2 = (1800)^2 - (2100)^2
                = 3.24\times10^6 - 4.41\times10^6
                = -1.17\times10^6\;<\;0.
   \]
Since \((\Delta s)^2<0\), A–C is spacelike; A cannot cause C (would require \(v>c\)).

Final answers (brief):

a. Yes. \((\Delta s)^2 = 0.63\times10^6\,\mathrm{m}^2>0\) ⇒ timelike ⇒ causal.

b. No.  \((\Delta s)^2 = -1.17\times10^6\,\mathrm{m}^2<0\) ⇒ spacelike ⇒ no causal influence.

Below we place the two charges on the x–axis at  
 Q₁ at x=0,  
 Q₂ at x=d.  

(a) Q₁=+Q, Q₂=+2Q  
1. Electric potential  
   V(x)=k·Q₁/|x|+k·Q₂/|x−d|  
   Since both charges are positive we may drop absolute‐value signs if we keep track of regions.  We look for finite x≠0,d such that  
   $$V(x)=kQ\Bigl(\frac1x+\frac{2}{x-d}\Bigr)=0$$  
   ⟹  
   \[
     \frac1x+\frac2{x-d}=0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \frac{x-d+2x}{x(x-d)}=0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     3x-d=0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     x=\frac d3.
   \]  
   This lies in the interval (0,d).  

2. Electric field  
   On the x–axis the fields from the two charges point in opposite directions only if 0<x<d.  There  
   $$E(x)=kQ\frac{1}{x^2}\;\hat i\;-\;k(2Q)\frac{1}{(d-x)^2}\;\hat i  
     =0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \frac{1}{x^2}=\frac{2}{(d-x)^2}
     \;\Longrightarrow\;(d-x)^2=2x^2$$  
   Taking the positive root d−x=√2 x (the negative root gives x<0 or x>d which we reject for this region)  
   $$d-x=\sqrt2\,x
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     x\bigl(1+\sqrt2\bigr)=d
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     x=\frac{d}{1+\sqrt2}
     =\bigl(\sqrt2-1\bigr)\,d\,. $$  

(b) Q₁=−Q, Q₂=+2Q  
1. Electric potential  
   $$V(x)=-\,\frac{kQ}{x}+\frac{2kQ}{x-d}=0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     -\frac1x+\frac2{x-d}=0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     2x=x-d
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     x=-\,d\,. $$  
   This lies to the left of Q₁ (x<0).  

2. Electric field  
   We must check three regions: x<0, 0<x<d, and x>d.  One finds cancellations only for x<0.  In that region the fields from −Q (toward the origin) and from +2Q (away from x=d) point in opposite directions.  Setting magnitudes equal gives  
   $$\frac{kQ}{x^2}=\frac{2kQ}{(d-x)^2}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     (d-x)^2=2x^2\,. $$  
   Now for x<0 we must take the negative square root d−x=−√2 x (so that x is negative):  
   $$d-x=-\sqrt2\,x
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     d=x(1-\sqrt2)
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     x=-\,d\,(1+\sqrt2)\,. $$  

(c) Comparison  
   In neither case does the zero of V coincide with the zero of E at a finite point:
   • (a) V=0 at x=d/3, E=0 at x=d/(1+√2).  
   • (b) V=0 at x=−d, E=0 at x=−d(1+√2).  

Final answers (brief)

(a) Q₁=+Q at 0, Q₂=+2Q at d  
 V=0 at x=d/3  
 E=0 at x=d/(1+√2)  

(b) Q₁=−Q at 0, Q₂=+2Q at d  
 V=0 at x=−d  
 E=0 at x=−d(1+√2)  

(c) No finite point makes both V and E zero simultaneously.

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1) Determine the age of the rock from the U-238 ↔ Pb-206 system.

Let 
  N₀ = initial number (or mass) of U-238  
  N_U = present mass of U-238 = 0.86 mg  
  N_Pb = present mass of Pb-206 = 0.15 mg  
  λ_U = decay constant of U-238 = (ln 2)/(4.47×10⁹ y)  

Since Pb-206 is produced only by U-238 decay (assume no initial Pb):

  N_Pb = N₀ − N_U  
  N_U = N₀ e^(−λ_U t)

⇒ N_Pb/N_U = (N₀−N_U)/N_U = e^(λ_U t) − 1

Thus the age t is
  t = (1/λ_U) ln(1 + N_Pb/N_U)

Numerically:

  λ_U = ln 2 / (4.47×10⁹ y)  
        ≃ 0.693 / 4.47×10⁹ y  
        ≃1.55×10^(−10) y^(−1)

  N_Pb/N_U = 0.15/0.86 ≃ 0.1744  
  ⇒ t = (1/1.55×10^(−10)) ln(1 + 0.1744)
        ≃ (6.45×10⁹ y)·0.1609
        ≃1.04×10⁹ y

2) Use that age to find the present K-40 from its Ar-40 daughter.

Let 
  M_Ar = present Ar-40 mass = 1.6 mg  
  M_K = present K-40 mass (unknown)  
  λ_K = decay constant of K-40 = (ln 2)/(1.25×10⁹ y)

Assume all Ar-40 was produced by K-40 decay and that there was no initial Ar-40. Then if M₀ is the original K-40 mass,

  M_Ar = M₀ (1 − e^(−λ_K t))  
  M_K  = M₀ e^(−λ_K t)

Eliminate M₀:

  M_K = M_Ar · [ e^(−λ_K t) / (1 − e^(−λ_K t)) ]  

Numerically:

  λ_K = 0.693 / (1.25×10⁹ y) ≃5.54×10^(−10) y^(−1)  
  e^(−λ_K t) = exp[−5.54×10^(−10)·1.04×10⁹] ≃ e^(−0.576) ≃0.5624  

  ⇒ M_K = 1.6 mg · [0.5624 / (1 − 0.5624)]
          ≃1.6 mg · (0.5624/0.4376)
          ≃1.6 mg ·1.285
          ≃2.06 mg

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final answers (brief):

• Age of rock: t ≃1.04×10⁹ y  
• Present K-40 mass: M_K ≃2.06 mg

Here is a detailed, step‐by‐step solution.  Final answers are collected at the end.

Given:  
• Track length = 1070 m (not needed for parts a–c)  
• Initial speed \(v_0=0\)  
• Final speed \(v=224\;\mathrm{m/s}\)  
• Time interval \(\Delta t=0.900\;\mathrm{s}\)  
• Standard \(g=9.80\;\mathrm{m/s^2}\)

(a)  Constant acceleration \(a\):  
\[
a \;=\;\frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}
\;=\;\frac{v - v_0}{\Delta t}
\;=\;\frac{224 - 0}{0.900}
\;=\;248.9\;\mathrm{m/s^2}.
\]

(b)  Ratio to \(g\):  
\[
\frac{a}{g}
=\frac{248.9}{9.80}
\approx 25.4\;g.
\]

(c)  Distance covered in \(0.900\;\mathrm{s}\):  
\[
s
=v_0\,t + \tfrac12\,a\,t^2
=0 + \tfrac12(248.9)(0.900)^2
=100.8\;\mathrm{m}.
\]

(d)  Deceleration from \(283\;\mathrm{m/s}\) to 0 in \(1.40\;\mathrm{s}\):  
\[
a_{\rm dec}
=\frac{0 - 283}{1.40}
=-202.1\;\mathrm{m/s^2},
\]
so \(\lvert a_{\rm dec}\rvert/g =202.1/9.80\approx20.6\;g\).  
This is well below \(40g\), so the magazine’s claim (\(>40g\)) is not consistent.

— — —  
Final Answers (brief):

(a) \(a=248.9\;\mathrm{m/s^2}\)  
(b) \(a/g\approx25.4\)  
(c) \(s=100.8\;\mathrm{m}\)  
(d) Deceleration \(\approx20.6g\); the reported “\(>40g\)” is inconsistent.

Solution:

1. Bohr radius for hydrogen, \(n=1\):  
   \[
   a_{0}=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,\hbar^{2}}{m_{e}e^{2}}
   \approx5.29\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm{m}.
   \]

2. Heisenberg uncertainty principle (one spatial component):  
   \[
   \Delta x\,\Delta p \ge \frac{\hbar}{2}.
   \]
   With \(\Delta x = a_{0}\) one finds the minimum momentum uncertainty  
   \[
   \Delta p_{\min}
   = \frac{\hbar}{2\,a_{0}}
   = \frac{1.055\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\!·s}}{2\times5.29\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm{m}}
   \approx9.96\times10^{-25}\,\mathrm{kg\!·m/s}.
   \]

3. Momentum of the electron in the Bohr orbit (\(v_{1}=e^{2}/(2\varepsilon_{0}\hbar)\) or directly \(p=\hbar/a_{0}\)):  
   \[
   p_{\rm Bohr}
   = \frac{\hbar}{a_{0}}
   = \frac{1.055\times10^{-34}}{5.29\times10^{-11}}
   \approx1.99\times10^{-24}\,\mathrm{kg\!·m/s}.
   \]

4. Comparison and discussion:  
   \[
   \frac{\Delta p_{\min}}{p_{\rm Bohr}}
   \approx\frac{9.96\times10^{-25}}{1.99\times10^{-24}}
   \approx0.50.
   \]
   Thus the minimal uncertainty in momentum is of the same order as the actual momentum in the \(n=1\) orbit.  This shows that the Bohr‐model ground state is consistent with the Heisenberg uncertainty principle to within a factor of order unity.

Final answers (brief):

• \(\Delta x = a_{0} = 5.29\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm{m}.\)  
• \(\Delta p_{\min} = \dfrac{\hbar}{2a_{0}}\approx9.96\times10^{-25}\,\mathrm{kg\!·m/s}.\)  
• \(p_{\rm Bohr} = \dfrac{\hbar}{a_{0}}\approx1.99\times10^{-24}\,\mathrm{kg\!·m/s}.\)  
• Ratio: \(\Delta p_{\min}/p_{\rm Bohr}\approx0.5.\)
