Step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. Gaussian surface through a point charge  
   If a Gaussian surface passes exactly through a discrete (point) charge, the field on that surface is singular (infinite), so the flux integral  
   \[
     \Phi \;=\;\oint_{\!S} \mathbf E\cdot d\mathbf A
   \]
   becomes ill–defined.  Hence one never chooses a Gaussian surface that goes through a point charge.  
   ⇒ The Assertion is true.

2. Behaviour of \( \mathbf E\) at a point charge  
   The electric field of a point charge \(q\) at distance \(r\) is  
   \[
     \mathbf E(r) \;=\;\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\,\frac{q}{r^2}\,\hat r.
   \]
   As \(r\to0\) (i.e.\ at the charge location) \(\mathbf E\to\infty\).  Thus the field is not well–defined (it diverges).  
   ⇒ The Reason is false.

Final choice: Assertion true, Reason false.  Answer: (C).

Step‐by‐step solution

1. Definitions and assumptions  
   Let  
   • \(V_0\) = initial fill volume of helium at ground level  
   • \(V_{\max}\) = maximum (burst) volume of the balloon  
   • \(P_0\), \(T_0\) = pressure and temperature at ground level  
   • \(P(h)\), \(T(h)\) = pressure and temperature at altitude \(h\)  
   • \(n\) = number of moles of He (constant)  
   • \(R\) = universal gas constant  

2. Ideal‐gas law  
   At any altitude \(h\), the helium obeys  
   \[
     P(h)\,V(h)\;=\;n\,R\,T(h)\,.
   \]  
   At ground level (\(h=0\)):  
   \[
     P_0\,V_0 = n\,R\,T_0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     n = \frac{P_0\,V_0}{R\,T_0}\,.
   \]

3. Barometric (pressure) law  
   For an isothermal approximation (or scale‐height \(H\))  
   \[
     P(h) = P_0\,e^{-h/H}\,.
   \]

4. Volume expansion with altitude  
   Substitute \(n\) into the ideal‐gas law at altitude \(h\):  
   \[
     P(h)\,V(h)
     = \frac{P_0\,V_0}{R\,T_0}\;R\,T(h)
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     V(h)=V_0\;\frac{P_0}{P(h)}\;\frac{T(h)}{T_0}
     \approx V_0\,e^{h/H}
     \quad(\!T(h)\approx T_0\!)\,.
   \]

5. Burst condition  
   The balloon bursts when \(V(h_{\rm burst})=V_{\max}\).  Thus  
   \[
     V_{\max}
     = V_0\,e^{\,h_{\rm burst}/H}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \frac{V_0}{V_{\max}}
     = e^{-\,h_{\rm burst}/H}\,.
   \]

6. Numerical estimate  
   For a typical scale height \(H\approx7.5\)\,km and burst altitude \(h_{\rm burst}\sim30\)\,km:  
   \[
     \frac{V_0}{V_{\max}}
     \approx e^{-30/7.5}
     = e^{-4}
     \approx 0.018\;\;(1.8\%).
   \]  
   In practice, non‐isothermal layers, desired ascent rate, and safety margins lead operators to fill to about 10–20% of \(V_{\max}\).  

7. Buoyant‐lift and ascent rate  
   The net upward force is  
   \[
     F_{\rm net} = \bigl[\rho_{\rm air}(h)-\rho_{\rm He}(h)\bigr]\,V(h)\,g,
   \]  
   so choosing \(V_0\) in the 10–20% range also lets one control the ascent speed (typically 5 m/s).

Final answers (brief)

• By the ideal‐gas law and barometric formula, as \(P\downarrow\) with altitude, \(V\propto1/P\) so the helium expands roughly like \(V(h)=V_0e^{h/H}\).  
• To avoid bursting too low, one must choose \(V_0/V_{\max}=e^{-h_{\rm burst}/H}\).  For \(h_{\rm burst}\sim30\) km, that fraction is only a few %.  
• In practice a 10–20% fill balances burst altitude, ascent rate, and safety margins.

Here is the step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. An NPN transistor will conduct (i.e. be in the forward‐active region) only if  
   a. the base–emitter junction is forward‐biased, and  
   b. the base–collector junction is reverse‐biased.

2. Forward bias of the base–emitter junction means  
   $$V_{BE}=V_B - V_E>0\quad(\text{typically }V_{BE}\approx0.7\rm\,V).$$  
   Hence  
   $$V_B>V_E\quad\Longrightarrow\quad\text{emitter is negative w.r.t. base.}$$

3. Reverse bias of the base–collector junction means  
   $$V_{BC}=V_B - V_C<0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad V_C>V_B\quad\Longrightarrow\quad\text{collector is positive w.r.t. base.}$$

Putting these together: the collector must be positive and the emitter negative with respect to the base.

Answer in brief: (B)

Step 1:  Boltzmann law for two levels (no degeneracy)  
\[
\frac{N_2}{N_1}=\exp\Bigl(-\frac{\Delta E}{k_B\,T}\Bigr)\,.
\]
Here a “20 % inversion’’ means  
\[
N_2=1.20\,N_1\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;\frac{N_2}{N_1}=1.20\,. 
\]

Step 2:  Solve for \(T\).  
\[
1.20=\exp\Bigl(-\frac{\Delta E}{k_B\,T}\Bigr)
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\ln(1.20)=-\frac{\Delta E}{k_B\,T}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
T=-\frac{\Delta E}{k_B\,\ln(1.20)}\,. 
\]

Step 3:  Insert numbers  
\[
\Delta E=2.26\;{\rm eV}=2.26\times1.602\times10^{-19}\;{\rm J}\approx3.62\times10^{-19}\;J,
\quad
k_B=1.381\times10^{-23}\;J/K,
\quad
\ln(1.20)\approx0.1823.
\]
\[
T\approx -\frac{3.62\times10^{-19}}{(1.381\times10^{-23})(0.1823)}
\approx -1.44\times10^{5}\;{\rm K}\,. 
\]

Final answer (brief):  
\[
T\approx -1.4\times10^{5}\;{\rm K}.
\]

Solution.  
The equation of motion is  
\[
m\ddot x=-m\bigl(n^2+k^2\bigr)x-2mk\dot x
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\ddot x+2k\dot x+(n^2+k^2)x=0.
\]  
The characteristic roots are 
\[
r=-k\pm i n,
\]  
so the general solution is  
\[
x(t)=e^{-kt}\bigl(A\cos n t+B\sin n t\bigr).
\]  
Imposing \(x(0)=a\), \(\dot x(0)=0\) gives  
\[
A=a,\qquad
\dot x(0)=-kA+nB=0\;\Longrightarrow\;B=\frac{ka}{n}.
\]  
Hence  
\[
\boxed{
x(t)=\frac a n\,e^{-kt}\bigl(n\cos n t+k\sin n t\bigr).
}
\]  

Next rest‐point: \(\dot x(t)=0\) for the first time after \(t=0\).  We compute  
\[
\dot x(t)
=-\frac a n\,(n^2+k^2)\,e^{-kt}\sin n t
\;\Longrightarrow\;\sin n t=0\;\Rightarrow\;t_1=\frac\pi n.
\]  
At \(t_1=\pi/n\)  
\[
x(t_1)
=\frac a n\,e^{-k\pi/n}\bigl(n\cos\pi+k\sin\pi\bigr)
=-a\,e^{-k\pi/n}.
\]  
Thus the particle moves from \(x=a\) to \(x=0\) (distance \(a\)) and then to \(x=-a\,e^{-k\pi/n}\) (additional distance \(a\,e^{-k\pi/n}\)).  The total distance before it next comes to rest is  
\[
\boxed{
\Delta x
=a\;+\;a\,e^{-\,k\pi/n}
=a\Bigl(1+e^{-k\pi/n}\Bigr).
}
\]  

Final Answers (brief).  
1. \(x(t)=\dfrac a n\,e^{-kt}\bigl(n\cos n t+k\sin n t\bigr).\)  
2. Distance before next rest: \(\displaystyle a\bigl(1+e^{-k\pi/n}\bigr).\)

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.  In what follows,  N is the number of revolutions,  t the time,  R the sphere’s radius,  τ the applied torque, and M the unknown mass.

1.  Radius  
   \[
     R=\frac{D}{2}= \frac{0.72\rm\,m}{2}=0.36\rm\,m.
   \]

2.  Total angular displacement  
   \[
     \theta=2\pi\,N=2\pi(160)=320\pi\;\rm rad.
   \]

3.  Uniform angular acceleration  
   From  
   \[
     \theta=\tfrac12\,\alpha\,t^2
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \alpha=\frac{2\theta}{t^2}
             =\frac{2\,(320\pi)}{(15.0)^2}
             \approx8.93\;\rm rad/s^2.
   \]

4.  Moment of inertia of a solid sphere about its diameter  
   \[
     I=\tfrac25\,M\,R^2.
   \]

5.  Relation between torque and angular acceleration  
   \[
     \tau=I\,\alpha
         =\frac25\,M\,R^2\,\alpha
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     M=\frac{5\,\tau}{2\,R^2\,\alpha}.
   \]

6.  Substitute \(\alpha\) from step 3  
   \[
     M
     =\frac{5\,\tau}{2\,R^2}\,\frac{1}{\alpha}
     =\frac{5\,\tau}{2\,(0.36)^2}\,
       \frac{1}{8.93}
     =\frac{5\,\tau}{2\cdot0.1296\cdot8.93}
     =\frac{5\,\tau}{2.313\;}.
   \]

7.  If, for example, the applied torque is \(\tau=6.00\rm\;N\!\cdot\!m\) (a typical textbook value), then  
   \[
     M=\frac{5\,(6.00)}{2.313}\approx12.96\;\rm kg\approx13.0\;kg.
   \]

Final answers (brief):  
• Angular acceleration: \(\displaystyle \alpha=\frac{2\,(320\pi)}{15^2}\approx8.93\;\rm rad/s^2\).  
• Mass in terms of τ: \(\displaystyle M=\frac{5\,\tau}{2\,R^2\,\alpha}\).  
• With \(\tau=6.00\)\,N·m, \(M\approx13.0\)\,kg.

Here is the step‐by‐step solution:

1.  Given data  
    \[
      m = 2\;\mathrm{kg},\quad
      v_A = 5\;\mathrm{m/s},\quad
      v_B = 3\;\mathrm{m/s},\quad
      W_{\rm ext} = -10\;\mathrm{J}.
    \]

2.  Work–energy theorem in the presence of a conservative force:  
    \[
      W_{\rm ext} + W_{\rm cons} \;=\;\Delta K,
    \]
    and for a conservative force  
    \[
      W_{\rm cons} = -\,\Delta U.
    \]
    Hence
    \[
      W_{\rm ext} - \Delta U \;=\;\Delta K
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \Delta U = W_{\rm ext} - \Delta K.
    \]

3.  Compute the change in kinetic energy  
    \[
      \Delta K
      = \tfrac12\,m\bigl(v_B^2 - v_A^2\bigr)
      = \tfrac12\cdot2\,(3^2 - 5^2)
      = 1\cdot(9 - 25)
      = -16\;\mathrm{J}.
    \]

4.  Therefore the change in potential energy is  
    \[
      \Delta U = W_{\rm ext} - \Delta K
               = (-10) - (-16)
               = +6\;\mathrm{J}.
    \]

Final Answer (brief):  
\[
\boxed{\Delta U = U_B - U_A = +6\;\mathrm{J}.}
\]

Solution (outline)

1. Discrete‐particle form  
   \[
   T^{\mu\nu}(x)
   =\sum_a\frac{p_a^\mu\,p_a^\nu}{p_a^0}\,
     \delta^{(3)}\!\bigl(\mathbf x-\mathbf x_a(t)\bigr)\,.
   \]

2. Go to continuum by introducing the one‐particle phase‐space density \(f(x,p)\):
   \[
   T^{\mu\nu}(x)
   =\int\frac{d^3p}{p^0}\,f(x,p)\,p^\mu p^\nu\,.
   \]

3. In the local‐rest frame (\(u^\mu=(1,0,0,0)\)), define
   \[
   \rho\equiv T^{00}=\int d^3p\,f\,p^0,
   \quad
   p\equiv\frac{1}{3}\sum_{i=1}^3T^{ii}
     =\frac{1}{3}\int d^3p\,f\,\frac{\mathbf p^2}{p^0}.
   \]
   By isotropy: \(T^{0i}=0,\;T^{ij}=p\,\delta^{ij}\).

4. Recognize the unique covariant form reducing to the above in the rest frame:
   \[
   \boxed{
   T^{\mu\nu}=(\rho+p)\,u^\mu u^\nu + p\,g^{\mu\nu},
   }
   \]
   which is the perfect‐fluid energy–momentum tensor (eq. 1.114).

Final answers (brief)

• Discrete → continuum:
  \(\displaystyle T^{\mu\nu}=\int\!\frac{d^3p}{p^0}f(x,p)\,p^\mu p^\nu.\)

• Rest‐frame components:
  \[
    T^{00}=\rho,\quad T^{0i}=0,\quad T^{ij}=p\,\delta^{ij}.
  \]

• Covariant form:
  \(\displaystyle T^{\mu\nu}=(\rho+p)\,u^\mu u^\nu + p\,g^{\mu\nu}.\)

Here is a fully‐worked derivation.  All equations are in LaTeX.

1.  Geometry and density  
   Let the cube have side–length \(a\) and mass \(M\).  Place it so that the edge about which we wish to compute \(I\) lies along the \(z\)–axis at \(x=0,\;y=0\).  Then the cube occupies
   \[
     0\le x\le a,\quad 0\le y\le a,\quad 0\le z\le a,
   \]
   and its (uniform) mass density is
   \[
     \rho=\frac{M}{a^3}.
   \]

2.  Definition of the moment of inertia  
   About the \(z\)–axis at \(x=y=0\), one has
   \[
     I_{\rm edge}
     =\int_V \bigl(x^2+y^2\bigr)\,dm
     =\rho\int_0^a\!\!\int_0^a\!\!\int_0^a (x^2+y^2)\,dz\,dy\,dx.
   \]

3.  Perform the \(z\)–integral  
   Since the integrand does not depend on \(z\),
   \[
     I_{\rm edge}
     =\rho\;a\;\int_0^a\!\!\int_0^a (x^2+y^2)\,dy\,dx.
   \]

4.  Separate the \(x\) and \(y\) integrals  
   \[
     \int_0^a\!\!\int_0^a (x^2+y^2)\,dy\,dx
     =\int_0^a x^2\!\bigl[\!\int_0^a dy\bigr]dx
      +\int_0^a y^2\!\bigl[\!\int_0^a dx\bigr]dy
     =a\int_0^a x^2dx\;+\;a\int_0^a y^2dy.
   \]
   But \(\int_0^a x^2dx=\int_0^a y^2dy=\tfrac{a^3}{3}\), so
   \[
     \int_0^a\!\!\int_0^a (x^2+y^2)\,dy\,dx
     =a\!\cdot\!\frac{a^3}{3}+a\!\cdot\!\frac{a^3}{3}
     =\frac{2a^4}{3}.
   \]

5.  Assemble the result  
   \[
     I_{\rm edge}
     =\rho\;a\;\frac{2a^4}{3}
     =\frac{M}{a^3}\;a\;\frac{2a^4}{3}
     =\frac{2}{3}\,M\,a^2.
   \]

Final answer (brief):

\[
  \boxed{I_{\rm edge}=\frac{2}{3}\,M\,a^2.}
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.  We place A at the origin and denote by  
\[
\mathbf r_B=(2d,\,1d,\,2d),\quad \mathbf r_C=(-1d,\,2d,\,-3d),\quad \mathbf r_D=(x,y,z)\,.
\]  
The gravitational force on A from a point mass at \(\mathbf r\) of mass \(m\) is  
\[
\mathbf F
=G\,m_A\,m\,\frac{\mathbf r}{|\mathbf r|^3}\,.
\]  
We require  
\[
\mathbf F_B+\mathbf F_C+\mathbf F_D
=0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\frac{2m_A}{|\mathbf r_B|^3}\,\mathbf r_B
+\frac{3m_A}{|\mathbf r_C|^3}\,\mathbf r_C
+\frac{4m_A}{|\mathbf r_D|^3}\,\mathbf r_D
=0\,.
\]  
Divide out \(m_A\) and write explicitly:
\[
\frac{2}{(3d)^3}(2d,1d,2d)
+\frac{3}{(\sqrt{14}\,d)^3}(-1d,2d,-3d)
+\frac{4}{r^3}(x,y,z)
=0,
\]
where \(r=|\mathbf r_D|=\sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}\).  Simplify the known terms:
\[
\frac{2}{27d^3}(2d,1d,2d)
=\frac{(4,2,4)}{27\,d^2}, 
\quad
\frac{3}{14\sqrt{14}\,d^3}(-1d,2d,-3d)
=\frac{(-3,6,-9)}{14\sqrt{14}\,d^2}.
\]
Let
\[
\mathbf T
=\frac{(4,2,4)}{27}
+\frac{(-3,6,-9)}{14\sqrt{14}}
=(T_x,T_y,T_z)\,\frac1{d^2}.
\]
Numerically,
\[
T_x\approx0.090878,\quad
T_y\approx0.188614,\quad
T_z\approx-0.023662,
\quad
|\mathbf T|\approx0.21066\,. 
\]
Then the equilibrium condition gives
\[
\frac{4}{r^3}(x,y,z)=-\mathbf T\;\Longrightarrow\;(x,y,z)
=-\frac{r^3}{4\,d^2}\,\mathbf T,
\]
and consistency \(r=\sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}\) yields
\[
r=\frac{2d}{\sqrt{|\mathbf T|}}\approx4.355\,d,
\qquad
\frac{r^3}{4d^2}\approx20.656\,d.
\]
Hence
\[
(x,y,z)\approx-20.656\,d\,(0.090878,\,0.188614,\,-0.023662)
\approx(-1.878\,d,\,-3.895\,d,\,0.489\,d).
\]

Final answers (to three significant figures):
a)\; \(x\approx -1.88\,d\)  
b)\; \(y\approx -3.90\,d\)  
c)\; \(z\approx \;\,0.489\,d\)

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.  Label the two filaments “A” and “B,” with resistances \(R_A\) and \(R_B\).  The lamp is run on a 120 V supply.

2.  By design, the three switch positions give powers
   \[
     P_1=100\;W,\quad P_2=200\;W,\quad P_3=300\;W.
   \]

3.  We will assume
   – Position 1 lights filament A alone at \(P_1=100\) W,  
   – Position 2 lights filament B alone at \(P_2=200\) W,  
   – Position 3 lights A and B in parallel to give \(P_3=300\) W.

4.  From \(P=V^2/R\) we get
   \[
     R_A=\frac{V^2}{P_1}=\frac{(120)^2}{100}=144\;\Omega,
     \qquad
     R_B=\frac{V^2}{P_2}=\frac{(120)^2}{200}=72\;\Omega.
   \]

5.  Check the 300 W setting:
   \[
     R_{\rm eq}=\frac{R_A\,R_B}{R_A+R_B}
                 =\frac{144\cdot72}{144+72}
                 =\frac{10368}{216}=48\;\Omega,
   \]
   \[
     P_3=\frac{V^2}{R_{\rm eq}}
         =\frac{(120)^2}{48}
         =300\;W.
   \]
   ✓

6.  Now suppose one filament burns out, and afterward the lamp
   – still lights on the LOW and HIGH switch positions at the same brightness,  
   – but is dark on the MIDDLE position.

   That means LOW and HIGH must both be using the same surviving filament, while MIDDLE uses the burned‐out one.  Hence filament B (the 200 W one) has failed.  

7.  Final answers:

(a)  Wiring of the three switches:
   • LOW (100 W) → filament A alone.  
   • MIDDLE (200 W) → filament B alone.  
   • HIGH (300 W) → A and B in parallel.  

(b)  Smaller filament resistance:  
   \[
     R_B=72\;\Omega.
   \]

(c)  Larger filament resistance:  
   \[
     R_A=144\;\Omega.
   \]

Step-by‐step solution:

1. Convert temperature to kelvin  
   \(T = -120~^\circ\mathrm C + 273.15 = 153.15~\mathrm K\)

2. State the ideal gas law  
   \[
     P\,V = n\,R\,T
   \]

3. Solve for pressure \(P\)  
   \[
     P = \frac{n\,R\,T}{V}
   \]

4. Choice of units and constants  

   a) To get \(P\) in atmospheres, use  
      \[
        R = 0.08206\;\frac{\mathrm{L\cdot atm}}{\mathrm{mol\cdot K}}, 
        \quad V = 2.0\;\mathrm L
      \]
      \[
        P = \frac{(3.0\;\mathrm{mol})(0.08206\;\mathrm{L\cdot atm/mol\cdot K})(153.15\;\mathrm K)}{2.0\;\mathrm L}
          \approx 18.9\;\mathrm{atm}
      \]

   b) To get \(P\) in pascals, use  
      \[
        R = 8.314\;\frac{\mathrm{J}}{\mathrm{mol\cdot K}}, 
        \quad V = 2.0\;\mathrm L = 2.0\times10^{-3}\;\mathrm m^3
      \]
      \[
        P = \frac{(3.0)(8.314)(153.15)}{2.0\times10^{-3}}
          \approx 1.91\times10^6\;\mathrm{Pa}
      \]

Final answers (brief):

• \(P \approx 18.9\;\mathrm{atm}\)  
• \(P \approx 1.91\times10^6\;\mathrm{Pa}\)

Step 1.  Compute the first‐order partials  
\[
w(x,y)=x^3-y^3-2xy+6,
\]
\[
w_x=\frac{\partial w}{\partial x}=3x^2-2y,
\qquad
w_y=\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}=-3y^2-2x.
\]

Step 2.  Solve \(w_x=0\), \(w_y=0\):  
\[
3x^2-2y=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad y=\frac32\,x^2,
\]
\[
-3y^2-2x=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad x=-\frac32\,y^2.
\]
Substitute \(y=\tfrac32x^2\) into \(x=-\tfrac32y^2\):
\[
x=-\frac32\Bigl(\tfrac32x^2\Bigr)^2=-\frac{27}{8}x^4
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
x\Bigl(1+\tfrac{27}{8}x^3\Bigr)=0
\]
so \(x=0\) or \(x^3=-\tfrac8{27}\) (\(x=-\tfrac23\)).  Hence the critical points are
\[
(0,0),\qquad \Bigl(-\tfrac23,\;\tfrac32\bigl(-\tfrac23\bigr)^2\Bigr)=\bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\bigr).
\]

Step 3.  Compute the second‐order partials  
\[
w_{xx}=\frac{\partial^2 w}{\partial x^2}=6x,
\qquad
w_{yy}=\frac{\partial^2 w}{\partial y^2}=-6y.
\]

Step 4.  Evaluate at the critical points:

At \((0,0)\):
\[
w_{xx}(0,0)=6\cdot0=0,
\quad
w_{yy}(0,0)=-6\cdot0=0.
\]

At \(\bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\bigr)\):
\[
w_{xx}\Bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\Bigr)
=6\Bigl(-\tfrac23\Bigr)=-4,
\qquad
w_{yy}\Bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\Bigr)
=-6\Bigl(\tfrac23\Bigr)=-4.
\]

Final Answers (brief).  
\[
\frac{\partial^2w}{\partial x^2}(0,0)=0,\quad
\frac{\partial^2w}{\partial y^2}(0,0)=0;
\qquad
\frac{\partial^2w}{\partial x^2}\Bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\Bigr)=-4,\quad
\frac{\partial^2w}{\partial y^2}\Bigl(-\tfrac23,\tfrac23\Bigr)=-4.
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.  Define the downward drop onto the spring to be height h.  Let x be the maximum compression of the spring.  
2.  Conservation of energy from the moment the cable breaks (just before the fall) to the instant of maximum compression gives  
   \[
     M g h \;=\;\tfrac12\,k\,x^2\;. 
   \]  
3.  The maximum spring‐force \(F_{\max}=k\,x\) must not exceed the force that produces a total deceleration of \(5g\).  Since the passengers feel a deceleration \(a_{\rm max}=5g\) upward, the spring‐force satisfies  
   \[
     F_{\max}=k\,x \;=\;M\,(g+a_{\rm max})
               =M\,(g+5g)=6\,M\,g\;. 
   \]  
4.  Eliminate \(x\) by solving \(k\,x=6Mg\) for \(x\), namely \(x=6Mg/k\), and substituting into the energy equation:
   \[
     Mgh \;=\;\tfrac12\,k\Bigl(\frac{6Mg}{k}\Bigr)^2
           =\frac{18\,M^2g^2}{k}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
     k=\frac{18\,M\,g}{h}\,. 
   \]  

Final brief answers:

\[
   k = \frac{18\,M\,g}{h}\,, 
   \qquad
   x_{\max}=\frac{6Mg}{k}=\frac{h}{3}\,.
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step derivation of the distance between the two skew lines
\[
L_1:\;\mathbf r=(4,3,-1)+t\,(1,1,1), 
\qquad
L_2:\;\mathbf r=(4,-1,1)+s\,(1,-2,-1).
\]

1.  Identify points and direction vectors:  
    \[
      P_1=(4,3,-1),\quad \mathbf d_1=(1,1,1),
      \qquad
      P_2=(4,-1,1),\quad \mathbf d_2=(1,-2,-1).
    \]

2.  Compute the cross product \(\mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2\):  
    \[
      \mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2
      =\begin{vmatrix}
        \mathbf i & \mathbf j & \mathbf k\\
        1 & 1 & 1\\
        1 & -2 & -1
      \end{vmatrix}
      = (1\cdot(-1)-1\cdot(-2))\,\mathbf i
        -\bigl(1\cdot(-1)-1\cdot1\bigr)\,\mathbf j
        +\bigl(1\cdot(-2)-1\cdot1\bigr)\,\mathbf k
      = (1,\,2,\,-3).
    \]

3.  Form the vector between base points and take the scalar triple product:  
    \[
      \mathbf P_2P_1
      =P_2-P_1=(4,-1,1)-(4,3,-1)=(0,-4,2),
    \]  
    \[
      \bigl|\mathbf P_2P_1\cdot(\mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2)\bigr|
      =\bigl|(0,-4,2)\cdot(1,2,-3)\bigr|
      =\bigl|0-8-6\bigr|
      =14.
    \]

4.  Compute the magnitude \(\lVert\mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2\rVert\):  
    \[
      \lVert(1,2,-3)\rVert
      =\sqrt{1^2+2^2+(-3)^2}
      =\sqrt{14}.
    \]

5.  Hence the distance \(D\) between the two skew lines is  
    \[
      D
      =\frac{\bigl|\mathbf P_2P_1\cdot(\mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2)\bigr|}
            {\lVert\mathbf d_1\times\mathbf d_2\rVert}
      =\frac{14}{\sqrt{14}}
      =\sqrt{14}.
    \]

Final Answer (brief):  
\[
\boxed{D=\sqrt{14}}.
\]

Here is a clear step‐by‐step derivation:

1.  Force between two long, parallel currents  
   I₁ and I₂ separated by distance d (same direction ⇒ attraction):  
   \[
     F \;=\; \frac{\mu_{0}\,I_{1}\,I_{2}\,L}{2\pi\,d}\,.
   \]

2.  Now change one of the currents: double it and reverse its direction.  Without loss of generality let  
   \[
     I_2' = -\,2\,I_{2},
     \quad
     \text{and increase the separation to }3d.
   \]
   Then the new force is
   \[
     F' \;=\; \frac{\mu_{0}\,I_{1}\,I_{2}'\,L}{2\pi\,(3d)}
       \;=\;
       \frac{\mu_{0}\,I_{1}\,(-2I_{2})\,L}{2\pi\,(3d)}
       \;=\;
       -\frac{2}{3}\;\frac{\mu_{0}\,I_{1}\,I_{2}\,L}{2\pi\,d}
       \;=\;
       -\frac{2F}{3}.
   \]

3.  The negative sign indicates the force is now repulsive.

4.  Matching to the options gives (A) \(-\tfrac{2F}{3}\).

Final Answers (brief):
(A)  \(\displaystyle F'=-\frac{2F}{3}\)

Below we take as our starting point the limit‐definition of the derivative (your “(2.1)”):  
\[
f'(x)\;=\;\lim_{h\to0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\,.
\]  
We then show, step by step, that

1. \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx}x^n = n\,x^{n-1}\),  
2. \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx}e^x = e^x\),  
3. \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx}\sin x = \cos x\),  
4. \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx}\cos x = -\sin x\).

---

1. Power rule: \(f(x)=x^n\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
f'(x)&=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{(x+h)^n - x^n}{h}
=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\sum_{k=0}^n\binom nk x^{n-k}h^k - x^n}{h}\\
&=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{n\,x^{n-1}h + O(h^2)}{h}
=\;n\,x^{n-1}\,.
\end{aligned}
\]

2. Exponential: \(f(x)=e^x\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
f'(x)&=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{e^{x+h}-e^x}{h}
=e^x\lim_{h\to0}\frac{e^h-1}{h}
=e^x\cdot1
=e^x,
\end{aligned}
\]
since \(\displaystyle\lim_{h\to0}(e^h-1)/h=1\).

3. Sine: \(f(x)=\sin x\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
f'(x)
&=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\sin(x+h)-\sin x}{h}
=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\sin x\cos h+\cos x\sin h-\sin x}{h}\\
&=\sin x\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\cos h-1}{h}+\cos x\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\sin h}{h}
=0+\cos x
=\cos x,
\end{aligned}
\]
using \(\lim_{h\to0}(\cos h-1)/h=0\) and \(\lim_{h\to0}\sin h/h=1\).

4. Cosine: \(f(x)=\cos x\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
f'(x)
&=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\cos(x+h)-\cos x}{h}
=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\cos x\cos h-\sin x\sin h-\cos x}{h}\\
&=\cos x\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\cos h-1}{h}-\sin x\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\sin h}{h}
=0 - \sin x
=-\sin x.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

Final summary of results:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{dx}x^n&=n\,x^{n-1},\\
\frac{d}{dx}e^x&=e^x,\\
\frac{d}{dx}\sin x&=\cos x,\\
\frac{d}{dx}\cos x&=-\sin x.
\end{aligned}
\]

Here are six key characteristics of musical sounds that influence tone quality (timbre). For each one, I give (a) a brief definition, (b) a representative equation, and (c) a musical example of its use.

1. Fundamental Frequency (Pitch)  
   (a) The lowest‐frequency component of a periodic sound; it determines the perceived pitch.  
   (b) If the period is \(T\), then  
   \[
     f_0 = \frac{1}{T}\,.
   \]  
   (c) Tuning an orchestra to A4 at \(f_0=440\:\mathrm{Hz}\).

2. Amplitude (Loudness)  
   (a) The sound‐pressure variation’s magnitude; related logarithmically to perceived loudness.  
   (b) A pure tone \(p(t)=p_{\max}\sin(2\pi f_0t)\), and sound‐pressure level  
   \[
     L_p = 20\log_{10}\!\Bigl(\frac{p_{\max}}{p_{\rm ref}}\Bigr)\quad[\mathrm{dB}].
   \]  
   (c) Pianissimo (\(\mathit{pp}\)) versus fortissimo (\(\mathit{ff}\)) in piano music.

3. Harmonic Content (Spectrum)  
   (a) The amplitudes and phases of integer multiples (\(n f_0\)) of the fundamental; shapes timbre.  
   (b) Fourier series of a periodic wave:  
   \[
     x(t)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty A_n\sin\bigl(2\pi n f_0t+\phi_n\bigr)\,.
   \]  
   (c) Violin (strong higher harmonics) vs. flute (weaker upper harmonics).

4. Amplitude Envelope (ADSR)  
   (a) How amplitude evolves in time: Attack, Decay, Sustain, Release.  
   (b) A common model:  
   \[
     A(t)=
     \begin{cases}
       A_{\max}\bigl(1-e^{-t/\tau_{\rm a}}\bigr) & 0\le t<t_{\rm a}\quad(\rm attack)\\
       A_{\rm s}+ (A_{\max}-A_{\rm s})e^{-(t-t_{\rm a})/\tau_{\rm d}} & t_{\rm a}\le t<t_{\rm s}\quad(\rm decay)\\
       A_{\rm s} & t_{\rm s}\le t<t_{\rm r}\quad(\rm sustain)\\
       A_{\rm s}e^{-(t-t_{\rm r})/\tau_{\rm r}} & t\ge t_{\rm r}\quad(\rm release)\,.
     \end{cases}
   \]  
   (c) Piano: very fast attack, moderate decay; organ: slow attack, no decay.

5. Frequency Modulation (Vibrato)  
   (a) A periodic variation of pitch around \(f_0\), adds warmth or expressiveness.  
   (b)  
   \[
     f(t)=f_0+\Delta f\sin(2\pi f_{\rm m}t), 
     \quad \Delta f\ll f_0.
   \]  
   (c) Vocalists often use \(\sim5\:\mathrm{Hz}\) vibrato with \(\Delta f\approx\pm5\:\mathrm{Hz}\).

6. Amplitude Modulation (Tremolo)  
   (a) A periodic variation of loudness; can produce a “shimmering” effect.  
   (b)  
   \[
     A(t)=A_0\bigl[1+m\sin(2\pi f_{\rm m}t)\bigr], 
     \quad 0\le m\le1.
   \]  
   (c) Tremolo pedal on an electric guitar (e.g.\ setting \(f_{\rm m}=7\:\mathrm{Hz}\), \(m=0.8\)).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final Answers (brief):  
1. Fundamental frequency \(f_0=1/T\) (pitch, e.g.\ A4=440 Hz)  
2. Amplitude \(p(t)=p_{\max}\sin(2\pi f_0t)\), \(L_p=20\log_{10}(p_{\max}/p_{\rm ref})\) (loudness)  
3. Harmonic content \(x(t)=\sum A_n\sin(2\pi n f_0t+\phi_n)\) (timbre: violin vs. flute)  
4. Amplitude envelope ADSR (attack, decay, sustain, release; e.g.\ piano vs. organ)  
5. Vibrato \(f(t)=f_0+\Delta f\sin(2\pi f_{\rm m}t)\) (expressive pitch modulation)  
6. Tremolo \(A(t)=A_0[1+m\sin(2\pi f_{\rm m}t)]\) (amplitude modulation effect)

Here’s the step‐by‐step solution, with all equations in LaTeX:

Given:  
Diameter of Planet Z, \(D = 10\,000\;\mathrm{km}\)  
\(\displaystyle R = \frac{D}{2} = 5\,000\;\mathrm{km}=5.0\times10^6\;\mathrm m\)  
Surface free‐fall acceleration, \(g_0 = 8.0\;\mathrm{m/s^2}\)  
Gravitational constant, \(G = 6.674\times10^{-11}\;\mathrm{m^3/(kg\,s^2)}\)  

(a) Mass \(M\) of Planet Z  

We use  
\[
g_0 \;=\;\frac{G\,M}{R^2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
M \;=\;\frac{g_0\,R^2}{G}\,.
\]  
Substitute numbers:  
\[
M
=\frac{(8.0\;\mathrm{m/s^2})(5.0\times10^6\;\mathrm m)^2}{6.674\times10^{-11}\;\mathrm{m^3/(kg\,s^2)}}
\approx 3.0\times10^{24}\;\mathrm{kg}.
\]  

(b) Free‐fall acceleration \(g\) at height \(h=10\,000\;\mathrm{km}\) above the north pole  

Height above surface:  
\[
h = 10\,000\;\mathrm{km} =1.0\times10^7\;\mathrm m,
\qquad
r = R + h = 5.0\times10^6 + 1.0\times10^7 = 1.5\times10^7\;\mathrm m.
\]  
Then  
\[
g(r) \;=\;\frac{G\,M}{r^2}
=\;g_0\Bigl(\frac{R}{r}\Bigr)^2
=8.0\;\mathrm{m/s^2}\times\Bigl(\frac{5.0\times10^6}{1.5\times10^7}\Bigr)^2
\approx0.89\;\mathrm{m/s^2}.
\]  

Final Answers (brief)  
(a) \(M\approx3.0\times10^{24}\;\mathrm{kg}\)  
(b) \(g(10\,000\;\mathrm{km})\approx0.89\;\mathrm{m/s^2}\)

Here is a complete, step‐by‐step solution.  In each case we write down the boundary conditions, the allowed wavelengths λ, the standing‐wave formulas for displacement u(x) and pressure fluctuation p(x), then solve for their nodes (u=0 and p=0) and finally insert L=1.20 m.

1.  Pipe open at both ends  
    — Boundary conditions: at x=0 and x=L both ends are open ⇒ displacement antinodes, pressure nodes.  
    — Allowed modes: n=1,2,3,… with  
       \[
         \lambda_{n}=\frac{2L}{n}, 
         \quad k_n=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda_n}=\frac{n\pi}{L}\!,
         \quad \omega_n =v\,k_n.
       \]  
    — Displacement profile  
       \[
         u(x,t)=U_0\cos(k_n x)\,\sin(\omega_n t),
       \]  
       so u‐nodes satisfy  
       \[
         \cos(k_n x)=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         k_n x=\Bigl(2m+1\Bigr)\frac{\pi}{2}
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         x_{\rm disp}^{(n)}=\frac{2m+1}{4}\,\lambda_n
         =\frac{2m+1}{2n}\,L,
         \quad m=0,1,\dots,n-1.
       \]  
    — Pressure profile  
       \[
         p(x,t)=P_0\sin(k_n x)\,\cos(\omega_n t),
       \]  
       so p‐nodes satisfy  
       \[
         \sin(k_n x)=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         k_n x=m\pi
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         x_{\rm pres}^{(n)}=m\,\frac{\lambda_n}{2}
         =m\,\frac{L}{n},
         \quad m=0,1,\dots,n.
       \]  

    Now insert L=1.20 m:

    n=1 (fundamental, λ₁=2.40 m)  
      • Displacement nodes:  
        x=\frac{2m+1}{2}\,L with m=0 ⇒ x=½·1.20=0.600 m  
      • Pressure nodes:  
        x=m·1.20 with m=0,1 ⇒ x=0, 1.20 m  

    n=2 (1st overtone, λ₂=1.20 m)  
      • Displacement nodes:  
        x=\frac{2m+1}{4}·1.20 with m=0,1 ⇒ x=0.300, 0.900 m  
      • Pressure nodes:  
        x=m·0.600 with m=0,1,2 ⇒ x=0, 0.600, 1.200 m  

    n=3 (2nd overtone, λ₃=0.80 m)  
      • Displacement nodes:  
        x=\frac{2m+1}{6}·1.20 with m=0,1,2 ⇒ x=0.200, 0.600, 1.000 m  
      • Pressure nodes:  
        x=m·0.400 with m=0,1,2,3 ⇒ x=0, 0.400, 0.800, 1.200 m  

2.  Pipe closed at left (x=0) and open at right (x=L)  
    — Boundary conditions: x=0 is closed ⇒ u=0 (displ. node), p antinode; x=L open ⇒ u antinode, p=0 (pres. node).  
    — Allowed modes: only odd modes p=1,3,5… with  
       \[
         \lambda_p =\frac{4L}{p}, 
         \quad k_p=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda_p}=\frac{p\pi}{2L}.
       \]  
    — Displacement profile  
       \[
         u(x,t)=U_0\sin(k_p x)\,\cos(\omega_p t),
       \]  
       u‐nodes:  
       \[
         \sin(k_p x)=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         k_p x=m\pi
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         x_{\rm disp}^{(p)}=m\,\frac{\lambda_p}{2}
         =m\,\frac{2L}{p},
         \quad m=0,1,\dots.
       \]  
    — Pressure profile  
       \[
         p(x,t)=P_0\cos(k_p x)\,\sin(\omega_p t),
       \]  
       p‐nodes:  
       \[
         \cos(k_p x)=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         k_p x=\Bigl(2m+1\Bigr)\frac{\pi}{2}
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         x_{\rm pres}^{(p)}=\frac{2m+1}{4}\,\lambda_p
         =\frac{2m+1}{p}\,L,
         \quad m=0,1,\dots.
       \]  

    Insert L=1.20 m:

    p=1 (fundamental, λ₁=4.80 m)  
      • Displacement nodes: x=m·2.40 m ⇒ m=0 ⇒ x=0  
      • Pressure nodes: x=(2m+1)·1.20 m ⇒ m=0 ⇒ x=1.20 m  

    p=3 (1st overtone, λ₃=1.60 m)  
      • Displacement nodes: x=m·0.80 m ⇒ m=0,1 ⇒ x=0.000, 0.800 m  
      • Pressure nodes: x=(2m+1)·0.40 m ⇒ m=0,1 ⇒ x=0.400, 1.200 m  

    p=5 (2nd overtone, λ₅=0.96 m)  
      • Displacement nodes: x=m·0.48 m ⇒ m=0,1,2 ⇒ x=0.000, 0.480, 0.960 m  
      • Pressure nodes: x=(2m+1)·0.24 m ⇒ m=0,1,2 ⇒ x=0.240, 0.720, 1.200 m  

— — — —  
FINAL SUMMARY  

(a) Open–open (L=1.20 m)  
n=1:  
  • u‐nodes at 0.600 m  
  • p‐nodes at 0, 1.200 m  
n=2:  
  • u‐nodes at 0.300, 0.900 m  
  • p‐nodes at 0, 0.600, 1.200 m  
n=3:  
  • u‐nodes at 0.200, 0.600, 1.000 m  
  • p‐nodes at 0, 0.400, 0.800, 1.200 m  

(b) Closed–open (L=1.20 m)  
p=1:  
  • u‐nodes at 0  
  • p‐nodes at 1.200 m  
p=3:  
  • u‐nodes at 0.000, 0.800 m  
  • p‐nodes at 0.400, 1.200 m  
p=5:  
  • u‐nodes at 0.000, 0.480, 0.960 m  
  • p‐nodes at 0.240, 0.720, 1.200 m

Step‐by‐step solution

1.  No‐slip at a solid wall implies in either forced or natural convection that  
    u(y=0)=0.  The thermal analogue is the heat‐flux at the wall,  
    \[
      q''_{\rm wall}
      = -k\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{y=0}\,,
    \]
    where \(y\) is the coordinate normal to the wall, \(k\) the thermal conductivity, and the minus sign enforces the fact that heat flows from hot to cold.

2.  The magnitude of the heat flux is therefore  
    \[
      \bigl|q''_{\rm wall}\bigr|
      = k\Bigl|\frac{dT}{dy}\Bigr|_{y=0}
      \;\longrightarrow\;
      k\,\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{\rm wall}
      \quad(\text{assuming }dT/dy>0).
    \]

3.  Compare with the given options:
    (a) \(k(T_{\rm fluid}-T_{\rm wall})\) – this has dimensions of \(k\Delta T\), not a flux gradient.  
    (b) \(\displaystyle k\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{\rm wall}\) – matches the magnitude of Fourier’s law.  
    (c) \(\displaystyle k\left.\frac{d^2T}{dy^2}\right|_{\rm wall}\) – wrong order of derivative.  
    (d) \(\displaystyle h\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{\rm wall}\) – mixing convection coefficient \(h\) with a temperature gradient is not correct.  

Final answer (in brief)

The magnitude of the heat flux at the wall is  
\[
  q''_{\rm wall} = -\,k\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{\rm wall}
  \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
  \bigl|q''_{\rm wall}\bigr|
  = k\,\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{\rm wall}
\]
Hence the correct choice is (b).

Step-by-step solution

1. Define symbols  
   Let  
   \(M_m=75\rm\,kg\) be the mass of the man,  
   \(M_c=39\rm\,kg\) the mass of the cart,  
   \(v_i=2.3\rm\,m/s\) the initial velocity of both,  
   \(v_f\) the final velocity of the cart,  
   and after the jump the man’s horizontal velocity is zero.

2. Conservation of horizontal momentum  
   Initial total momentum  
   \[
     p_i=(M_m+M_c)\,v_i.
   \]
   Final total momentum  
   \[
     p_f=M_m\cdot0+M_c\,v_f=M_c\,v_f.
   \]
   By conservation, \(p_i=p_f\):
   \[
     (M_m+M_c)\,v_i=M_c\,v_f.
   \]

3. Solve for \(v_f\)  
   \[
     v_f=\frac{(M_m+M_c)\,v_i}{M_c}
         =\frac{(75+39)\times2.3}{39}
         =\frac{114\times2.3}{39}
         \approx6.72\rm\,m/s.
   \]

4. Change in cart’s velocity  
   \[
     \Delta v=v_f-v_i\approx6.72-2.30=+4.42\rm\,m/s.
   \]

Final answers (brief)

• Final velocity of cart: \(v_f\approx6.72\rm\,m/s\).  
• Change in cart’s velocity: \(\Delta v\approx+4.42\rm\,m/s\).

Step 1:  Linear weight density of the wire  
\[
\lambda=\frac{W}{L}\quad\bigl[\text{force per unit length}\bigr].
\]

Step 2:  Tension at a distance \(x\) above the lower end  
All the load below that section must be supported, namely the hanging weight \(W_1\) plus the weight of the wire of length \(x\):  
\[
T(x)=W_{1}+\lambda\,x
      =W_{1}+\frac{W}{L}\,x.
\]

Step 3:  Evaluate at \(x=\tfrac{3L}{4}\)  
\[
T\!\Bigl(\tfrac{3L}{4}\Bigr)
= W_{1}+\frac{W}{L}\,\frac{3L}{4}
= W_{1}+\frac{3W}{4}.
\]

Step 4:  Stress at that section  
Stress is tension divided by cross‐sectional area \(S\),  
\[
\sigma=\frac{T}{S}
       =\frac{W_{1}+\tfrac{3W}{4}}{S}.
\]

Final Answer (brief):  
\[
\boxed{\sigma\bigl(x=\tfrac{3L}{4}\bigr)
= \frac{W_{1}+\tfrac{3W}{4}}{S}}.
\]

Solution (step by step)

1.  Definition of binding energy  
    For a nucleus with \(Z\) protons, \(N\) neutrons and mass \(M\), its total binding energy is  
    \[
      B = \bigl(Z\,m_p + N\,m_n - M\bigr)\,c^2,
    \]  
    where \(m_p,m_n\) are the proton and neutron masses.

2.  Average binding energy per nucleon  
    If the mass number is \(A=Z+N\), the average binding energy per nucleon is  
    \[
      \frac{B}{A}\,.
    \]

3.  Energy release in fission  
    Suppose a heavy nucleus (mass \(M_i\), binding \(B_i\), mass number \(A_i\)) splits into two fragments  
    with masses \(M_1,M_2\), binding energies \(B_1,B_2\), and mass numbers \(A_1,A_2\) (with \(A_i=A_1+A_2\)).  
    The energy released is
    \[
      Q \;=\; \bigl(M_i - (M_1+M_2)\bigr)\,c^2 \;>\; 0.
    \]

4.  Express \(Q\) in terms of binding energies  
    Using \(M = Zm_p+Nm_n - B/c^2\),  
    \begin{align*}
      Q
      &=\Bigl[(Z_i m_p+N_i m_n)-\tfrac{B_i}{c^2} - \bigl((Z_1 m_p+N_1 m_n)-\tfrac{B_1}{c^2}+(Z_2 m_p+N_2 m_n)-\tfrac{B_2}{c^2}\bigr)\Bigr]c^2\\
      &= B_1 + B_2 - B_i \;=\; B_f - B_i.
    \end{align*}
    Since \(Q>0\), it follows that
    \[
      B_f \;>\; B_i.
    \]

5.  Average binding per nucleon after fission  
    The total number of nucleons is conserved: \(A_i=A_1+A_2\).  Thus the average binding energy per nucleon increases:
    \[
      \frac{B_f}{A_i}\;>\;\frac{B_i}{A_i}.
    \]

Final answer (brief)

• The energy release \(Q>0\) implies \(B_f>B_i\).  
• Therefore the average binding energy per nucleon increases.

Below is a step‐by‐step derivation of the identity

\[
\frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr] \;=\; x^pJ_{p-1}(x)\,,
\]

where \(J_p\) is the Bessel function of the first kind of order \(p\).

1.  Apply the product rule:
    \[
      \frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr]
      = p\,x^{p-1}J_p(x) \;+\; x^p\,J_p'(x)\,.
    \]

2.  Use the standard derivative formula for Bessel functions,
    \[
      J_p'(x)
      = \frac{1}{2}\bigl[J_{p-1}(x)-J_{p+1}(x)\bigr].
    \]
    Substituting gives
    \[
      \frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr]
      = p\,x^{p-1}J_p(x)
        \;+\;\frac{x^p}{2}\bigl[J_{p-1}(x)-J_{p+1}(x)\bigr].
    \]

3.  Factor out \(x^{p-1}\):
    \[
      \frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr]
      = x^{p-1}\Bigl[pJ_p(x)
        +\frac{x}{2}J_{p-1}(x)
        -\frac{x}{2}J_{p+1}(x)\Bigr].
    \]

4.  Use the three-term recurrence
    \[
      J_{p+1}(x)
      = \frac{2p}{x}\,J_p(x)\;-\;J_{p-1}(x)
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      -\frac{x}{2}J_{p+1}(x)
      = -p\,J_p(x) \;+\;\frac{x}{2}J_{p-1}(x).
    \]
    Hence the bracket becomes
    \[
      pJ_p
      +\frac{x}{2}J_{p-1}
      +\Bigl(-pJ_p+\tfrac{x}{2}J_{p-1}\Bigr)
      = x\,J_{p-1}(x).
    \]

5.  Putting it all together,
    \[
      \frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr]
      = x^{p-1}\bigl[x\,J_{p-1}(x)\bigr]
      = x^p\,J_{p-1}(x).
    \]

Final answer (in brief):

\[
\boxed{
\frac{d}{dx}\bigl[x^pJ_p(x)\bigr] \;=\; x^p\,J_{p-1}(x)\,.
}
\]

Below is a sketch of the moving‐control‐volume analysis for a turbojet flying at constant speed \(v_{0}=800\rm\ km/h\).  Speeds will be converted to m/s where needed:  
\[
v_{0}=\frac{800}{3.6}\approx222.2\rm\ m/s,\quad
w=\frac{1200}{3.6}\approx333.3\rm\ m/s.
\]

1. Choice of control volume (CV)  
   • CV encloses the engine, the intake air and the mixing/combustion chamber.  
   • We choose the CV moving at \(v_{0}\) in the ground frame.  Then all inlet/outlet flows are steady in the CV:  
     \[
       \frac{\partial}{\partial t}(\,\cdot\,)_{\rm CV}=0.
     \]

2. Open surfaces and normals  
   • Inlet \(S_{1}\) at the front of engine, area vector \(\mathbf{n}_{1}=+\hat x\) (points forward).  
   • Exit  \(S_{2}\) at the rear,  area vector \(\mathbf{n}_{2}=-\hat x\) (points backward).  
   • Fuel‐injection port \(S_{f}\) (assume very small area; fuel enters essentially at the CV speed).

3. Relative velocities in the CV  
   We take \(+x\) = flight direction.  
   • Air at inlet:  
     \[
       \mathbf{u}_{1}=-v_{0}\,\hat x
       \quad(\text{magnitude }v_{0}=222.2\rm\ m/s\text{, directed into CV})
     \]  
   • Exhaust at exit:  
     \[
       \mathbf{u}_{2}=-w\,\hat x
       \quad(\text{magnitude }w=333.3\rm\ m/s\text{, directed out of CV})
     \]  
   • Fuel injection: assume \(\mathbf{u}_{f}\approx\mathbf{0}\) in CV.

4. Mass‐conservation (steady R–T theorem)  
   Let \(\dot m_{a},\dot m_{f}\) be the air and fuel mass‐flow rates into the CV, and \(\dot m_{e}\) the exhaust rate out:  
   \[
     \dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f}
     \;=\;\dot m_{e}\,.
     \tag{1}
   \]

5. Momentum‐conservation (steady form)  
   The net force on the CV in \(x\)–direction, \(F_{x}\), equals the net out–in convective momentum flux:  
   \[
     F_{x}
     =\sum_{\rm out}\dot m\,u_{n}
     -\sum_{\rm in}\dot m\,u_{n}.
     \tag{2}
   \]
   Here \(u_{n}=\mathbf{u}\cdot\hat x\).  Substituting streams:  
   \[
     F_{x}
     =\dot m_{e}(-w)\;
     -\;\bigl[\dot m_{a}(-v_{0})+\dot m_{f}(0)\bigr]
     =\dot m_{a}\,v_{0}-\dot m_{e}\,w.
     \tag{3}
   \]
   Using (1)\:\(\dot m_{e}=\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f}\), we get the thrust delivered on the engine (positive in \(+x\))  
   \[
     T\;=\;F_{x}
     =\dot m_{a}\,v_{0}
     \;-\;(\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f})\,w
     =-(\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f})\,w+\dot m_{a}\,v_{0}.
     \tag{4}
   \]
   Equivalently, if one prefers the usual form  
   (mass × exit‐speed – mass × inlet‐speed),  
   \[
     T
     =(\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f})\,w-\dot m_{a}\,v_{0}.
     \tag{5}
   \]

6. Local vs.\ convective changes  
   • Local (unsteady) terms vanish because the flow is steady in our moving CV.  
   • All changes appear as convective fluxes of mass and momentum through \(S_{1},S_{2},S_{f}\).  

7. Why a moving CV?  
   • In the engine frame the inlet‐ and exit‐flows are steady, \(\partial/\partial t=0\).  
   • Surfaces of the CV (the engine walls) are then stationary in the CV, greatly simplifying the R–T bookkeeping.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final brief answers:  

(1) Steady mass balance  
\[
\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f}=\dot m_{e}.
\]

(2) Steady momentum (thrust)  
\[
T=(\dot m_{a}+\dot m_{f})\,w-\dot m_{a}\,v_{0}
\quad
\bigl[w=333.3\rm\ m/s,\ v_{0}=222.2\rm\ m/s\bigr].
\]

Below is a self‐contained summary of the orthogonal parabolic coordinates 
\((\xi,\eta,\phi)\), the scale‐factors \(h_i\), and the usual vector‐operators in these coordinates.  All equations are in LaTeX.

1. Definition  
   \[
     x = \xi\,\eta\cos\phi,\qquad
     y = \xi\,\eta\sin\phi,\qquad
     z = \frac{\xi^2 - \eta^2}{2},
   \]
   with \(\xi\ge0,\;\eta\ge0,\;0\le\phi<2\pi\).

2. Scale‐factors  
   \[
     h_\xi = \sqrt{\bigl(\partial_\xi x\bigr)^2+\bigl(\partial_\xi y\bigr)^2+\bigl(\partial_\xi z\bigr)^2}
            = \sqrt{\eta^2+\xi^2},
   \]
   \[
     h_\eta=\sqrt{\xi^2+\eta^2}, 
     \qquad
     h_\phi = \sqrt{\bigl(\partial_\phi x\bigr)^2+\bigl(\partial_\phi y\bigr)^2}
            = \xi\,\eta.
   \]
   We set 
   \[
     h:=\sqrt{\xi^2+\eta^2}, 
     \quad
     h_\xi=h_\eta=h,
     \quad 
     h_\phi=\xi\,\eta.
   \]

3. Orthonormal basis  
   \(\{\hat e_\xi,\hat e_\eta,\hat e_\phi\}\) with  
   \(\hat e_i = (1/h_i)\,\partial_i\bm r\) and \(\bm r=(x,y,z)\).

4. Gradient  
   \[
     \displaystyle
     \nabla\Psi
     = \frac{1}{h}\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\xi}\,\hat e_\xi
       +\frac{1}{h}\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\eta}\,\hat e_\eta
       +\frac{1}{\xi\,\eta}\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\phi}\,\hat e_\phi.
   \]

5. Divergence  
   For \(\bm A=A_\xi\,\hat e_\xi +A_\eta\,\hat e_\eta +A_\phi\,\hat e_\phi\),
   \[
     \displaystyle
     \nabla\!\cdot\!\bm A
     = \frac{1}{h^2\,\xi\,\eta}
       \Bigl[
         \frac{\partial}{\partial\xi}\bigl(\xi\,\eta\,h\,A_\xi\bigr)
        +\frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\bigl(\xi\,\eta\,h\,A_\eta\bigr)
        +\frac{\partial}{\partial\phi}\bigl(h^2\,A_\phi\bigr)
       \Bigr].
   \]

6. Curl  
   Its components in the \(\{\hat e_\xi,\hat e_\eta,\hat e_\phi\}\) basis are
   \[
     (\nabla\times\bm A)_\xi
     = \frac{1}{h\,h_\phi}\Bigl[\partial_\eta(h_\phi A_\phi)-\partial_\phi(h\,A_\eta)\Bigr],
   \]
   \[
     (\nabla\times\bm A)_\eta
     = \frac{1}{h_\phi\,h}\Bigl[\partial_\phi(h\,A_\xi)-\partial_\xi(h_\phi A_\phi)\Bigr],
   \]
   \[
     (\nabla\times\bm A)_\phi
     = \frac{1}{h\,h}\Bigl[\partial_\xi(h\,A_\eta)-\partial_\eta(h\,A_\xi)\Bigr],
   \]
   with \(h_\phi=\xi\eta\), \(h=\sqrt{\xi^2+\eta^2}\).

7. Laplacian  
   For a scalar \(\Psi\),
   \[
     \displaystyle
     \nabla^2\Psi
     = \frac{1}{h^2\,\xi\,\eta}\Biggl[
       \frac{\partial}{\partial\xi}\Bigl(\xi\,\eta\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\xi}\Bigr)
      +\frac{\partial}{\partial\eta}\Bigl(\xi\,\eta\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\eta}\Bigr)
      +\frac{\partial}{\partial\phi}\Bigl(\frac{h^2}{\xi\,\eta}\,\frac{\partial\Psi}{\partial\phi}\Bigr)
     \Biggr].
   \]

That completes the vector‐calculus formulas for parabolic coordinates.

Solution:  
We have three waves of equal amplitude \(A\) and frequencies \(f_1=v-1\), \(f_2=v\), \(f_3=v+1\) (all in Hz).  Writing each as a sinusoid in time \(t\), the resultant is
\[
y(t)
= A\sin\bigl(2\pi (v-1)t\bigr)\;+\;A\sin\bigl(2\pi v\,t\bigr)\;+\;A\sin\bigl(2\pi (v+1)t\bigr).
\]
Step 1:  Sum the first and third terms using the identity 
\[
\sin\alpha+\sin\beta = 2\sin\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\alpha+\beta}{2}\Bigr)\cos\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\alpha-\beta}{2}\Bigr).
\]
Here \(\alpha=2\pi(v-1)t\), \(\beta=2\pi(v+1)t\).  Then
\[
\sin\bigl[2\pi(v-1)t\bigr] + \sin\bigl[2\pi(v+1)t\bigr]
= 2\sin\bigl(2\pi v\,t\bigr)\,\cos\bigl(2\pi t\bigr).
\]
Step 2:  Hence the total becomes
\[
y(t)
= A\bigl[2\sin(2\pi v t)\cos(2\pi t)\bigr] + A\sin(2\pi v t)
= A\,\sin(2\pi v t)\bigl[2\cos(2\pi t)+1\bigr].
\]
Thus the *amplitude envelope* is
\[
E(t)=A\;\bigl|2\cos(2\pi t)+1\bigr|.
\]
Since \(\cos(2\pi t)\) oscillates once every second, the envelope (and hence the beats) repeat at \(1\) cycle per second.

Final answer (brief):  
Number of beats per second = 1. (Option C)

Here is a step‐by‐step solution:

1. Decompose the initial velocity:  
   \(v_{0x}=v_{0}\cos\theta,\quad v_{0y}=v_{0}\sin\theta\)  
   with \(v_{0}=19.5\) m/s, \(\theta=45^\circ\).  
   Hence  
   \[
     v_{0x}=19.5\cos45^\circ,\quad 
     v_{0y}=19.5\sin45^\circ.
   \]

2. Time of flight \(T\) (when the ball returns to \(y=0\)):  
   \[
     0=v_{0y}\,T-\tfrac12 gT^2
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     T=\frac{2\,v_{0y}}{g}
     =\frac{2\,v_0\sin\theta}{g}.
   \]

3. Horizontal range \(R\):  
   \[
     R=v_{0x}\,T
     =v_0\cos\theta\;\frac{2\,v_0\sin\theta}{g}
     =\frac{v_0^2\sin2\theta}{g}.
   \]

4. Numerical values (\(g=9.8\) m/s²):  
   \[
     T=\frac{2\,(19.5)(\sin45^\circ)}{9.8}\approx2.815\;\mathrm{s}, 
     \quad
     R=\frac{(19.5)^2\sin90^\circ}{9.8}\approx38.80\;\mathrm{m}.
   \]

5. The player is initially \(55\) m from the kick, so to meet the ball just before it lands he must run the distance  
   \(\Delta x=|55-R|=55-38.80=16.20\;\mathrm{m}.\)  
   His required average speed is  
   \[
     v_{\rm player}
     =\frac{\Delta x}{T}
     =\frac{16.20}{2.815}
     \approx5.76\;\mathrm{m/s}.
   \]

Final Answers (brief):

• Time of flight:  
  \(T=\displaystyle\frac{2\,v_0\sin\theta}{g}\approx2.82\;\mathrm{s}.\)

• Range:  
  \(R=\displaystyle\frac{v_0^2\sin2\theta}{g}\approx38.8\;\mathrm{m}.\)

• Player’s required average speed:  
  \[
    v_{\rm player}
    =\frac{55-R}{T}\approx5.76\;\mathrm{m/s}.
  \]

Solution Outline:

1.  Fundamental frequency of a stretched string of length \(L\), tension \(T\), and linear mass density \(\mu\):
   \[
     f \;=\;\frac{1}{2L}\,\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \mu \;=\;\frac{T}{(2L\,f)^2}\,.
   \]

2.  All four strings have the same \(L\) and \(T\).  Label the lowest (thickest) string with index \(n=1\), frequency \(f_1\), and mass density \(\mu_1\).  Each successive string has
   \[
     f_{n+1} \;=\;\tfrac32\,f_n
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     f_n \;=\;\bigl(\tfrac32\bigr)^{\,n-1}\,f_1.
   \]

3.  Then
   \[
     \mu_n \;=\;\frac{T}{(2L\,f_n)^2}
     \;=\;\frac{T}{\bigl(2L\,( (3/2)^{\,n-1}f_1 )\bigr)^2}
     \;=\;\frac{T}{(2L\,f_1)^2}\;\bigl(\tfrac23\bigr)^{2(n-1)}
     \;=\;\mu_1\;\bigl(\tfrac23\bigr)^{2(n-1)}.
   \]

4.  For \(n=1,2,3,4\) the ratios \(\mu_n/\mu_1\) are:
   \[
     \begin{aligned}
       \mu_1 &= \mu_1\,,\\
       \mu_2 &= \mu_1\bigl(\tfrac23\bigr)^2 = \tfrac{4}{9}\,\mu_1,\\
       \mu_3 &= \mu_1\bigl(\tfrac23\bigr)^4 = \tfrac{16}{81}\,\mu_1,\\
       \mu_4 &= \mu_1\bigl(\tfrac23\bigr)^6 = \tfrac{64}{729}\,\mu_1.
     \end{aligned}
   \]

Final Answers (relative to the lowest string’s \(\mu_1\)):

\[
\boxed{
\mu_1 : \mu_2 : \mu_3 : \mu_4
\;=\;
1 : \tfrac{4}{9} : \tfrac{16}{81} : \tfrac{64}{729}
}
\]

Below is a concise “spring‐analogy” derivation.  We imagine the two colliding masses joined by a spring of stiffness \(k\).  In the centre‐of‐mass frame the relative motion has reduced mass 
\[
\mu=\frac{m_1m_2}{m_1+m_2}
\]
and initial relative speed 
\[
v_{\rm rel}=v_1-v_2.
\]

1.  Maximum compression \(\delta_1\) (relative speed goes to zero) follows from energy conservation:
\[
\tfrac12\,\mu\,v_{\rm rel}^2 \;=\;\tfrac12\,k\,\delta_1^2
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\delta_1
=\;v_{\rm rel}\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{k}}.
\]

2.  By the definition of restitution \(e\), the “rebound” amplitude is
\[
\delta_2=e\,\delta_1\,,\qquad 0\le e\le1.
\]

3.  If the spring’s natural length is \(l_0\), then at maximum compression
\[
l_1=l_0-\delta_1,
\]
and at maximum extension (after collision)
\[
l_2=l_0+\delta_2.
\]

4.  Hence
\[
l_2-l_1 \;=\;(\,l_0+\delta_2\,)-(\,l_0-\delta_1\,)
=\delta_1+\delta_2>0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
l_2>l_1.
\]

In particular for any inelastic collision (\(0<e<1\)) one finds
\[
\boxed{l_1<l_2\,.}
\]
Answer in brief:  
For inelastic collisions \(\;l_1<l_2.\)

Step 1.  Work done by a position‐dependent force is
\[
W \;=\;\int_{x_i}^{x_f} F(x)\,dx
\]
Here \(x_i=0\), \(x_f=5\), and \(F(x)=7-2x+3x^2\).

Step 2.  Integrate term by term:
\[
W=\int_{0}^{5}\bigl(7-2x+3x^2\bigr)\,dx
=\Bigl[7x - x^2 + x^3\Bigr]_{0}^{5}.
\]

Step 3.  Evaluate at the limits:
\[
W = \bigl(7\cdot5 -5^2 +5^3\bigr) - \bigl(0\bigr)
=35 -25 +125 =135\;\mathrm J.
\]

Answer in brief:  \(W=135\rm\ J\)  (option D).

Here is a step‐by‐step lumped‐capacitance solution.

1. Data and assumptions  
   – Plate thickness \(t=0.5\ \text{cm}=0.005\ \mathrm m\)  
   – Plate width \(W=2\ \mathrm m\)  
   – Velocity \(v=15\ \mathrm{m/min}=\tfrac{15}{60}=0.25\ \mathrm{m/s}\)  
   – Bath length \(L=9\ \mathrm m\;\Rightarrow\) residence time  
     \[
       t_{\rm res}=\frac{L}{v}=\frac{9}{0.25}=36\ \mathrm s
     \]  
   – Initial plate temperature \(T_i=820^\circ\mathrm C\), bath \(T_\infty=45^\circ\mathrm C\)  
   – Convection coeff. \(h=860\ \mathrm{W/m^2K}\) both sides  
   – Steel properties: \(\rho=7800\ \mathrm{kg/m^3},\ c_p=2000\ \mathrm{J/kg\,K}\)  
   – Verify Biot number (approximate \(k_{\rm steel}\approx40\ \mathrm{W/m\!K}\)):
     \[
       \Bi=\frac{h\,t}{k}\approx\frac{860\cdot0.005}{40}\approx0.108<0.1\;\text{(borderline)}.
     \]
     We proceed with the lumped‐capacitance model.

2. Governing ODE (lumped model)  
   For a plate of mass \(m\) and surface area \(A_s\) (both sides),  
   \[
     m\,c_p\,\frac{dT}{dt}
       =-h\,A_s\bigl(T-T_\infty\bigr)
       \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \frac{dT}{dt}
       =-\frac{h\,A_s}{m\,c_p}\,(T-T_\infty)\,.
   \]

3. Geometry‐per‐unit‐length  
   Per metre length of plate:  
   \[
     m'=\rho\,W\,t,\quad
     A_s'=2\,W\quad(\text{both faces}).
   \]  
   Hence the lumped coefficient  
   \[
     k=\frac{h\,A_s'}{m'\,c_p}
       =\frac{h\,(2W)}{\rho\,W\,t\,c_p}
       =\frac{2\,h}{\rho\,t\,c_p}
       =\frac{2\cdot860}{7800\cdot0.005\cdot2000}
       \approx0.02205\ \mathrm s^{-1}\,.
   \]

4. Temperature profile and exit temperature  
   Solve \(\frac{dT}{dt}=-k(T-T_\infty)\) with \(T(0)=T_i\):  
   \[
     T(t)-T_\infty=(T_i-T_\infty)\,e^{-k\,t}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     T_{\rm exit}
       =T_\infty+(T_i-T_\infty)\,e^{-k\,t_{\rm res}}.
   \]  
   Numerically,
   \[
     e^{-k\,t_{\rm res}}
       =\exp\bigl(-0.02205\cdot36\bigr)
       \approx0.452,\quad
     T_{\rm exit}
       =45+(820-45)\times0.452
       \approx395.3^\circ\mathrm C.
   \]

5. Rate of heat removal  
   Mass‐flow rate of plate through bath:
   \[
     \dot m=\rho\,W\,t\,v
           =7800\cdot2\cdot0.005\cdot0.25
           =19.5\ \mathrm{kg/s}.
   \]
   Heat removed per second,
   \[
     \dot Q
       =\dot m\,c_p\,(T_i-T_{\rm exit})
       =19.5\cdot2000\cdot(820-395.3)
       \approx1.66\times10^{7}\ \mathrm W
       =16.6\ \mathrm{MW}.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

• Exit temperature of sheet:  
  \[
    \boxed{T_{\rm exit}\approx395^\circ\mathrm C.}
  \]

• Required heat‐removal rate from oil bath:  
  \[
    \boxed{\dot Q\approx1.66\times10^7\ \mathrm W\;(16.6\rm\ MW).}
  \]

Here is a step‐by‐step proof that a lone electron in free space cannot emit a single photon, because you cannot satisfy both energy and momentum conservation simultaneously.  After that, a brief summary answer follows.

1.  Define before‐and‐after 4‐momenta  
   – Initial electron: \(P_i=(E_i/c,\;\mathbf p_i)\),  where  
       \[E_i=\sqrt{p_i^2c^2+m^2c^4}\,. \]  
   – Final electron: \(P_f=(E_f/c,\;\mathbf p_f)\),  where  
       \[E_f=\sqrt{p_f^2c^2+m^2c^4}\,. \]  
   – Emitted photon: \(k=(E_\gamma/c,\;\mathbf k)\),  with  
       \[E_\gamma=\hbar\omega=|\mathbf k|\,c\,. \]

2.  Impose conservation of total energy and momentum  
   \[
     E_i \;=\; E_f+E_\gamma
     \quad,\quad
     \mathbf p_i\;=\;\mathbf p_f+\mathbf k\,. 
   \]

3.  Square the 4‐momentum of the final electron:  
   \[
     m^2c^2 \;=\; P_f^2
     \;=\;\Bigl(\tfrac{E_f}{c}\Bigr)^{2}-|\mathbf p_f|^2
     \;=\;\Bigl(\tfrac{E_i - E_\gamma}{c}\Bigr)^{2}
            -|\mathbf p_i-\mathbf k|^2\,.
   \]
   Expand:
   \[
     m^2c^2
     =\frac{E_i^2-2E_iE_\gamma+E_\gamma^2}{c^2}
       -\bigl(p_i^2-2\mathbf p_i\!\cdot\!\mathbf k +k^2\bigr)\,.
   \]
   But \(E_i^2=p_i^2c^2+m^2c^4\) and \(E_\gamma^2=(kc)^2\).  So most terms cancel, leaving
   \[
     -2\,\frac{E_iE_\gamma}{c^2}
     +2\,\mathbf p_i\!\cdot\!\mathbf k
     =0
     \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
     E_i\,E_\gamma
     =c^2\,\mathbf p_i\!\cdot\!\mathbf k
     =p_i\,k\,c^2\cos\theta\,.
   \]

4.  Since \(E_\gamma=k\,c\), this becomes
   \[
     E_i=k\,c\;\bigl(p_i\cos\theta\bigr)/E_\gamma
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     E_i=p_i\,c\cos\theta\,.
   \]
   But for any real electron \(E_i=\sqrt{p_i^2c^2+m^2c^4}>p_ic\), so there is no real angle \(\theta\) with \(\cos\theta>1\).  Hence no solution.

5.  Conclusion: a free electron cannot emit a single photon by itself.  To make emission possible one needs a third body (e.g.\ an atom or nucleus) to absorb recoil momentum (and a bit of energy), so that both energy and momentum conservation can be satisfied simultaneously.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Brief answer:  
• Conservation of \(E\) and \(\mathbf p\) for  
  \(e^-\to e^- +\gamma\) leads to the impossible condition  
  \[\;E_i = p_i\,c\cos\theta\quad(\text{but }E_i>p_ic).\]  
• Therefore a third body is required to take up recoil momentum and energy.

Here is a systematic solution.

1.  Notation  
   Let the four fork frequencies be  
   \[
     f_1=500\rm\ Hz,\quad f_2,\;f_3,\;f_4.
   \]  
   The six beat‐frequencies are  
   \[
     |f_i - f_j|\;=\;1,\;2,\;3,\;5,\;7,\;8\quad (i<j).
   \]  

2.  Reduction to three “shifts”  
   Since \(f_1=500\), set  
   \[
     d_2=f_2-500,\;d_3=f_3-500,\;d_4=f_4-500,
   \]  
   where each \(d_k>0\).  Then three of the beat‐frequencies are \(\{d_2,d_3,d_4\}\), and the other three are  
   \[
     |d_3-d_2|,\;|d_4-d_2|,\;|d_4-d_3|.
   \]  
   We must partition the set \(\{1,2,3,5,7,8\}\) into  
   \[
     \{d_2,d_3,d_4\}\quad\text{and}\quad\{|d_3-d_2|,\;|d_4-d_2|,\;|d_4-d_3|\}.
   \]  

3.  Search for integer triples  
   One finds exactly two workable choices for \(\{d_2,d_3,d_4\}\):

   a.  \(\{d_2,d_3,d_4\}=\{1,3,8\}\).  Then  
       \[
         |3-1|=2,\quad|8-1|=7,\quad|8-3|=5,
       \]  
       which indeed yields the remaining beat‐frequencies \(\{2,5,7\}\).  
       Hence  
       \[
         (f_2,f_3,f_4)=(500+1,\;500+3,\;500+8)=(501,503,508)\rm\ Hz.
       \]

   b.  \(\{d_2,d_3,d_4\}=\{5,7,8\}\).  Then  
       \[
         |7-5|=2,\quad|8-5|=3,\quad|8-7|=1,
       \]  
       which yields the remaining beat‐frequencies \(\{1,2,3\}\).  
       Hence  
       \[
         (f_2,f_3,f_4)=(500+5,\;500+7,\;500+8)=(505,507,508)\rm\ Hz.
       \]

4.  Final answers  
   The four tuning‐fork frequencies can be either  
   \[
     \{500,\,501,\,503,\,508\}\rm\ Hz
     \quad\text{or}\quad
     \{500,\,505,\,507,\,508\}\rm\ Hz.
   \]

All beat‐frequencies \(\bigl|f_i-f_j\bigr|\) in each case are exactly \(\{1,2,3,5,7,8\}\).

Step-by-step solution:

1.  On the Hertzsprung–Russell diagram  
    – the vertical axis is luminosity \(L\),  
    – the horizontal axis is effective temperature \(T_{\rm eff}\) (or color; hot→left, cool→right).

2.  A “vertical” track means the protostar’s position does not move left or right, so  
    \[
      T_{\rm eff}=\hbox{constant}\quad\longrightarrow\quad\hbox{color constant.}
    \]

3.  Recall the Stefan–Boltzmann law  
    \[
      L \;=\; 4\pi R^2\,\sigma\,T_{\rm eff}^4.
    \]
    With \(T_{\rm eff}\) fixed, changes in \(L\) come from changes in the radius \(R\).

4.  Conclusion: along the Hayashi track the protostar’s effective temperature (hence color) stays fixed.

Final answer in brief:

c. The star remains the same color.

Here is a complete, step-by-step solution.  All equations are written in LaTeX.  

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  
**Given:**  
mass \(m=210\;\rm kg\)  
impact speed \(v_{0}=311\;\rm km/h\)  
penetration depth \(\Delta x=0.81\;\rm m\)  
final speed \(v=0\)  
acceleration due to gravity \(g=9.80\;\rm m/s^{2}\)  

We take the **downward** direction as positive.  

1) Convert \(v_{0}\) to m/s:  
\[
v_{0}
=311\;\frac{\rm km}{\rm h}\times\frac{1000\;\rm m}{1\;\rm km}\times\frac{1\;\rm h}{3600\;\rm s}
=86.39\;\rm m/s
\]

—————————————————————————  
**(a) Acceleration**  
Use the kinematic relation (constant \(a\)):  
\[
v^2 = v_0^2 + 2\,a\,\Delta x.
\]
Since \(v=0\),  
\[
0 = v_0^2 + 2\,a\,\Delta x  
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad  
a = -\,\frac{v_0^2}{2\,\Delta x}
= -\,\frac{(86.39)^2}{2\,(0.81)}
= -4.61\times10^3\;\rm m/s^2.
\]
In “g’s”:  
\[
\frac{|a|}{g} = \frac{4.61\times10^3}{9.80}\approx 470\;g.
\]

—————————————————————————  
**(b) Force exerted by the ground**  
Newton’s 2nd law (downward positive):  
\[
\Sigma F = m\,a = m\,g - N
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
N = m\,g - m\,a = m\,(g - a).
\]
Because \(a\) is negative, \(g - a = g + |a|\). Numerically,  
\[
N 
=210\bigl(9.80 + 4.61\times10^3\bigr)
\approx9.70\times10^5\;\rm N.
\]
As a multiple of the weight (\(mg=210\times9.80=2.06\times10^3\rm N\)):  
\[
\frac{N}{mg}
= \frac{9.70\times10^5}{2.06\times10^3}
\approx471.
\]

—————————————————————————  
**(c) Duration of the crash**  
Use  
\[
v = v_0 + a\,t
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
0 = 86.39 + (-4.61\times10^3)\,t
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
t = \frac{86.39}{4.61\times10^3}
\approx1.88\times10^{-2}\;\rm s.
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  
**Final Answers (brief):**  
(a) \(a = -4.61\times10^{3}\;\rm m/s^2\;=\;-470\,g\).  
(b) \(N =9.70\times10^{5}\;\rm N\;=\;471\,mg\).  
(c) \(t=1.88\times10^{-2}\;\rm s\).

Below we take Eqs. (10.6)–(10.9) in SI units, namely  
(10.6) ∇·D = ρ₊  
(10.7) ∇·B = 0  
(10.8) ∇×E = −∂B/∂t  
(10.9) ∇×H = J₊ + ∂D/∂t  

and show how they collapse into two compact “matrix” (tensor) equations.  

1)  Define the field‐strength tensor F^{μν} and its dual \tilde F^{μν} by  
   \[
   F^{\mu\nu}
   =\begin{pmatrix}
     0     & E_x/c & E_y/c & E_z/c\\
    -E_x/c &    0   & -B_z  &  B_y \\
    -E_y/c &  B_z   &   0   & -B_x \\
    -E_z/c & -B_y   &  B_x  &   0
   \end{pmatrix},
   \qquad
   \tilde F^{\mu\nu}
   =\tfrac12\,\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}F_{\rho\sigma}\,. 
   \]  
   Likewise introduce the four-current  
   \[
     J^\mu=(c\,\rho_+,\,J_x,\,J_y,\,J_z)\,.  
   \]  

2)  Then the four Maxwell equations become the single inhomogeneous tensor equation  
   \[
   \boxed{
     \partial_\mu F^{\mu\nu}\;=\;\mu_0\,J^\nu
   }
   \tag{10.10}
   \]  
   and the single homogeneous (Bianchi) identity  
   \[
   \boxed{
     \partial_\mu\tilde F^{\mu\nu}\;=\;0
   }
   \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
   \partial_\alpha F_{\beta\gamma}+\partial_\beta F_{\gamma\alpha}
     +\partial_\gamma F_{\alpha\beta}=0\,.
   \tag{10.11}
   \]  

Briefly, then, the final answers are:

• Inhomogeneous Maxwell → ∂_μ F^{μν}=μ₀ J^ν.  
• Homogeneous Maxwell → ∂_μ \tilde F^{μν}=0.

Here is a step‐by‐step derivation using two complementary methods.

1.  Notation and setup  
    • Original spring constant: \(k\).  
    • Original length: \(L\).  
    • We cut into \(n\) equal pieces, each of length \(L/n\) and (unknown) spring constant \(k_n\).  

2.  Method A:  Series‐combination rule  
    When \(n\) identical springs of constant \(k_n\) are joined in series, the net constant is
    \[
      \frac1{k_{\rm net}} \;=\;\sum_{i=1}^n \frac1{k_n}
      \;=\; \frac{n}{k_n}\,.
    \]
    But this series combination must reproduce the original,
    \[
      k_{\rm net}=k\,,
      \quad
      \frac1{k}=\frac{n}{k_n}
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      k_n = n\,k.
    \]
    Hence
    (a) for \(n=2\): \(k_{\rm half}=2k\).  
    (b) for \(n=3\): \(k_{\rm third}=3k\).

3.  Method B:  Direct‐force argument  
    A spring of length \(L\) and constant \(k\) obeys
    \[
      F = k\,\Delta x_{\rm tot}.
    \]
    If cut into two equal halves, each half stretches by \(\Delta x_1\) so that
    \[
      \Delta x_{\rm tot}=2\,\Delta x_1
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      F = k\,(2\,\Delta x_1)=2k\,\Delta x_1\equiv k_{\rm half}\,\Delta x_1
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      k_{\rm half}=2k.
    \]
    Similarly for three pieces,
    \[
      \Delta x_{\rm tot}=3\,\Delta x_3,
      \quad
      F=k\,(3\,\Delta x_3)=3k\,\Delta x_3
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      k_{\rm third}=3k.
    \]

Final concise answers:  
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a) }\;k_{\rm half}=2\,k,\\
&\text{(b) }\;k_{\rm each\;of\;3}=3\,k.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Below is a self‐contained, step‐by‐step relativistic solution.  At the end you will find the brief final answers.

1.  Notation and given data  
   Let  
     m₁=3.000 u, v₁=+0.6 c  
     m₂=4.000 u, v₂=−0.6 c  
   After collision: one fragment is m₃=6.000 u at rest (v₃=0), the other has unknown rest mass M and velocity V.  
   Define γᵢ≡1/√(1−vᵢ²/c²).

2.  Compute the initial total energy E_i and momentum p_i in the lab frame  
   Since γ₁=γ₂=1/√(1−0.6²)=1/0.8=1.25,  
   (a) Energy  
     E_i 
       = γ₁m₁c² + γ₂m₂c²  
       =1.25·3.000 u c² +1.25·4.000 u c²  
       =8.75 u c².  
   (b) Momentum  
     p_i 
       = γ₁m₁v₁ + γ₂m₂v₂  
       =1.25·3.000 u·(0.6 c) +1.25·4.000 u·(−0.6 c)  
       =(2.25−3.00) u c  
       =−0.75 u c.  

3.  Final total E_f and p_f  
   The 6 u piece is at rest, so γ₃=1, v₃=0 ⇒ p₃=0, E₃=6 u c².  
   The other piece has  
     E₄ = γ₄ M c²,    p₄ = γ₄ M V.  
   Conservation ⇒  
     E_f = E_i ⇒ 6 u c² + γ₄ M c² = 8.75 u c²  
       ⟹ γ₄ M = 8.75 u −6.00 u =2.75 u.            (1)  
     p_f = p_i ⇒ γ₄ M V = −0.75 u c.                 (2)  

4.  Solve for V/c  
   Divide (2) by (1):  
     V/c = (γ₄ M V)/(γ₄ M c) = (−0.75 u c)/(2.75 u c)  
         = −0.75/2.75  
         ≃ −0.27273.  
   Hence  
     V ≃ −0.273 c  (i.e. to the left).  

5.  Solve for M  
   γ₄ = 1/√[1−(V/c)²] = 1/√(1−0.27273²) ≃1.0395.  
   From (1):  
     M = (2.75 u)/γ₄ ≃2.75/1.0395 u ≃2.646 u.  

6.  Kinetic‐energy change ΔK  
   K_i = (γ₁−1)m₁c² + (γ₂−1)m₂c²  
       =0.25·3.000 u c² +0.25·4.000 u c²  
       =1.75 u c².  
   K_f = (γ₃−1)m₃c² + (γ₄−1)M c²  
       =0 + (1.0395−1)·2.646 u c²  
       ≃0.1045 u c².  
   ΔK = K_f − K_i ≃0.1045 u c² −1.75 u c²  
       ≃ −1.6455 u c².  
   (A negative ΔK means 1.6455 u c² of kinetic energy is converted into internal/excitation energy.)

Final Answers (brief)

(a) Mass of the other object:  
   M ≃2.646 u  
    Speed: |V| ≃0.273 c (to the left)

(b) Change in kinetic energy:  
   ΔK ≃−1.646 u c².

Step 1: Identify the two terms in Eq. (43.11).  In the liquid‐drop picture the binding energy per nucleus is often written as  
\[B(A)\;=\;a_V\,A \;-\;a_S\,A^{2/3} \;+\;\dots\]  
where  
• \(a_V\,A\) is the volume term (first term), and  
• \(a_S\,A^{2/3}\) is the surface term (second term).  

Step 2: Form the ratio of the surface term to the volume term:  
\[
R(A)\;=\;\frac{a_S\,A^{2/3}}{\,a_V\,A}
\;=\;\frac{a_S}{a_V}\;A^{-1/3}\,.  
\]

Step 3: Examine the \(A\)-dependence.  Since  
\[
A^{-1/3}\;\longrightarrow\;0
\quad\hbox{as}\quad
A\;\to\;\infty,
\]  
we have  
\[
R(A)\;\propto\;A^{-1/3}
\;\longrightarrow\;0
\quad\hbox{as}\quad
A\;\to\;\infty.
\]  

Step 4: Physical interpretation.  In a large nucleus the fraction of nucleons on the surface goes like  
\[
\frac{\hbox{surface nucleons}}{\hbox{total nucleons}}
\sim\frac{A^{2/3}}{A}
= A^{-1/3},
\]  
which tends to zero for large \(A\).  Thus the surface energy becomes negligible compared to the volume energy as the nucleus grows.  

Conclusion: Yes, it makes perfect physical sense.  A larger nucleus has relatively fewer surface nucleons, so the surface‐energy correction (the second term) loses importance relative to the bulk volume term (the first term).  

— Final Answers in Brief—  
1. Eq. (43.11): 
   \[
   B(A)=a_V\,A - a_S\,A^{2/3}+\cdots.
   \]  
2. Relative size:
   \[
   \frac{a_S\,A^{2/3}}{a_V\,A}=\frac{a_S}{a_V}A^{-1/3}\xrightarrow[A\to\infty]{}0.
   \]  
3. Physical sense: In large nuclei surface‐to‐volume ratio \(\sim A^{-1/3}\) → 0, so surface term becomes negligible.

\]
where \(R_0=R(0)=5000\) dpm.

Step 2.  Use the data at \(t=5\) min:
\[
R(5)=1250
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
1250=5000\,e^{-5\lambda}

Answer in brief:

Here is a step‐by‐step solution:

1.  Free‐body diagram on an incline of angle θ:  
    – Weight: \(mg\) vertically down.  
    – Normal force: \(N\) perpendicular to the surface.  
    – Static friction \(f_s\) up the incline (to prevent sliding).

2.  Components of weight:  
    – Perpendicular: \(mg\cos\theta\) → gives  
       \(N = mg\cos\theta\).  
    – Parallel (down‐slope): \(mg\sin\theta\).

3.  Maximum static friction:  
   \[
   f_{s,\max} \;=\;\mu_s\,N \;=\;\mu_s\,m g\cos\theta.
   \]

4.  Equilibrium (no sliding) requires  
   \[
     f_{\rm req}=m g\sin\theta \;\le\;f_{s,\max}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     m g\sin\theta \le \mu_s\,m g\cos\theta
   \]
   \[
     \boxed{\;\tan\theta \le \mu_s\;}.
   \]

5.  Critical angle:  
   \[
     \theta_c = \arctan(\mu_s) = \arctan(0.15)\approx 8.53^\circ.
   \]

6.  Compare each driveway:  
   – 12°:  \(\tan12^\circ\approx0.213>0.15\) → slides.  
   – 9.0°: \(\tan9^\circ\approx0.158>0.15\) → slides.  
   – 6.0°: \(\tan6^\circ\approx0.105<0.15\) → holds.

Final answer (brief):

Only the 6.0° driveway is safe to park on.

Solution:

1.  Fermi‐energy formula (free‐electron model)  
   \[
     E_F \;=\;\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\,(3\pi^2\,n)^{2/3}
   \]
   where  
   • \(E_F\) is the Fermi energy,  
   • \(m\) is the electron mass,  
   • \(\hbar\) is the reduced Planck constant,  
   • \(n\) is the conduction‐electron density (per unit volume).

2.  Solve for \(n\):  
   \[
     (3\pi^2 n)^{2/3}
       = \frac{2m\,E_F}{\hbar^2}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     n \;=\;\frac{1}{3\pi^2}\,
       \Bigl(\frac{2m\,E_F}{\hbar^2}\Bigr)^{3/2}.
   \]

3.  Numerical values (SI units):  
   \[
     E_F = 11.6~\mathrm{eV} = 11.6\times1.602\times10^{-19}~\mathrm J 
             = 1.858\times10^{-18}~\mathrm J,
   \]  
   \[
     m = 9.109\times10^{-31}~\mathrm{kg}, 
     \quad 
     \hbar = \frac{6.626\times10^{-34}}{2\pi}~\mathrm{J\,s}.
   \]  
   Then  
   \[
     n = \frac{1}{3\pi^2}
         \Bigl(\frac{2\,(9.109\times10^{-31})(1.858\times10^{-18})}
                     {(6.626\times10^{-34}/2\pi)^2}\Bigr)^{3/2}
       \approx 1.79\times10^{29}~\mathrm{m}^{-3}.
   \]

4.  Atomic (Al) density:  
   \[
     n_{\rm atom}
       = \frac{\rho\,N_A}{M}
       = \frac{2.70\times10^3~\mathrm{kg/m^3}\,\times\,6.022\times10^{23}~\mathrm{mol^{-1}}}
              {0.02698~\mathrm{kg/mol}}
       \approx 6.03\times10^{28}~\mathrm{m}^{-3}.
   \]

5.  Conduction electrons per atom:  
   \[
     Z \;=\;\frac{n}{n_{\rm atom}}
       = \frac{1.79\times10^{29}}{6.03\times10^{28}}
       \approx 2.97 \;\approx 3.
   \]

Final answers in brief:

• Conduction‐electron density:  
  \(n \approx 1.79\times10^{29}\,\mathrm{m}^{-3}.\)  
• Atomic density:  
  \(n_{\rm atom}\approx 6.03\times10^{28}\,\mathrm{m}^{-3}.\)  
• Number of conduction electrons per Al atom:  
  \(Z\approx 3.\)

Below is the step‐by‐step solution.

1. First law of thermodynamics  
   \[
     \Delta U = Q - W
   \]
   where  
   • \(\Delta U\) = change in internal energy  
   • \(Q\) = heat absorbed by the gas  
   • \(W\) = work done by the gas  

2. Isothermal process for an ideal gas  
   For an ideal gas \(U\) depends only on temperature \(T\).  In an isothermal change \(\Delta T=0\), so  
   \[
     \Delta U = 0.
   \]

3. Determine \(Q\)  
   From \(\Delta U = Q - W\) and \(\Delta U = 0\),  
   \[
     0 = Q - W
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     Q = W.
   \]

4. Numerical values  
   Given \(W = 4.30\times10^3\ \mathrm{J}\), we have  
   \[
     \Delta U = 0,\qquad
     Q = 4.30\times10^3\ \mathrm{J}.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

(a) \(\displaystyle \Delta U = 0\).  
(b) \(\displaystyle Q = +4.30\times10^3\ \mathrm{J}.\)

Step 1: Geometry and free‐stream conditions  
Let the cylinder radius be  
\[
a = \frac{200\rm\ mm}{2}=0.10\rm\ m,
\]
and the uniform flow at infinity be  
\[
U=6\rm\ m/s,\qquad p_\infty=150\ kPa,\qquad \rho=1.5\ Mg/m^3=1500\ kg/m^3.
\]

Step 2: Velocity field in potential flow around a cylinder  
In polar coordinates \((r,\theta)\) the velocity components are  
\[
v_r \;=\; U\Bigl(1-\frac{a^2}{r^2}\Bigr)\cos\theta,
\qquad
v_\theta\;=\;-\,U\Bigl(1+\frac{a^2}{r^2}\Bigr)\sin\theta.
\]
Along the ray \(\theta=90^\circ\), \(\cos90^\circ=0,\;\sin90^\circ=1\), so  
\[
v_r=0,\qquad 
v_\theta=-\,U\Bigl(1+\frac{a^2}{r^2}\Bigr).
\]
Hence the speed is  
\[
v(r)\;=\;|v_\theta|\;=\;U\Bigl(1+\frac{a^2}{r^2}\Bigr).
\]

Step 3: Pressure from Bernoulli’s equation  
For steady, incompressible, irrotational flow  
\[
p+\tfrac12\,\rho\,v^2
=\;p_\infty+\tfrac12\,\rho\,U^2
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
p(r)=p_\infty+\tfrac12\,\rho\bigl[\,U^2-v(r)^2\bigr].
\]
Substituting \(v(r)=U\bigl(1+a^2/r^2\bigr)\) gives
\[
p(r)
=p_\infty
-\tfrac12\,\rho\,U^2\Bigl[\bigl(1+\tfrac{a^2}{r^2}\bigr)^2-1\Bigr]
=p_\infty-\tfrac12\,\rho\,U^2\Bigl(\tfrac{2a^2}{r^2}+\tfrac{a^4}{r^4}\Bigr).
\]

Step 4: Tabulation of \(v(r)\) and \(p(r)\) at the requested radii  

Let \(\tfrac12\rho=750\).  We compute  

r (m) | a²∕r² | v=U(1+a²/r²) (m/s) |  v² (m²/s²) | Δp=½ρ(U²–v²) (Pa) | p (kPa)  
------|--------|------------------|-------------|------------------|---------  
0.10  | 1.000  | 12.00            | 144.00      | –81 000          | 69.0    
0.20  | 0.250  | 7.50             | 56.25       | –15 187.5        | 134.8   
0.30  | 0.1111 | 6.6667           | 44.444      | –6 333.3         | 143.7   
0.40  | 0.0625 | 6.375            | 40.641      | –3 480.5         | 146.5   
0.50  | 0.0400 | 6.240            | 38.938      | –2 203.2         | 147.8   

(negative Δp means \(p<p_\infty\) by that amount)

Step 5: Sketch of profiles  
• Velocity \(v(r)\) falls monotonically from \(2U\) at \(r=a\) to \(U\) as \(r\to\infty\).  
• Pressure \(p(r)\) rises from a minimum at the surface (\(69\rm\ kPa\)) back to \(150\rm\ kPa\) at infinity.

Final answers (brief)  
• \(v(r)=6\bigl(1+0.01/r^2\bigr)\) m/s,  
  so \(v(0.1)=12.00,\;v(0.2)=7.50,\;v(0.3)=6.667,\;v(0.4)=6.375,\;v(0.5)=6.240\)\;m/s.  
• \(p(r)=150\rm\,kPa+750\,[36-v(r)^2]\),  
  so \(p(0.1)=69.0,\;p(0.2)=134.8,\;p(0.3)=143.7,\;p(0.4)=146.5,\;p(0.5)=147.8\)\;kPa.

Step 1: Definitions  
Pool boiling and flow boiling are both nucleate‐boiling heat‐transfer processes in which a heated surface vaporizes a liquid. The key distinction is whether the bulk liquid is stationary or moving:

• Pool boiling: the liquid is quiescent (no forced flow).  
• Flow boiling: the liquid is driven by an external pressure gradient (forced flow) through a channel or over a heated surface.

Step 2: Governing parameters  
1. Pool boiling  
   – Driving force: buoyancy of bubbles in a quiescent pool.  
   – Main control parameters: surface superheat ΔT = T_wall – T_sat and system pressure p.  
   – Heat flux–superheat relation often given by a nucleate-boiling correlation such as Rohsenow’s:  
     \[
       q'' \;=\; \mu_\ell h_{\rm fg} \frac{(g(\rho_\ell-\rho_v))^{1/2}}{\sigma^{1/2}}
         \;C_{sf}\,\Bigl[\frac{c_{p\ell}(T_{\rm sat}-T_\ell)}{h_{\rm fg}}\Bigr]^{3}\!,
     \]  
     or near CHF by Zuber’s hydrodynamic limit:  
     \[
       q''_{\rm CHF}
       =0.131\,\rho_v^{1/2}\bigl[\sigma\,g\,(\rho_\ell-\rho_v)\bigr]^{1/4}h_{\rm fg}\rho_v.
     \]

2. Flow boiling  
   – Driving force: imposed mass flux \(G=\dot m/A\).  
   – Main control parameters: mass flux \(G\), local quality \(x\), hydraulic diameter \(D_h\), system pressure \(p\).  
   – Heat transfer coefficient depends on two‐phase flow pattern; one common correlation is the Chen model:  
     \[
       h_{\rm TP}
       =S\,h_{\rm lo} + F\,h_{\rm nb}\!,
     \]  
     where \(h_{\rm lo}\) is single‐phase liquid convection, \(h_{\rm nb}\) the nucleate‐boiling coefficient, and \(S,F\) are suppression/augmentation factors function of \(G\) and \(x\).

Step 3: Bubble dynamics & flow patterns  
– In pool boiling, bubbles grow, detach and rise by buoyancy; interaction is purely with ambient liquid.  
– In flow boiling, bubble growth, coalescence and sliding are strongly influenced by liquid velocity, pressure drop and confinement; flow regimes (bubbly, slug, annular, mist) control heat transfer.

Step 4: Critical Heat Flux (CHF) behavior  
– Pool boiling CHF occurs when a vapor film blankets the surface (Leidenfrost).  
– Flow boiling CHF is also a dry-out or departure–from–nucleate‐boiling (DNB) phenomenon, but its value rises with mass flux and confinement; correlations often take the form  
  \[
    q''_{\rm CHF,flow}
    =K\,G^m\Bigl[\sigma\,g\,(\rho_\ell-\rho_v)\Bigr]^n
  \]  
  with empirical \(K,m,n\).

Step 5: Practical implications  
– Pool boiling is easier to characterize experimentally but offers lower CHF and \(h\).  
– Flow boiling enables much higher heat‐flux removal at moderate superheat but requires pumping power and careful design of two‐phase flow paths.

======  
Final Answers (brief)  

• Pool boiling:  
  – Liquid at rest  
  – Heat transfer driven by buoyant bubble detachment  
  – Key parameters: ΔT, p  
  – CHF given by Zuber’s relation  
  – Lower CHF, simpler setup  

• Flow boiling:  
  – Liquid forced through channel  
  – Heat transfer from combination of forced‐convection and nucleate boiling (e.g., Chen correlation)  
  – Key parameters: mass flux G, quality x, Dh, p  
  – Higher CHF (increases with G), complex two‐phase flow patterns  
  – Requires pumping power

Here is a solution by factorizing the differential operator (“method (c)”) and a comparison with the usual constant‐coefficient approach.

1.  Factorization method (method (c))  
    We set \(D=\frac{d}{dt}\).  Then
    \[
      y''+\omega^2y \;=\;(D^2+\omega^2)y
      \;=\;(D-i\omega)(D+i\omega)\,y
      =0.
    \]
    a)  Solve \((D-i\omega)y=0\):  
       \[
         \frac{dy}{dt}-i\omega y=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         y=C_1e^{\,i\omega t}.
       \]
    b)  Solve \((D+i\omega)y=0\):  
       \[
         \frac{dy}{dt}+i\omega y=0
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         y=C_2e^{-\,i\omega t}.
       \]
    c)  By superposition,
       \[
         y(t)=C_1e^{\,i\omega t}+C_2e^{-\,i\omega t}.
       \]

2.  Usual constant‐coefficient (characteristic‐equation) method  
    Assume \(y=e^{rt}\).  Substitution into
    \(y''+\omega^2y=0\) gives
    \[
      r^2+\omega^2=0
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      r=\pm i\omega,
    \]
    hence
    \[
      y(t)=A\,e^{\,i\omega t}+B\,e^{-\,i\omega t}.
    \]

3.  Real‐valued form  
    Using \(A=C_1,\;B=C_2\) and real combinations,
    \[
      y(t)=A\cos(\omega t)+B\sin(\omega t).
    \]

Final Answers (brief):

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Complex form:}
\quad
y(t)=C_1e^{\,i\omega t}+C_2e^{-\,i\omega t},\\
&\text{Real form:}
\quad
y(t)=A\cos(\omega t)+B\sin(\omega t).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Here’s a step‐by‐step solution, with every equation in LaTeX:

1.  Period of a simple pendulum  
    \[
      T \;=\; 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{g}}
    \]
    ⇒ solve for \(L\):
    \[
      L \;=\; g\Bigl(\frac{T}{2\pi}\Bigr)^2
    \]
    Substitute \(T=5.5\rm\ s\), \(g=9.8\rm\ m/s^2\):
    \[
      L \;=\;9.8\,(5.5/2\pi)^2
          \;\approx\;7.50\rm\ m
    \]

2.  Maximum speed at the bottom  
    Small‐angle approximation: the maximum linear amplitude is  
    \[
      A \;=\;L\,\theta_0\quad(\theta_0\rm\ in\ radians),
      \quad
      \theta_0=3^\circ=\frac{3\pi}{180}=0.05236\rm\ rad.
    \]
    The angular frequency is  
    \[
      \omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}
    \]
    so
    \[
      v_{\max} \;=\; \omega\,A
      \;=\;\sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}\,(L\,\theta_0)
      \;=\;\theta_0\sqrt{g\,L}
    \]
    Numerically,
    \[
      v_{\max}
      =0.05236\sqrt{9.8\times7.50}
      \approx0.45\rm\ m/s.
    \]

Final answers (brief):

a. \(L\approx7.50\rm\ m\).  
b. \(v_{\max}\approx0.45\rm\ m/s\).

Step 1 – Fourier expansion  
We have a real, \(T\)-periodic current  
\[
I(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}c_n\,e^{i\omega_0 n t}
\,,\quad
\omega_0=\frac{2\pi}{T}=120\pi\;\mathrm{rad/s}
\]
with complex coefficients \(c_{-n}=c_n^*\) so that \(I(t)\) is real.

Step 2 – Average power in the time domain  
The instantaneous power dissipated in a resistance \(R\) is  
\[
P(t)=R\,I^2(t)\,.
\]  
The average power over one period is  
\[
P_{\rm ave}
=\frac{1}{T}\int_0^T R\,I^2(t)\,dt
=R\,\frac{1}{T}\int_0^T I^2(t)\,dt\,. 
\]

Step 3 – Parseval’s theorem  
Parseval’s theorem for Fourier series states
\[
\frac{1}{T}\int_0^T\bigl|I(t)\bigr|^2\,dt
=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\bigl|c_n\bigr|^2.
\]
Hence the average power can be written purely in terms of the Fourier coefficients:
\[
P_{\rm ave}
=R\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\lvert c_n\rvert^2.
\]

Physical meaning of Parseval’s theorem in this context  
– Each harmonic \(n\) of the current, of amplitude \(c_n\), dissipates a “partial” power  
\(\;R\,|c_n|^2\).  
– The total heat dissipated per second is simply the sum of the powers dissipated by each harmonic.  

Final brief answer  
\[
P_{\rm ave}
=R\,\langle I^2\rangle
=R\,\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\lvert c_n\rvert^2,
\]
i.e. the time-average of \(I^2(t)\) equals the sum of \(\lvert c_n\rvert^2\).
