Step 1. Write the wave and its transverse (particle) velocity  
\(y = y_0\sin\!\Bigl[2\pi\bigl(f\,t - \tfrac{x}{\lambda}\bigr)\Bigr]\)  
\[
v_{\rm p}(t)
= \frac{\partial y}{\partial t}
= y_0\,(2\pi f)\,\cos\!\Bigl[2\pi(f t - \tfrac{x}{\lambda})\Bigr]\,,
\]  
so the maximum particle speed is  
\[
v_{p,\max}
= y_0\,2\pi f\,.
\]

Step 2. Wave (phase) speed  
\[
v = f\,\lambda\,.
\]

Step 3. Impose “particle speed = 4 × wave speed”  
\[
y_0\,(2\pi f) \;=\;4\,(f\lambda)
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
2\pi\,y_0 = 4\,\lambda
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\boxed{\lambda = \frac{\pi\,y_0}{2}}\quad(\text{Option B})
\]

We denote by  
• m the mass of the module,  
• g the (constant) lunar‐surface acceleration due to gravity,  
• h the height above the landing site at which the engine is cut off,  
• v_i the vertical velocity of the module (positive upward, negative downward) at cut‐off,  
• v_f the (maximum safe) impact speed,  

and we assume that at impact the module has fallen from height h (plus whatever “coasting” height comes from an initial upward velocity).  By energy conservation between the instant of engine cut‐off and the moment of impact:

\[
\underbrace{\tfrac12\,m\,v_i^2}_{\text{initial KE}}
\;+\;
\underbrace{m\,g\,h}_{\text{loss of PE}}
\;=\;
\underbrace{\tfrac12\,m\,v_f^2}_{\text{final KE}}.
\]

Solving for h gives the general result

\[
\frac12 m\,v_i^2 \;+\; m\,g\,h \;=\;\frac12 m\,v_f^2
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
h \;=\;\frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2\,g}\,.
\]

Now specialize to the three cases:

1.  (a)  “Engine off at zero speed,”  v_i=0:  
   \[
   h_a = \frac{v_f^2 - 0^2}{2\,g}
          = \frac{v_f^2}{2\,g}\,. 
   \]
2.  (b)  “Engine off while already descending at speed v₀ downward,”  
      here v_i = −v₀ so v_i^2 = v₀^2:  
   \[
   h_b = \frac{v_f^2 - v_0^2}{2\,g}\,, 
   \qquad(v_0>0\text{ is the downward speed at cut‐off})
   \]
3.  (c)  “Engine off while climbing at speed v₀ upward,”  
      here v_i = +v₀ so again v_i^2 = v₀^2:  
   \[
   h_c = \frac{v_f^2 - v_0^2}{2\,g}\,, 
   \qquad(v_0>0\text{ is the upward speed at cut‐off})
   \]

Final summary (all in one line):

   \(h=\dfrac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2g}\), 

   so

   (a) \(h_a=\dfrac{v_f^2}{2g}\),  

   (b) \(h_b=\dfrac{v_f^2 - v_0^2}{2g}\)  with \(v_0\) downward,  

   (c) \(h_c=\dfrac{v_f^2 - v_0^2}{2g}\)  with \(v_0\) upward.

Here is a clear, step–by–step solution.  All equations are in LaTeX.

1) Geometry  
   The disk has radius  
   \[
     R = \frac{5\rm\;m}{2} = 2.5\rm\;m,
   \]  
   the chain length is \(L=6\rm\;m\), and at full speed the chain makes an angle \(\theta=20^\circ\) with the vertical.  
   Hence the horizontal radius of the car’s circular path is  
   \[
     r = R + L\sin\theta
       = 2.5 + 6\sin20^\circ
       \approx 4.552\rm\;m.
   \]

2) Free–body diagram & force equations  
   Let \(T\) be the tension in the chain, \(m\) the mass of the car plus rider, and \(v\) the (constant) speed.  
   Vertically (no acceleration):  
   \[
     T\cos\theta = mg.
   \]  
   Horizontally (centripetal force):  
   \[
     T\sin\theta = \frac{m\,v^2}{r}.
   \]

3) Solve for \(v\)  
   From \(T\cos\theta=mg\) we get 
   \[
     T = \frac{mg}{\cos\theta}.
   \]  
   Substitute into the horizontal equation:
   \[
     \frac{mg}{\cos\theta}\,\sin\theta \;=\;\frac{m\,v^2}{r}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     v^2 = r\,g\,\tan\theta
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     v = \sqrt{r\,g\,\tan\theta}.
   \]

4) Numerical result  
   \[
     r = 4.552\rm\;m,
     \quad
     g = 9.80\rm\;m/s^2,
     \quad
     \tan20^\circ\approx0.364
   \]
   \[
     v = \sqrt{4.552\cdot9.80\cdot0.364}
       \approx 4.03\rm\;m/s.
   \]

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final answer (brief):

\(v \;=\;\sqrt{\bigl(R + L\sin\theta\bigr)\,g\,\tan\theta}
\;\approx\;4.0\rm\;m/s\).

Here is a step‐by‐step solution, with all equations in LaTeX.

(a)  Acceleration of an electron  
1.  The force on a charge $q$ in a field $E$ is  
\[
F=qE\,.
\]  
2.  Thus the acceleration is  
\[
a=\frac{F}{m}=\frac{qE}{m}\,.
\]  
3.  For an electron, $q=-e$ and $m=m_e$, so the magnitude is  
\[
a_e=\frac{e\,E}{m_e}
=\frac{(1.602\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm C)(150\,\mathrm{N/C})}{9.11\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg}}
\approx2.64\times10^{13}\,\mathrm{m/s^2}\,.
\]

(b)  Acceleration of a proton  
\[
a_p=\frac{e\,E}{m_p}
=\frac{(1.602\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm C)(150\,\mathrm{N/C})}{1.673\times10^{-27}\,\mathrm{kg}}
\approx1.44\times10^{10}\,\mathrm{m/s^2}\,.
\]

(c)  Ratios to $g=9.8\,\mathrm{m/s^2}$  
\[
\frac{a_e}{g}\approx\frac{2.64\times10^{13}}{9.8}\approx2.7\times10^{12}, 
\qquad
\frac{a_p}{g}\approx\frac{1.44\times10^{10}}{9.8}\approx1.5\times10^{9}\,.
\]

Final answers (magnitudes):  
(a) $a_e\approx2.6\times10^{13}\,\mathrm{m/s^2}$  
(b) $a_p\approx1.4\times10^{10}\,\mathrm{m/s^2}$  
(c) $a_e/g\approx2.7\times10^{12},\quad a_p/g\approx1.5\times10^{9}$.

Solution:

Let each resistor have resistance \(R\), and let the ideal battery emf be \(V\).

(a) Series connection  
When three resistors are in series, their equivalent resistance is the sum:  
\[
R_{\rm series}
=R+R+R
=3R.
\]

(b) Parallel connection  
When three resistors are in parallel, the reciprocal of the equivalent resistance is the sum of reciprocals:
\[
\frac{1}{R_{\rm parallel}}
=\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{R}
=\frac{3}{R}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
R_{\rm parallel}=\frac{R}{3}.
\]

(c) Potential difference comparison  
An ideal battery maintains the same emf \(V\) across whatever load is connected. Hence
\[
\Delta V_{\rm series}=V
\quad\text{and}\quad
\Delta V_{\rm parallel}=V,
\]
so the potential differences are equal.

Final Answers (brief):

(a) \(R_{\rm series}=3R\)  
(b) \(R_{\rm parallel}=\tfrac{R}{3}\)  
(c) \(\Delta V_{\rm series}=\Delta V_{\rm parallel}\) (equal)

We begin by reading off the ultimate tensile strength σ₍UTS₎ from the stress–strain curves:  

– For the naval brass (Fig. 6.12)  
  σ₍UTS,brass₎ ≃ 380 MPa  

– For the steel alloy (Fig. 6.21)  
  σ₍UTS,steel₎ ≃ 900 MPa  

1.  Brinell hardness  
    An empirical correlation for many metals is  
    $$\tag{1} 
       H_B\approx\frac{\sigma_{\rm UTS}}{3.5\;{\rm MPa/H_B}} 
       \quad(\sigma_{\rm UTS}\text{ in MPa, }H_B\text{ in kgf/mm}^2)\,. $$
    Thus  
    $$\begin{aligned}
      H_{B,\,\rm brass}&\approx\frac{380}{3.5}=108\approx1.1\times10^2\,,\\
      H_{B,\,\rm steel}&\approx\frac{900}{3.5}=257\approx2.6\times10^2\,. 
    \end{aligned}$$

2.  Rockwell hardness  
    –  For relatively soft metals such as brass one uses the B‐scale:  
       $$\tag{2a} 
         H_B\approx0.95\,HR_B 
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         HR_B\approx\frac{H_B}{0.95}\,. $$
    –  For harder alloys normally one uses the C‐scale:  
       $$\tag{2b} 
         H_B\approx 2\,HR_C + 50
         \;\Longrightarrow\;
         HR_C\approx\frac{H_B-50}{2}\,. $$
    Inserting the above H_B:  
    $$\begin{aligned}
      HR_{B,\,\rm brass}&\approx\frac{108}{0.95}\approx114\quad(\text{≈\,85–95 realistically from a conversion chart}),\\
      HR_{C,\,\rm steel}&\approx\frac{257-50}{2}\approx104\quad(\text{but C‐scale tops out at ≃70, so from tables }HR_C\simeq65).
    \end{aligned}$$  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final answers (approximate)  
(a) Naval brass:  
  • Brinell hardness  HB ≃ 1.1×10²  
  • Rockwell‐B hardness  HRB ≃ 85  

(b) Steel alloy:  
  • Brinell hardness  HB ≃ 2.6×10²  
  • Rockwell‐C hardness  HRC ≃ 65

Solution (using Hooke’s law):  

1. Define  
   \(L_0=10\text{ cm}\) (unstretched length),  
   \(L\) = current length,  
   \(\Delta L=L-L_0\) (extension if \(\Delta L>0\), compression if \(\Delta L<0\)),  
   and the spring constant \(k\).  
2. Hooke’s law gives  
   \[
     F \;=\; k\Delta L\;=\;k(L-L_0)\,.
   \]  
3. From the data point \(L=11\text{ cm}\), \(\Delta L=1\text{ cm}\), and \(F\), we get  
   \[
     F = k\,(1\text{ cm})
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     k = \frac{F}{1\text{ cm}}\,.
   \]

(a)  For a restoring force \(F'=3F\),  
\[
  3F \;=\; k\,(L_2 - L_0)
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  L_2 - 10 = \frac{3F}{k} = 3\text{ cm}
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  L_2 = 13\text{ cm}\,.  
\]

(b)  For a restoring force \(F''=2F\) in compression,  
\[
  2F = k\bigl|L_3 - L_0\bigr|
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  |L_3 - 10| = \frac{2F}{k} = 2\text{ cm}.
\]
Since it is compression (\(L_3<L_0\)),  
\[
  L_3 - 10 = -2\quad\Longrightarrow\quad L_3 = 8\text{ cm}\,.  
\]

Final answers (brief):  
a. \(13\text{ cm}\)  
b. \(8\text{ cm}\)

Solution Sketch:

1. Free-body diagram at angle \(\alpha\):
   – Weight: \(mg\) (vertically down).  
   – Normal reaction: \(N\) (radial, perpendicular to surface).  
   – Friction: \(f\) (tangential, opposing slipping).

2. Resolve \(mg\) into components on the surface:
   – Normal component: \(mg\cos\alpha\;\longrightarrow\;N=mg\cos\alpha\).  
   – Tangential component (tending to pull the insect down): \(mg\sin\alpha\).

3. Maximum static friction:  
   \(f_{\max}=\mu N=\mu\,mg\cos\alpha\),  where \(\mu=1/3\).

4. Equilibrium (just about to slip):  
   \(mg\sin\alpha = f_{\max} = \mu\,mg\cos\alpha\)  
   \(\displaystyle\implies \tan\alpha = \mu = \tfrac{1}{3}\)  
   \(\displaystyle\implies \cot\alpha = 3\).

Answer (in brief):  
The maximum angle satisfies \(\displaystyle \cot\alpha=3\). (Option A)

Here we take the principal branch of the complex logarithm, so that \(\ln(-1)=i\pi\).  Recall the standard formula for the complex arctangent:  
\[
\arctan z \;=\;\frac1{2i}\,\bigl[\ln(1+iz)\;-\;\ln(1-iz)\bigr]\,.
\]
Set \(z=2i\).  Then
\[
1+iz \;=\;1+i(2i)=1-2=-1,\qquad
1-iz \;=\;1-i(2i)=1+2=3.
\]
Hence
\[
\arctan(2i)
=\frac1{2i}\Bigl[\ln(-1)-\ln(3)\Bigr]
=\frac1{2i}\bigl[i\pi-\ln3\bigr]
=\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{\ln3}{2i}
=\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{i}{2}\,\ln3.
\]
In \(x+iy\) form this is
\[
\boxed{
\arctan(2i)\;=\;\frac{\pi}{2} \;+\;\frac{i}{2}\ln3
}\,.
\]
Numerical check (e.g.\ in Python’s `cmath`):

\[
\texttt{cmath.atan(2j)}\;\approx\;1.5707963267948966 \;+\;0.5493061443340548\,j
\]
and indeed \(\pi/2\approx1.5707963\), \(\tfrac12\ln3\approx0.5493061\).

Here is the step‐by‐step solution:

1.  Photon energy  
   \[
     E_{\rm ph} \;=\;\frac{h\,c}{\lambda}
   \]  
   where  
   \(h=6.626\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s}\),  
   \(c=3.00\times10^8\,\mathrm{m/s}\),  
   \(\lambda=600\,\mathrm{nm}=6.00\times10^{-7}\,\mathrm{m}\).  
   Thus  
   \[
     E_{\rm ph}
     =\frac{(6.626\times10^{-34})(3.00\times10^8)}{6.00\times10^{-7}}
     \approx3.31\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J}.
   \]

   The bulb emits \(P_{\rm vis}=5\,\mathrm{W}=5\,\mathrm{J/s}\) in visible light.  If each photon carries \(E_{\rm ph}\), then the emission rate is  
   \[
     N
     =\frac{P_{\rm vis}}{E_{\rm ph}}
     =\frac{5\,\mathrm{J/s}}{3.31\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J}}
     \approx1.51\times10^{19}\ \text{photons/s}.
   \]

Final Answer (brief):  
Number of visible photons emitted ≃ \(1.5\times10^{19}\) per second.

Here is the detailed solution.

1.  Energy and turning point  
   The energy of the \(n\)th stationary state of the 1-D harmonic oscillator is
   \[
     E_n \;=\;\hbar\omega\Bigl(n+\tfrac12\Bigr)\,.
   \]
   The classical turning points \(x=\pm x_2\) are given by
   \[
     V(x_2)\;=\;E_n
     \;\longrightarrow\;
     \tfrac12\,m\omega^2\,x_2^2
     \;=\;\hbar\omega\Bigl(n+\tfrac12\Bigr)
     \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
     x_2
     =\sqrt{\frac{2E_n}{m\omega^2}}
     =\sqrt{\frac{2\hbar\omega(n+\tfrac12)}{m\omega^2}}
     =\sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{m\omega}}\;\sqrt{2n+1}\,.
   \]
   Defining the oscillator length \(a\equiv\sqrt{\hbar/(m\omega)}\), one may write
   \[
     \boxed{x_2 \;=\;a\,\sqrt{2n+1}\,.}
   \]

2.  Linearization error at \(x_2+d\)  
   Near \(x_2\), expand
   \[
     V(x)=\tfrac12\,m\omega^2x^2
     =V(x_2)+V'(x_2)\,(x-x_2)+\tfrac12\,V''(x_2)\,(x-x_2)^2+\cdots.
   \]
   Here
   \[
     V'(x_2)=m\omega^2\,x_2\,,\qquad
     V''(x_2)=m\omega^2\,.
   \]
   The linearized potential is
   \[
     V_{\rm lin}(x_2+d)
     =V(x_2)+m\omega^2x_2\,d.
   \]
   The true potential at \(x_2+d\) is
   \[
     V(x_2+d)
     =V(x_2)+m\omega^2x_2\,d+\tfrac12\,m\omega^2\,d^2.
   \]
   Hence the absolute error is \(\tfrac12\,m\omega^2d^2\), and the fractional error relative to \(V(x_2)=\tfrac12m\omega^2x_2^2\) is
   \[
     \frac{V(x_2+d)-V_{\rm lin}(x_2+d)}{V(x_2)}
     =\frac{\tfrac12m\omega^2\,d^2}{\tfrac12m\omega^2\,x_2^2}
     =\Bigl(\tfrac{d}{x_2}\Bigr)^2.
   \]
   Setting this equal to 0.01,
   \[
     \Bigl(\tfrac{d}{x_2}\Bigr)^2=0.01
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     d=0.1\,x_2
     =0.1\,a\,\sqrt{2n+1}\,.
   \]
   \[
     \boxed{d=0.1\,a\,\sqrt{2n+1}\,.}
   \]

3.  Airy‐function overlap criterion  
   In the linearized‐turning‐point analysis the Schrödinger equation becomes an Airy equation with argument
   \[
     z\;=\;\alpha\,(x-x_2), 
     \quad
     \alpha
     =\Bigl[\tfrac{2m}{\hbar^2}\,V'(x_2)\Bigr]^{1/3}
     =\Bigl[\tfrac{2m^2\omega^2x_2}{\hbar^2}\Bigr]^{1/3}.
   \]
   Using \(x_2=a\sqrt{2n+1}\) and \(a=\sqrt{\hbar/(m\omega)}\) one finds
   \[
     \alpha
     =2^{1/3}\,(m\omega/\hbar)^{1/2}\,(2n+1)^{1/6}
     =2^{1/3}\,\frac{(2n+1)^{1/6}}{a}\,.
   \]
   Hence at \(x_2+d\)
   \[
     \alpha\,d
     =2^{1/3}\,\frac{(2n+1)^{1/6}}{a}\;\times\;0.1\,a\,\sqrt{2n+1}
     =0.1\;2^{1/3}\;(2n+1)^{2/3}.
   \]
   Requiring \(\alpha d\ge5\) for the Airy‐asymptotic to be within 1% gives
   \[
     0.1\,2^{1/3}\,(2n+1)^{2/3}\ge5
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     (2n+1)^{2/3}\ge\frac{5}{0.1\,2^{1/3}}
     =\frac{50}{2^{1/3}}
     \;\Longrightarrow\;2n+1\ge250
     \;\Longrightarrow\;n\ge125.
   \]
   \[
     \boxed{n_{\min}=125.}
   \]

  
Final answers (brief):  
(a) \(x_2=a\sqrt{2n+1}\).  
(b) \(d=0.1\,a\sqrt{2n+1}\).  
(c) Minimum \(n\) so that \(\alpha d\ge5\) is \(n=125\).

Here is a detailed, step‐by‐step solution, with all equations in LaTeX, followed by a brief summary of the final answers.

**Given:**  
Rod length \(L=1.60\rm\ m\), rod diameter \(D=5.50\rm\ mm=5.50\times10^{-3}\,m\),  
resistance \(R=1.09\times10^{-3}\,\Omega\) at \(20^\circ\rm C\).

(a) Determine the material (i.e.\ its resistivity \(\rho\)).  
1. Cross‐sectional area of the rod:  
   \[
     A=\pi\Bigl(\frac{D}{2}\Bigr)^2
       =\pi\Bigl(\frac{5.50\times10^{-3}}{2}\Bigr)^2
       =\pi\,(2.75\times10^{-3})^2
       =2.375\times10^{-5}\,\mathrm m^2.
   \]
2. Resistivity from \(R=\rho\,\frac{L}{A}\):  
   \[
     \rho
      =R\,\frac{A}{L}
      =\bigl(1.09\times10^{-3}\bigr)\,\frac{2.375\times10^{-5}}{1.60}
      =1.62\times10^{-8}\,\Omega\cdot\mathrm m.
   \]
3. Comparing \(\rho\approx1.6\times10^{-8}\,\Omega\cdot\mathrm m\) with standard values shows the material is **copper**.

(b) A round disk of the same material has diameter \(d=2.00\rm\ cm=0.020\,m\) and thickness \(t=1.00\rm\ mm=1.00\times10^{-3}\,m\).  
We seek the resistance between the flat faces, i.e.\ current path length \(L'=t\) and cross‐sectional area  
\[
  A'=\pi\Bigl(\frac{d}{2}\Bigr)^2
     =\pi\,(0.010)^2
     =3.142\times10^{-4}\,\mathrm m^2.
\]  
Then  
\[
  R'=\rho\,\frac{L'}{A'}
     =(1.62\times10^{-8})\,
      \frac{1.00\times10^{-3}}{3.142\times10^{-4}}
     =5.15\times10^{-8}\,\Omega.
\]

**Final Answers (brief):**  
(a) Material: copper (\(\rho=1.62\times10^{-8}\,\Omega\cdot\mathrm m\)).  
(b) Disk resistance: \(R'=5.15\times10^{-8}\,\Omega\).

Here is a step‐by‐step proof that a charge moving in a static magnetic field has constant speed.

1.  Newton’s second law for a particle of mass \(m\) and charge \(e\) in the field \(\mathbf B(\mathbf r)\) is
    \[
       m\,\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt}\;=\;e\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B\,. 
    \]

2.  Take the dot‐product of both sides with \(\mathbf v\):
    \[
       m\,\mathbf v\cdot\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt}
       \;=\;
       e\,\mathbf v\cdot(\mathbf v\times\mathbf B)\,. 
    \]

3.  But for any vectors \(\mathbf v\) and \(\mathbf B\),
    \(\mathbf v\cdot(\mathbf v\times\mathbf B)=0\).  Hence
    \[
       m\,\mathbf v\cdot\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt}=0\,.
    \]

4.  Noting that
    \(\mathbf v\cdot\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt}=\tfrac12\,\frac{d}{dt}(v^2)\), we get
    \[
       \frac{d}{dt}\bigl(v^2\bigr)=0
       \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
       v^2=\text{constant}.
    \]
    Therefore \(\lvert \mathbf v\rvert = v\) remains fixed in time.

5.  Equivalently, the magnetic force does no work:
    \[
       P=\mathbf F\cdot\mathbf v
         =e\,(\mathbf v\times\mathbf B)\cdot\mathbf v
         =0
       \;\Longrightarrow\;
       \text{kinetic energy constant.}
    \]

Final Answers (brief):

1.  Equation of motion:
    \(\displaystyle m\,\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt}=e\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B.\)

2.  Dotting with \(\mathbf v\) gives
    \(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dt}(v^2)=0.\)

3.  Hence
    \(\displaystyle |\mathbf v|=\text{constant}.\)

Here is a step-by-step solution.  All equations are in LaTeX.

Step 1 (Properties).  
Let 
 L29: \displaystyle \mathcal L\{t\,f(t)\}(s)\;=\;-\,\frac{d}{ds}\bigl[\mathcal L\{f(t)\}(s)\bigr],  
and  
 L11: \displaystyle \mathcal L\{e^{\alpha t}f(t)\}(s)\;=\;\mathcal L\{f(t)\}(s-\alpha).  

Step 2 (Compute \(\mathcal L\{e^{-a t}\sin b t\}\)).  
Since \(\mathcal L\{\sin b t\}(s)=\dfrac{b}{s^2+b^2},\) by L11 with \(\alpha=-a\):  
\[
\mathcal L\{e^{-a t}\sin b t\}(s)
=\frac{b}{(s+a)^2+b^2}\,.
\]

Step 3 (Apply L29).  
\[
\mathcal L\{t\,e^{-a t}\sin b t\}(s)
=-\frac{d}{ds}\!\Bigl[\frac{b}{(s+a)^2+b^2}\Bigr]
=-b\cdot\frac{-2(s+a)}{\bigl[(s+a)^2+b^2\bigr]^2}
=\frac{2b\,(s+a)}{\bigl[(s+a)^2+b^2\bigr]^2}\,.  
\]

Final Answer (brief).  
\[
\boxed{\mathcal L\{t\,e^{-a t}\sin b t\}(s)
=\frac{2b\,(s+a)}{\bigl[(s+a)^2+b^2\bigr]^2}\,.}
\]

Solution (assuming equal masses m for A and B, or m_A=m_B=m):

1. Conservation of momentum  
\[
m\,\mathbf v_A + m\,\mathbf v_B \;=\; m\,\mathbf v'_A + m\,\mathbf v'_B
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\mathbf v'_B \;=\;\mathbf v_A + \mathbf v_B - \mathbf v'_A.
\]

2. Compute \(\mathbf v'_B\):  
\[
\mathbf v_A + \mathbf v_B
=(15\,\mathbf i+30\,\mathbf j)+(-10\,\mathbf i+5\,\mathbf j)
=(5\,\mathbf i+35\,\mathbf j),
\]
\[
\mathbf v'_B=(5\,\mathbf i+35\,\mathbf j)-(-5\,\mathbf i+20\,\mathbf j)
=(10\,\mathbf i+15\,\mathbf j)\ \mathrm{m/s}.
\]

3. Kinetic‐energy change  
\[
K_{\rm in}
=\tfrac12m\bigl|\mathbf v_A\bigr|^2+\tfrac12m\bigl|\mathbf v_B\bigr|^2
=\tfrac12m\,(1125+125)=\tfrac12m\cdot1250,
\]
\[
K_{\rm out}
=\tfrac12m\bigl|\mathbf v'_A\bigr|^2+\tfrac12m\bigl|\mathbf v'_B\bigr|^2
=\tfrac12m\,(425+325)=\tfrac12m\cdot750,
\]
\[
\Delta K=K_{\rm out}-K_{\rm in}
=\tfrac12m\,(750-1250)=-250\,m\quad\bigl(\text{J}\bigr).
\]
If \(m=1\rm\,kg\), then \(\Delta K=-250\rm\,J\).

Final answers in brief:

(a) \(\displaystyle \mathbf v'_B = (10\,\mathbf i + 15\,\mathbf j)\rm\ m/s.\)  
(b) \(\displaystyle \Delta K = -250\,m\ (\text{J}),\) i.e.\ \(-250\rm\,J\) if \(m=1\rm\,kg\).

Here is a step‐by‐step analysis.  We take the vertical motion only, since horizontal speed is constant and does not affect bounce heights.

Notation and data  
Let the total drop be \(H_0=4.00\rm\ m\), each step is \(\Delta h=1.00\rm\ m\), and the \(n\)th step (measured down from the top) is at height
\[
y_n = H_0 - n\,\Delta h\,,\quad n=1,2,3,4.
\]
Each collision is perfectly elastic, so the magnitude of the vertical speed is unchanged, only its sign reverses.

1.  Vertical speed just before impacting the \(n\)th step  
   The ball falls from its previous apex (which we will see always lies at \(H_0\)) down to \(y_n\).  Hence the drop is
   \[
   \Delta y_n = H_0 - y_n = n\,\Delta h\,,
   \]
   and by energy conservation
   \[
   v_{y,n} = \sqrt{2g\,\Delta y_n}
             = \sqrt{2g\,(H_0 - y_n)}\,.
   \]

2.  Bounce height above the \(n\)th step  
   After an elastic collision the vertical speed is reversed, so the ball rises until \(v_y=0\).  Its rise above \(y_n\) is
   \[
   h_n = \frac{v_{y,n}^2}{2g}
        = \frac{2g\,(H_0 - y_n)}{2g}
        = H_0 - y_n
        = n\,\Delta h\,.
   \]
   Thus the successive bounce heights above each step are
   \[
   h_1 =1\;\rm m,\quad
   h_2 =2\;\rm m,\quad
   h_3 =3\;\rm m,\quad
   h_4 =4\;\rm m.
   \]

3.  In particular, on the fourth bounce (at the bottom, \(y_4=0\)) the ball rises
   \[
   \boxed{h_4 = 4.00\;\rm m.}
   \]

Final answers (bounce heights above each step):  
h₁=1.00 m, h₂=2.00 m, h₃=3.00 m, h₄=4.00 m.

Step-by-step explanation

1. Definition of conservative vs. nonconservative forces  
   – A force **F** is conservative if the work it does from A to B depends only on the endpoints, i.e.  
     $$
       W_{A\to B}=\int_A^B\mathbf F\cdot d\mathbf r
     $$  
     is path-independent and for any closed path  
     $$
       \oint\mathbf F\cdot d\mathbf r=0.
     $$  

2. Work done by kinetic friction  
   – For a block of mass $m$ sliding a distance $d$ on a horizontal surface with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k$, the friction force is  
     $$
       \mathbf F_f=-\mu_k\,N\,\hat{\mathbf v},\quad N=mg.
     $$  
   – The work done by friction over the path of length $d$ is  
     $$
       W_f=\int_0^d(-\mu_k\,mg)\,dx=-\mu_k mg\,d,
     $$  
     which depends explicitly on the *length* $d$ of the path.

3. Closed‐path work is nonzero  
   – If the block returns to its starting point via another path of total length $L$, friction’s work is  
     $$
       W_{\rm loop}=-\mu_k\,mg\,L\neq0,
     $$  
     so $\oint\mathbf F_f\cdot d\mathbf r\neq0$.  

4. Energy bookkeeping  
   – The “lost” mechanical energy $-\!W_f$ appears as increased internal (thermal) energy of the surfaces.  
   – There is no stored potential energy associated with friction; the process is irreversible and dissipative.

Does friction store energy for future use?  
No. Friction converts ordered mechanical energy into disordered internal (thermal) energy; it does not retain energy in a recoverable form.

Final answers (brief)

• Friction is nonconservative because  
  $$
    W_f=\int\mathbf F_f\!\cdot d\mathbf r=-\mu_k\,mg\,d
  $$  
  depends on the path length and  
  $$
    \oint\mathbf F_f\cdot d\mathbf r\neq0.
  $$

• Friction does *not* store energy; it irreversibly converts mechanical work into heat.

Here is the detailed solution, followed by a brief summary of the answers.

Step‐by‐step Solution

1.  Identify the forces on the stone (mass \(m=0.80\) kg) moving in a horizontal circle of radius \(r=0.90\) m on a frictionless table:

    –  Tension \(\vec T\) in the string, directed radially inward  
    –  Weight \(\vec W = m\,\vec g\), vertically downward  
    –  Normal force \(\vec N\), vertically upward  

2.  Free‐body diagram (side view):  
         •  Upward: \(\vec N\)  
         •  Downward: \(\vec W = m g\)  
         •  Horizontal (toward center): \(\vec T\)

3.  Since the motion is horizontal, \(\vec N\) and \(\vec W\) cancel:
    \[
      N - mg = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad N = mg \,.
    \]

4.  The only unbalanced force in the horizontal plane is the tension \(T\), which provides the centripetal acceleration \(a_c = v^2/r\).  Thus
    \[
      T = m\,a_c = m\,\frac{v^2}{r} \,.
    \]

5.  The string breaks if \(T\) exceeds \(T_{\max}=60.0\) N.  Set \(T=T_{\max}\) to find the maximum speed \(v_{\max}\):
    \[
      T_{\max} = m\,\frac{v_{\max}^2}{r}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      v_{\max} = \sqrt{\frac{T_{\max}\,r}{m}} 
      = \sqrt{\frac{60.0\,(0.90)}{0.80}}
      \approx 8.22\ \text{m/s}.
    \]

Final Answers (brief)

(a)  Free‐body diagram:  
    –  \(\vec T\) inward (horizontal)  
    –  \(\vec N\) upward  
    –  \(\vec W=mg\) downward  

(b)  Maximum speed  
    \[
      v_{\max} = \sqrt{\frac{T_{\max}\,r}{m}}
                   = \sqrt{\frac{60.0\times0.90}{0.80}}
                   \approx 8.22\ \text{m/s}\,.
    \]

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.  Let the ball start from rest with constant acceleration \(a\).  Then its displacement from \(t=0\) to time \(t\) is
   \[
     s(t)=\tfrac12\,a\,t^2.
   \]

2.  “The second 5 s” means the interval from \(t=5\) s to \(t=10\) s.  The distance traveled in that interval is
   \[
     s_{2} \;=\; s(10)-s(5)
            =\tfrac12\,a\,(10^2-5^2)
            =\tfrac12\,a\,(100-25)
            =\tfrac12\cdot75\,a
            =\tfrac{75}{2}\,a.
   \]
   We are told \(s_{2}=200\) m, so
   \[
     \frac{75}{2}\,a =200
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     a = \frac{200\cdot2}{75}=\frac{400}{75}=\frac{16}{3}\ \mathrm{m/s^2}.
   \]

3.  The distance during the first 5 s is
   \[
     s_{1}=s(5)=\tfrac12\,a\,(5^2)
            =\tfrac12\;\frac{16}{3}\;(25)
            =\frac{8\cdot25}{3}
            =\frac{200}{3}\ \mathrm{m}
            \approx66.7\ \mathrm{m}.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

• Acceleration: \(a=\tfrac{16}{3}\,\mathrm{m/s^2}\).  
• Distance in first 5 s: \(s_1=\tfrac{200}{3}\,\mathrm{m}\approx66.7\,\mathrm{m}.\)

Here is a step-by-step quantum‐tunneling calculation for electrons of energy \(E=50\) eV facing a rectangular barrier of height \(V_{0}=200\) eV and width \(a=1\) nm.

1.  Define the barrier parameters and constants  
    \[
      E = 50\;\mathrm{eV},\quad
      V_{0}=200\;\mathrm{eV},\quad
      a = 1\,\mathrm{nm}=1\times 10^{-9}\,\mathrm{m},
    \]  
    electron mass \(m=9.11\times10^{-31}\) kg, Planck’s constant \(\hbar=1.055\times10^{-34}\) J·s, and \(1\,\mathrm{eV}=1.602\times10^{-19}\) J.

2.  Write the decay constant inside the barrier  
    \[
      \kappa \;=\;\sqrt{\frac{2m\bigl(V_{0}-E\bigr)e}{\hbar^{2}}}
      \;=\;\sqrt{\frac{2\,(9.11\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg})\,(150\,\mathrm{eV})\,(1.602\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J/eV})}
                             {(1.055\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\!\cdot\!s})^{2}}}
      \;\approx\;6.27\times10^{10}\,\mathrm{m^{-1}}.
    \]

3.  Use the thick‐barrier (WKB) approximation  
    For \(V_{0}-E\gg E\) and \(\kappa a\gg1\), the transmission coefficient is
    \[
      T \;\approx\; e^{-2\,\kappa\,a}
      \;=\;\exp\!\bigl[-2\,(6.27\times10^{10}\,\mathrm{m^{-1}})\,(1\times10^{-9}\,\mathrm{m})\bigr]
      \;=\;\exp(-125.4)
      \;\approx\;4\times10^{-55}.
    \]

4.  (Optional exact prefactor)  
    The more exact one‐dimensional formula is
    \[
      T \;=\;\frac{1}{1+\displaystyle\frac{V_{0}^{2}}{4E\,(V_{0}-E)}\sinh^{2}(\kappa a)},
    \]
    which for \(\kappa a\gg1\) gives essentially the same result (\(T\sim10^{-54}\)).

Final brief answer:

• Transmission coefficient   
  \[
    T \approx e^{-2\,\kappa\,a}\approx 4\times10^{-55}\,\approx 10^{-54}.
  \]

Below is a step‐by‐step analysis followed by a brief summary of the final answers.

1.  Definition of “touch”  
    On a piano, the performer’s finger motion generates a time‐varying force \(F(t)\) on the key.  Through the action of the key lever and wippen this force accelerates the hammer of mass \(m\).  We call the performer’s choice of the temporal shape of \(F(t)\) the pianist’s “touch.”  In particular, it determines the hammer’s velocity \(v_h(t)\) at the moment it strikes the string.

2.  Hammer–string interaction and loudness  
    Just before impact the hammer satisfies the equation of motion  
    \[
      m\,\ddot x_h(t) + k\bigl[x_h(t)\bigr] = F(t),
    \]
    where \(x_h\) is hammer displacement and \(k[x_h]\) is the (nonlinear) hammer‐felt stiffness.  The maximum hammer velocity \(v_{h,\max}\) at impact fixes the initial excitation of the string.  The kinetic energy delivered to the string is
    \[
      E = \tfrac12\,m\,v_{h,\max}^2,
    \]
    and the resulting acoustic loudness (sound‐pressure level) scales approximately like
    \[
      L \;\propto\; 20\log_{10}(v_{h,\max})\;.
    \]

3.  Why touch and loudness cannot be chosen independently  
    – Both “touch” (the full time‐history \(F(t)\)) and loudness \(L\) are ultimately functions of the same control waveform \(F(t)\).  
    – In practice the dominant audible effect (loudness) is set by the single scalar \(v_{h,\max}\), which itself is determined by the choice of \(F(t)\).  
    – Since there is only one degree of freedom in mapping finger‐force history onto hammer velocity, you cannot vary the loudness (i.e.\ \(v_{h,\max}\)) without also altering the shape of the force impulse and hence the “touch,” and vice versa.

— — —

Final answers in brief:

1.  Touch: the performer’s choice of the time‐profile of key‐force \(F(t)\), which determines the hammer’s velocity \(v_h(t)\).  
2.  Loudness: set by the hammer’s impact speed \(v_{h,\max}\), since  
    \[
      E=\tfrac12m\,v_{h,\max}^2,\quad L\propto20\log_{10}(v_{h,\max})\,.  
    \]
3.  Impossible to control both independently because there is only one control function \(F(t)\) mapping onto both the hammer‐velocity curve (touch) and its peak value (loudness).

Step 1.  Introduce components  
Let  
\[
\mathbf A = (A_x,\,A_y,\,A_z)\,.  
\]

Step 2.  Compute the scalar (dot) product  
\[
\mathbf A\cdot\mathbf A 
= A_xA_x + A_yA_y + A_zA_z
= A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2
= \lvert \mathbf A\rvert^2\,.  
\]

Step 3.  Compute the vector (cross) product  
\[
\mathbf A \times \mathbf A
= 
\begin{vmatrix}
\mathbf i & \mathbf j & \mathbf k\\
A_x        & A_y        & A_z\\
A_x        & A_y        & A_z
\end{vmatrix}
= \mathbf 0
\]  
(or, by antisymmetry \( \mathbf A\times\mathbf A=-\mathbf A\times\mathbf A\Rightarrow\mathbf A\times\mathbf A=\mathbf0\)).  

Final answers (brief)  
\[
\boxed{
\mathbf A\cdot\mathbf A = \lvert \mathbf A\rvert^2,
\qquad
\mathbf A\times\mathbf A = \mathbf 0
}
\]

Here is the step–by–step solution:

1. Define variables  
   Let  
   \(M=50\;\mathrm{kg}\) be the mass of the archer,  
   \(m=0.10\;\mathrm{kg}\) the mass of the arrow,  
   \(v_{\rm arrow}=100\;\mathrm{m/s}\) its speed,  
   and \(V\) the recoil speed of the archer.

2. Conservation of horizontal momentum  
   Since there is no external horizontal force, initial momentum is zero and final momentum must also be zero:  
   \[
     0 \;=\; M\,V + m\,v_{\rm arrow}\,.
   \]

3. Solve for \(V\)  
   \[
     M\,V = -\,m\,v_{\rm arrow}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     V = -\,\frac{m}{M}\,v_{\rm arrow}
     = -\,\frac{0.10}{50}\,(100)
     = -\,0.20\;\mathrm{m/s}.
   \]

4. Interpretation  
   The negative sign means the archer moves opposite to the arrow’s direction.

Final answer (in brief):

\(V_{\rm recoil}=0.20\;\mathrm{m/s}\) (opposite to the arrow)

    \[

    \]
    and the masses (from Table 12.1) in energy units:
    \[
      M_W c^2 = 80.4\;\mathrm{GeV}=8.04\times10^4\;\mathrm{MeV},

      M_Z c^2 = 91.2\;\mathrm{GeV}=9.12\times10^4\;\mathrm{MeV}.
    \]

    \[

            \;=\;\frac{197.3\;\mathrm{MeV\,fm}}{8.04\times10^4\;\mathrm{MeV}}
            \approx2.45\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{fm},

    \[
      r_Z \;=\;\frac{\hbar c}{M_Z c^2}
            \;=\;\frac{197.3\;\mathrm{MeV\,fm}}{9.12\times10^4\;\mathrm{MeV}}

    \[
       r\sim10^{-3}\,\mathrm{fm},
    \]
    which is the characteristic range of the weak force.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Final Answers (brief):

•  Range of \(W\)–exchange:  
   \(\displaystyle r_W\approx2.5\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{fm}.\)

•  Range of \(Z\)–exchange:  
   \(\displaystyle r_Z\approx2.2\times10^{-3}\,\mathrm{fm}.\)

•  Order of magnitude:  
   \(\displaystyle r\sim10^{-3}\,\mathrm{fm}.\)

Step 1:  Write the acceleration in plane‐polar (cylindrical) coordinates.  If the particle’s position is  
\[
\vec r(t)=r(t)\,\hat e_r \quad\text{with}\quad \hat e_r,\;\hat e_θ,
\]  
then its acceleration is  
\[
\vec a
=\Bigl(\ddot r - r\dot θ^2\Bigr)\,\hat e_r
+\Bigl(r\ddot θ+2\dot r\,\dot θ\Bigr)\,\hat e_θ
\,. 
\]

Step 2:  Impose circular motion.  For motion on a circle of fixed radius \(R\), we have  
\[
r(t)=R=\text{const}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\dot r=0,\ \ddot r=0.
\]  
Hence  
\[
a_r=\ddot r -r\dot θ^2=-R\dot θ^2
=-\frac{v^2}{R}
\neq0,
\qquad
a_t=r\ddot θ+2\dot r\,\dot θ
=R\,\ddot θ
=\frac{dv}{dt}.
\]

Step 3:  Classify cases.  
• Uniform circular motion: \(v=\text{const}\Rightarrow \dot θ=const\), so  
\[
a_r=-\frac{v^2}{R}\neq0,
\quad
a_t=\frac{dv}{dt}=0.
\]
• Non‐uniform circular motion: \(v\) not constant \(\Rightarrow \dot θ\) not constant, so  
\[
a_r=-\frac{v^2}{R}\neq0,
\quad
a_t=\frac{dv}{dt}\neq0.
\]

Step 4:  Match to the given options.  Circular motion requires \(a_r\neq0\), while \(a_t\) may be zero (uniform) or nonzero (non‐uniform).  Therefore the allowed cases are  
(C) \(a_r\neq0,\;a_t=0\)  
(D) \(a_r\neq0,\;a_t\neq0\)

Final Answer (brief):  
(C) and (D)

Problem statement  
A cubic furnace has interior faces of size 3 m×3 m.  The top and four side walls are (virtually) black at T₂=1200 K.  The bottom wall (area A₁=9 m²) has emissivity ε₁=0.4 and is held at T₁=800 K.  Find the net radiative heat transfer rate to the bottom face from the other five faces.

Solution outline  
1.  Label surfaces: 1=bottom, 2…6=top+4 sides.  
2.  All non‐bottom surfaces are black (ε=1) and at uniform temperature T₂.  
3.  Geometry: the bottom is a flat, nonreentrant surface ⇒ F₁₁=0 and ∑_{j≠1}F₁j=1.  
4.  The bottom therefore “sees” the other surfaces as a single (composite) black enclosure at T₂.  

By the net‐radiation formula for a single gray surface facing a black enclosure:  
\[
   \dot Q_{1\to\mathrm{surr}}
 = A_1\,\frac{\varepsilon_1}{1-\!(1-\varepsilon_1)F_{11}}\,
   \sigma\bigl(T_{\mathrm{surr}}^4-T_1^4\bigr)
\]
but since F₁₁=0 and T_{\mathrm{surr}}=T₂, this reduces to
\[
   \dot Q
 = \varepsilon_1\,A_1\,\sigma\bigl(T_2^4-T_1^4\bigr).
\]

Compute numerically:  
\[
  A_1 = 3\;\text{m}\times3\;\text{m}=9\;\text{m}^2,\quad
  \sigma=5.67\times10^{-8}\,\frac{\rm W}{\rm m^2\;K^4},
\]  
\[
  T_2^4-T_1^4 = (1200^4-800^4)\;\mathrm{K}^4
              =2.0736\times10^{12}-4.096\times10^{11}
              =1.664\times10^{12}\;\mathrm{K}^4.
\]  
Thus  
\[
  \dot Q
 =0.4\times9\times5.67\times10^{-8}\times1.664\times10^{12}
 \approx3.40\times10^5\;\mathrm{W}
 =340\;\mathrm{kW}.
\]

Final answer (brief)  
\[
  \dot Q_{\rm net}
 =\varepsilon_1\,A_1\,\sigma\bigl(T_2^4-T_1^4\bigr)
 =340\;\mathrm{kW}.
\]

Here is a step‐by‐step solution.

1.   The force is related to the potential by  
     \[
       \mathbf F = -\nabla U \;,\quad
       \nabla U = \biggl(\frac{\partial U}{\partial x},\;\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}\biggr).
     \]

2.   Compute the partial derivatives:  
     \[
       \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}
         = 2\,(5.80)\,x
         = 11.6\,x,
       \quad
       \frac{\partial U}{\partial y}
         = -3\,(3.60)\,y^2
         = -10.8\,y^2.
     \]

3.   Thus the components of the force are  
     \[
       F_x = -\,\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} = -11.6\,x,
       \quad
       F_y = -\,\frac{\partial U}{\partial y} = +10.8\,y^2.
     \]

4.   At \((x,y)=(0.300,\,0.600)\,\mathrm m\):  
     \[
       F_x = -11.6\,(0.300) = -3.48\;\mathrm N,
       \quad
       F_y = 10.8\,(0.600)^2 = 3.888\;\mathrm N.
     \]

5.   The acceleration is \(\mathbf a=\mathbf F/m\). With \(m=0.0400\)\,kg:  
     \[
       a_x = \frac{F_x}{m} = \frac{-3.48}{0.0400} = -87.0\;\mathrm{m/s^2},
       \quad
       a_y = \frac{3.888}{0.0400} = 97.2\;\mathrm{m/s^2}.
     \]

6.   Magnitude and direction (measured CCW from +x):  
     \[
       |\mathbf a| = \sqrt{a_x^2 + a_y^2}
                    = \sqrt{(-87.0)^2 + (97.2)^2}
                    = 1.30\times10^2\;\mathrm{m/s^2},
     \]
     \[
       \theta = \tan^{-1}\!\bigl(\tfrac{a_y}{a_x}\bigr)
              = \tan^{-1}\!\bigl(\tfrac{97.2}{-87.0}\bigr)
              \approx 132^\circ.
     \]

Final Answers (brief):

\[
\boxed{|\mathbf a| = 1.30\times10^2\;\mathrm{m/s^2}, 
\quad \theta = 132^\circ\ \text{(above +x axis).}}
\]

Step 1:  Pilot’s mass from his Earth‐weight  
Let \(W_E=735\){ N} and \(g_E=9.8\){ m/s²}.  Then  
\[
m=\frac{W_E}{g_E}=\frac{735}{9.8}=75\ {\rm kg}.
\]

Step 2:  Free‐body diagram on the Moon  
For upward positive,  
\[
N - m\,g_{\rm moon}=m\,a_{\rm up},
\]  
where \(g_{\rm moon}=1.6\){ m/s²}, \(a_{\rm up}=1.0\){ m/s²}, and \(N\) is the force of the ship on the pilot.

Step 3:  Solve for \(N\)  
\[
N=m\bigl(g_{\rm moon}+a_{\rm up}\bigr)
 =75\,(1.6+1.0)
 =75\times2.6
 =195\ {\rm N}.
\]

Final Answer (brief)  
• Pilot’s mass: \(m=75\rm\ kg\).  
• Force on pilot: \(N=195\rm\ N\).

Step 1: Identify the Group-VIIA elements  
They are the halogens:  
F, Cl, Br, I, At, Ts

Step 2: Write out their electron configurations (showing only the valence shell)  
F : 1s² 2s² 2p⁵  
Cl : [Ne] 3s² 3p⁵  
Br : [Ar] 4s² 3d¹⁰ 4p⁵  
I  : [Kr] 5s² 4d¹⁰ 5p⁵  
At : [Xe] 6s² 4f¹⁴ 5d¹⁰ 6p⁵  

Step 3: Extract the common feature  
In every case the outer-shell electrons occupy an s-subshell with 2 electrons and a p-subshell with 5 electrons.

Step 4: State the common valence configuration  
All Group VIIA elements have seven valence electrons and a valence-shell configuration of  
\[
ns^2\,np^5
\]  
They are one electron short of the noble‐gas configuration.

Final Answers (brief):

1. Each has seven valence electrons.  
2. Valence‐shell configuration: \(\displaystyle ns^2\,np^5\).

Step-by-Step Reasoning

1. Definition of a planetary nebula  
   A planetary nebula is the ionized shell of gas ejected by a low- to intermediate-mass star near the end of its asymptotic giant branch (AGB) phase. What we see is the glowing gas around a hot central white dwarf remnant.

2. Candidate explanations  
   a. “It is hot.”  
      – The gas is indeed hot (∼10⁴ K), but mere thermal emission (continuum) at that temperature is very weak in the optical; the bright optical lines are not from thermal bremsstrahlung.  
   b. “Fusion is happening in the nebula.”  
      – Fusion occurs in stellar cores, not in the diffuse expelled gas. No fusion in the nebula.  
   c. “It is heating up the interstellar medium around it.”  
      – The nebula is itself the expelled gas; it does not primarily glow by heating still more distant ISM.  
   d. “Light from the central star causes emission lines.”  
      – The hot central star emits large numbers of ultraviolet (UV) photons which photoionize the nebula. When ions and electrons recombine, they cascade downward in energy levels and emit characteristic line radiation.

3. Photoionization and recombination mechanism  
   a) Photoionization of hydrogen (for example):  
      \[
        \text{H} + h\nu \;(\lambda<912\text{\AA}) \;\longrightarrow\; \text{H}^+ + e^-
      \]  
   b) Radiative recombination and line emission:  
      \[
        e^- + \text{H}^+ \;\longrightarrow\; \text{H}^* \;\longrightarrow\; \text{H}(n=2) + h\nu_{\alpha}
      \]  
      where \(h\nu_{\alpha}\) is Hα (6563 Å), plus similar cascades for other lines (e.g.\ [O III] 5007 Å).

4. Conclusion  
   The dominant glow of a planetary nebula comes from emission lines excited by UV photons from the hot central star.

Final Answer (brief)

d. light from the central star causes emission lines.

Here is a step‐by‐step analysis, followed by the brief answers.

1.  Charging of the car  
    – When the high‐voltage DC line touches the metal body of the car, the car (plus any one sitting in it and electrically connected to the body) is raised to the line potential \(V_{\rm line}\).  
    – The car’s rubber tyres (and any air gaps) isolate it from earth, so under steady DC no significant current leaks to ground.  

2.  Equipotential inside the car  
    – The interior of the metal car is a Faraday cage: every point on the metal shell and everything in firm metallic contact with it (including the occupant) is at the same potential \(V_{\rm line}\).  
    – Since no two points on the occupant’s body have any potential difference, no current flows through him.  
    – Conclusion: sitting in the car, the occupant is safe.

3.  Forming a discharge path on stepping out  
    – As soon as the occupant touches the ground while still touching the car, he provides a conductor between the car at \(V_{\rm line}\) and earth at 0 V.  
    – A current  
       \[
         I \;=\;\frac{V_{\rm line}-0}{R_{\rm body}}
       \]  
       will flow through his body. For typical values, e.g.\ \(V_{\rm line}=10^5\rm\ V\), \(R_{\rm body}\sim10^3\ \Omega\), one finds  
       \[
         I\sim\frac{10^5}{10^3}=10^2\rm\ A,
       \]  
       which is fatal.  
    – Conclusion: stepping out in the normal way causes a dangerous (even lethal) shock.

Final Answers (in brief)

(a) While sitting in the car, the occupant and the car are both at the same potential \(V_{\rm line}\). There is no potential difference across the body ⇒ no current ⇒ safe.

(b) The moment the occupant touches ground while still in contact with the car, a potential difference \(V_{\rm line}-0\) appears across his body. A large current  
\[
   I = \frac{V_{\rm line}}{R_{\rm body}}
\]  
flows ⇒ electric shock, usually fatal.

Here is the step‐by‐step solution.

Given:  
A=1.0 m×1.5 m=1.5 m²  
T_i=20 °C,  T_o=–20 °C ⇒ ΔT=40 K  
h_i=40 W/m²K,  h_o=20 W/m²K  
Two glass layers, each L_g=4 mm=0.004 m, k_g=0.78 W/mK  
Air gap L_a=5 mm=0.005 m, k_a=0.025 W/mK  

1) Thermal resistances in series per unit area:  
   R_conv,in=1/(h_i A)  
   R_glass (each)=L_g/(k_g A)  
   R_air=L_a/(k_a A)  
   R_conv,out=1/(h_o A)  

   Numerically:  
   R_conv,in=1/(40·1.5)=0.01667 K/W  
   R_glass=0.004/(0.78·1.5)=0.003418 K/W (each layer)  
   R_air =0.005/(0.025·1.5)=0.13333 K/W  
   R_conv,out=1/(20·1.5)=0.03333 K/W  

2) Total resistance  
   R_tot=R_conv,in+2R_glass+R_air+R_conv,out  
   R_tot=0.01667+2·0.003418+0.13333+0.03333  
   R_tot≈0.19016 K/W  

3) Steady‐state heat flow  
   \[
     \dot Q \;=\;\frac{T_i - T_o}{R_{\rm tot}}
            \;=\;\frac{40}{0.19016}
            \;\approx\;210.3\;{\rm W}.
   \]

4) Daily heat loss  
   \[
     Q_{\rm day}
     =\dot Q\;\times 86400\;{\rm s}
     =210.3\times86400
     \approx1.82\times10^{7}\;{\rm J/day}.
   \]

5) Temperature drop across air gap  
   \[
     \Delta T_{\rm air}
     =\dot Q\;R_{\rm air}
     =210.3\times0.13333
     \approx28.0\;{\rm K}.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

(a) Daily heat loss ≃1.82×10^7 J/day (≈5.05 kWh/day).  
(b) Largest ΔT occurs across the air gap: ≃28 K.

Here is a step‐by‐step derivation and the numerical estimate:

(a)  Allowed wavelengths and energies in a 1‐D box of length L

1.  Standing‐wave condition (nodes at x=0 and x=L):
   \[
     L \;=\; \frac{n\,\lambda}{2}
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \lambda_n \;=\;\frac{2L}{n}
     \quad(n=1,2,3,\dots).
   \]

2.  de Broglie relation for momentum:
   \[
     p_n \;=\;\frac{h}{\lambda_n}
     \;=\;\frac{h}{2L/n}
     \;=\;\frac{n\,h}{2L}.
   \]

3.  Nonrelativistic kinetic energy:
   \[
     E_n \;=\;\frac{p_n^2}{2m}
     \;=\;\frac{1}{2m}\Bigl(\frac{n\,h}{2L}\Bigr)^2
     \;=\;\frac{n^2\,h^2}{8\,m\,L^2}\,.
   \]

Hence the allowed energy levels are
\[
  \boxed{E_n \;=\;\frac{n^2\,h^2}{8\,m\,L^2}
  \quad(n=1,2,3,\dots).}
\]

(b)  Model H‐atom as a 1-D box of length \(L=a_0\) (Bohr radius \(a_0=5.29\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm m\)), lowest level (\(n=1\)):
\[
  E_1
  =\frac{h^2}{8\,m_e\,a_0^2}
  \approx\frac{(6.626\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\!\cdot\!s})^2}
              {8\,(9.11\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg})(5.29\times10^{-11}\,\mathrm m)^2}
  \approx2.15\times10^{-17}\,\mathrm J
  \approx1.34\times10^2\,\mathrm{eV}.
\]

Final brief answers:  
• \(E_n=\dfrac{n^2h^2}{8mL^2}.\)  
• For \(L=a_0\), \(E_1\approx1.34\times10^2\;\mathrm{eV}.\)

Here is the requested derivation.

(a) Expression for E₀ in terms of D, ρ and r₀  
1.  Start from  
   E_N(r)=−C/r + D e^(−r/ρ)  
   Equilibrium at r=r₀ ⇒ dE_N/dr|_{r₀}=0.  
   
2.  Compute the derivative  
   dE_N/dr = +C/r² − (D/ρ) e^(−r/ρ)  
   ⇒ at r=r₀  
   (1) C/r₀² = (D/ρ) e^(−r₀/ρ)  
   ⇒  
   (2) C = (D r₀²/ρ)\,e^(−r₀/ρ) .  
   
3.  The bonding energy is E₀=E_N(r₀):  
   E₀ = −C/r₀ + D e^(−r₀/ρ)  
       = −(D r₀²/ρ)\,e^(−r₀/ρ)·(1/r₀) + D e^(−r₀/ρ)  
       = D e^(−r₀/ρ)·(1 − r₀/ρ)\,.  

Hence  
(3a) E₀ = D e^(−r₀/ρ) (1 − r₀/ρ)\,.  

(b) Expression for E₀ in terms of C, ρ and r₀  

From (1) above we have  
   D e^(−r₀/ρ) = C ρ/r₀².  
Substitute into E₀ of part (a):  
   E₀ = (C ρ/r₀²)·(1 − r₀/ρ)  
       = C (ρ − r₀)/r₀²\,.  

Hence  
(3b) E₀ = C (ρ − r₀)/r₀²\,.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final Answers (brief)  
(a) E₀ = D e^(−r₀/ρ)\,(1 − r₀/ρ)  
(b) E₀ = C\,(ρ − r₀)/r₀²

Below we denote by  
\[
f(x)\;=\;\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}c_n\,e^{i n x},\qquad
c_n=\frac1{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}f(x)\,e^{-i n x}\,dx,
\]  
the complex‐exponential Fourier series on \((-\pi,\pi)\).  One easily checks in each case that if  
\[
f(x)=\frac{a_0}{2}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty\bigl(a_n\cos nx+b_n\sin nx\bigr)
\]  
then  
\[
c_0=\frac{a_0}{2},\quad
c_n=\frac{a_n-i\,b_n}{2}\;(n>0),\quad
c_{-n}=\overline{c_n}=\frac{a_n+i\,b_n}{2}.
\]  
By inserting the known real Fourier coefficients \(a_n,b_n\) from Section 5 one recovers the following eleven complex‐coefficient formulas.

Final answers (Problems 5.1–5.11):

1. \(f(x)=1\)  
   \[
   c_0=1,\qquad c_n=0\quad(n\neq0).
   \]

2. \(f(x)=x\)  
   \[
   c_0=0,\qquad
   c_n=\frac{(-1)^n-1}{i\,n}\quad(n\neq0).
   \]

3. \(f(x)=x^2\)  
   \[
   c_0=\frac{\pi^2}{3},\qquad
   c_n=\frac{2(-1)^n}{n^2}\quad(n\neq0).
   \]

4. \(f(x)=|x|\)  
   \[
   c_0=\frac{\pi}{2},\qquad
   c_n=\begin{cases}
     -\displaystyle\frac{2}{\pi\,n^2},&n\text{ odd},\\[1ex]
     0,&n\text{ even}.
   \end{cases}
   \]

5. \(f(x)=\operatorname{sgn}(x)=\begin{cases}-1,&x<0,\\+1,&x>0\end{cases}\)  
   \[
   c_0=0,\qquad
   c_n=\begin{cases}
     \displaystyle\frac{2}{i\pi\,n},&n\text{ odd},\\[1ex]
     0,&n\text{ even}.
   \end{cases}
   \]

6. \(f(x)=\sin(kx)\) \((k\in\mathbb{N})\)  
   \[
   c_n=\begin{cases}
     \displaystyle\frac{1}{2i},&n=k,\\[1ex]
     \displaystyle-\frac{1}{2i},&n=-k,\\[1ex]
     0,&|n|\neq k.
   \end{cases}
   \]

7. \(f(x)=\cos(kx)\) \((k\in\mathbb{N})\)  
   \[
   c_n=\begin{cases}
     \displaystyle\frac12,&n=k\text{ or }n=-k,\\[1ex]
     0,&|n|\neq k.
   \end{cases}
   \]

8. Sawtooth: \(f(x)=\displaystyle\frac{x}{\pi}\) on \((-\pi,\pi)\) (periodic)  
   \[
   c_0=0,\qquad
   c_n=\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{i\,n}\quad(n\neq0).
   \]

9. Full‐wave rectified sine: \(f(x)=|\sin x|\)  
   \[
   c_0=\frac{2}{\pi},\qquad
   c_n=\begin{cases}
     -\displaystyle\frac{4}{\pi\,(4m^2-1)},&n=2m\neq0,\\[1ex]
     0,&n\text{ odd}.
   \end{cases}
   \]

10. Rectangular pulse of width \(2\alpha\) (\(0<\alpha<\pi\)):  
    \[
    f(x)=\begin{cases}1,&|x|<\alpha,\\0,&\alpha<|x|<\pi,\end{cases}
    \]
    \[
    c_0=\frac{\alpha}{\pi},\qquad
    c_n=\frac{\sin(n\alpha)}{n\pi}\quad(n\neq0).
    \]

11. Exponential \(f(x)=e^{a x}\) \((a\in\mathbb{R})\):  
    \[
    c_n
    =\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}e^{a x}e^{-i n x}dx
    =\frac{e^{a\pi}(-1)^n-e^{-a\pi}}{2\pi\,(a-i\,n)}.
    \]

One checks in each case that
\[
a_0=2c_0,\quad
a_n=c_n+c_{-n},\quad
b_n=i\,(c_n-c_{-n}),
\]
so the above complex‐coefficient forms are algebraically equivalent to the real‐coefficient series given in Section 5.

Here is the detailed solution:

1. Convert all given quantities to SI units  
   Mass of string:  
   \[
     m = 3.4\ {\rm g} = 0.0034\ {\rm kg}
   \]  
   Total length of string:  
   \[
     L = 92\ {\rm cm} = 0.92\ {\rm m}
   \]  
   Vibrating length (bridge to post):  
   \[
     \ell = 62\ {\rm cm} = 0.62\ {\rm m}
   \]  
   Tension:  
   \[
     T = 520\ {\rm N}
   \]

2. Linear mass density of the string  
   \[
     \mu = \frac{m}{L}
           = \frac{0.0034\ \rm kg}{0.92\ \rm m}
           = 0.00369565\ \rm kg/m
   \]

3. Wave speed on the string  
   \[
     v = \sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}
       = \sqrt{\frac{520\ \rm N}{0.00369565\ \rm kg/m}}
       \approx 375.2\ \rm m/s
   \]

4. Frequencies of the normal modes  
   The \(n\)th harmonic on a string of length \(\ell\) has frequency  
   \[
     f_n = \frac{n\,v}{2\ell}
     \;\;(n = 1,2,3,\dots)
   \]

   – Fundamental (\(n=1\)):  
   \[
     f_1 = \frac{v}{2\ell}
         = \frac{375.2}{2\times0.62}
         \approx 302.6\ \rm Hz
   \]

   – First overtone (\(n=2\), second harmonic):  
   \[
     f_2 = 2\,f_1 \approx 2\times302.6 = 605.2\ \rm Hz
   \]

   – Second overtone (\(n=3\), third harmonic):  
   \[
     f_3 = 3\,f_1 \approx 3\times302.6 = 907.8\ \rm Hz
   \]

Final answers (to three significant figures):  
\[
  f_1 = 303\ \rm Hz,\quad
  f_2 = 605\ \rm Hz,\quad
  f_3 = 908\ \rm Hz.
\]

Here is a clean Gauss‐law argument:

1.  Total flux through the cube  
   Since a point charge \(+q\) sits at a corner, one may imagine eight identical cubes sharing that corner.  By symmetry the total flux out of each cube is  
   \[
     \Phi_{\rm total}=\frac{1}{8}\,\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}\,.
   \]

2.  Flux through the three “corner” faces  
   Label the cube so that its corner with the charge is at the origin and its edges run along the \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) axes from \(0\) to \(a\).  The three faces meeting at the charge lie in the planes \(x=0\), \(y=0\), \(z=0\).  At any point on, say, \(x=0\), the field is radial from the origin and hence lies entirely in the \(yz\)‐plane.  Thus
   \[
     \Phi_{x=0}
     =\iint_{x=0}\!E_x\,dA
     =0
     \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
     \Phi\bigl(\text{each of }x=0,y=0,z=0\bigr)=0.
   \]

3.  Flux through the remaining three faces  
   The only nonzero contribution to \(\Phi_{\rm total}\) comes from the faces at \(x=a\), \(y=a\), and \(z=a\).  By symmetry these three fluxes are equal and must sum to \(\Phi_{\rm total}\).  Hence each is
   \[
     \Phi_{x=a}
     \;=\;\Phi_{y=a}
     \;=\;\Phi_{z=a}
     \;=\;\frac{1}{3}\,\Phi_{\rm total}
     \;=\;\frac{1}{3}\,\frac{q}{8\varepsilon_0}
     \;=\;\frac{q}{24\,\varepsilon_0}.
   \]

——————————————  
Final answer (in multiples of \(q/\varepsilon_0\))  

(a)  Each face through the corner (planes \(x=0,y=0,z=0\)):  
\[
  \boxed{0}
\]

(b)  Each of the other three faces (planes \(x=a,y=a,z=a\)):  
\[
  \boxed{\frac{1}{24}\,\frac{q}{\varepsilon_0}}
\]

1.  Hyperfine Hamiltonian in the ground state (n=1) of a hydrogen‐like atom is given by the magnetic–dipole contact interaction  
   \[
     H_{\rm hfs}
     \;=\;
     \frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\,\frac{2}{3}\,\boldsymbol{\mu}_{e}\!\cdot\!\boldsymbol{\mu}_{N}\,\delta^{3}(\mathbf r)
   \]
   with
   \[
     \boldsymbol{\mu}_{e}
     =-\,g_{e}\,\mu_{B}\,\frac{\mathbf S}{\hbar}
     ,
     \qquad
     \boldsymbol{\mu}_{N}
     =\;g_{N}\,\mu_{N}\,\frac{\mathbf I}{\hbar}
     ,
   \]
   where  
   –  \(\mu_{B}=e\hbar/(2m_{e})\) is the Bohr magneton,  
   –  \(\mu_{N}=e\hbar/(2m_{p})\) is the nuclear magneton,  
   –  \(g_{e}\approx2.0023\), \(g_{N}=g_{d}=1.71\) for the deuteron,  
   –  \(\mathbf S\) and \(\mathbf I\) are the electron and nuclear spins.  

2.  In first‐order perturbation theory one replaces \(\delta^3(\mathbf r)\) by \(|\psi_{1s}(0)|^2\) with  
   \[
     \psi_{1s}(0)
     =\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi a^{3}}}
     ,
     \quad
     a=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,\hbar^{2}}{\mu\,e^{2}}
     \approx a_{0}\Bigl(1-\frac{m_{e}}{m_{N}}\Bigr)
     \,,
   \]
   and \(\mu\) the reduced mass.  One finds  
   \[
     H_{\rm hfs}
     =C\;\mathbf I\cdot \mathbf S,
     \qquad
     C
     =\frac{\mu_{0}}{4\pi}\,\frac{2}{3}\,
       g_{e}\,\mu_{B}\;g_{N}\,\mu_{N}\;\bigl|\psi_{1s}(0)\bigr|^2.
   \]

3.  The eigen‐energies depend on
   \[
     F(F+1)-I(I+1)-S(S+1),
   \]
   where for deuterium \(I=1\), \(S=\tfrac12\), so
   \[
     F_{\max}=\tfrac32,\quad F_{\min}=\tfrac12,
     \quad
     F_{\max}(F_{\max}+1)-F_{\min}(F_{\min}+1)
     =\frac{15}{4}-\frac{3}{4}=3.
   \]
   Hence the splitting
   \[
     \Delta E_{d}
     =\bigl[E(F_{\max})-E(F_{\min})\bigr]
     =3\,C_{d}.
   \]

4.  We eliminate \(C_{d}\) by using the known hydrogen splitting
   \[
     \Delta E_{H}
     =E_{H}(F=1)-E_{H}(F=0)
     =2\,C_{H}
     =5.87433\times10^{-6}\,\rm eV.
   \]
   Since
   \[
     C\propto g_{N}\,\mu_{N}\;|\psi(0)|^2,
     \quad
     \mu_{N}^{\rm (nuclear)}=g_{N}\,\frac{e\hbar}{2\,m_{N}}
     =g_{N}\,\mu_{N}\frac{m_{p}}{m_{N}},
   \]
   one finds
   \[
     \frac{C_{d}}{C_{H}}
     =
     \frac{g_{d}}{g_{p}}\;\frac{m_{p}}{m_{d}}
     \;\times\;
     \frac{|\psi_{d}(0)|^2}{|\psi_{H}(0)|^2}
     \approx
     \frac{1.71}{5.586}\;\frac{1}{2}\;\times1.0008
     \approx1.5329\times10^{-1}.
   \]
   Therefore
   \[
     \Delta E_{d}
     =3\,C_{d}
     =3\Bigl(\tfrac{C_{d}}{C_{H}}\Bigr)\,C_{H}
     =3\,(0.15329)\,\frac{\Delta E_{H}}{2}
     =0.230\,\Delta E_{H}
     \approx1.352\times10^{-6}\,\rm eV.
   \]

5.  The corresponding wavelength is
   \[
     \lambda_{d}
     =\frac{h\,c}{\Delta E_{d}}
     =\frac{(4.1357\times10^{-15}\,\rm eV\,s)\,(2.998\times10^{8}\,\rm m/s)}
           {1.352\times10^{-6}\,\rm eV}
     \;\approx\;0.917\,\rm m
     =91.7\;cm.
   \]

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
Final answer (in brief):  
\[
  \Delta E_{d}\approx1.35\times10^{-6}\,\rm eV,
  \qquad
  \lambda_{d}\approx91.7\;\rm cm.
\]

Here is a unified derivation of (a)–(c) using the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff (BCH) expansion and the Pauli commutation relations

  [σ_i,σ_j] = 2 i ε_{ijk} σ_k.  

---

1)  BCH‐expansion  
For any operator A and B one has  
\[
e^{A}\,B\,e^{-A}
= B \;+\;[A,B]\;+\;\frac1{2!}\,[A,[A,B]]\;+\;\frac1{3!}\,[A,[A,[A,B]]]\;+\cdots
\]

2)  Rotation about the y–axis:  
Let  
\[
A = i\alpha\,\sigma_{y},\quad B=\sigma_{x}.
\]  
First commutator:  
\[
[A,B]
= i\alpha\,[\sigma_{y},\sigma_{x}]
= i\alpha\,(-2i\,\sigma_{z})
= +2\alpha\,\sigma_{z}\,.
\]  
Second commutator:  
\[
[A,[A,B]]
= [\,i\alpha\,\sigma_{y},\,2\alpha\,\sigma_{z}]
= 2\alpha\;i\alpha\,[\sigma_{y},\sigma_{z}]
= 2\,i\alpha^{2}\,(2i\,\sigma_{x})
= -4\alpha^{2}\,\sigma_{x}\,.
\]  
One continues in the same way and finds that the series splits into an even part (∼σ_x) and an odd part (∼σ_z):  
\[
e^{i\alpha\sigma_{y}}\;\sigma_{x}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\sigma_{y}}
=\sigma_{x}\,\Bigl(1-\frac{(2\alpha)^{2}}{2!}+\frac{(2\alpha)^{4}}{4!}-\cdots\Bigr)
\;+\;\sigma_{z}\,\Bigl(\frac{(2\alpha)}{1!}-\frac{(2\alpha)^{3}}{3!}+\cdots\Bigr)
=\sigma_{x}\cos(2\alpha)+\sigma_{z}\sin(2\alpha)\,.  
\]

3)  Rotations about z and x  
By exactly the same steps, using  
\[
[\sigma_{z},\sigma_{x}]=2\,i\,\sigma_{y},\quad
[\sigma_{x},\sigma_{y}]=2\,i\,\sigma_{z},
\]  
one finds  

(b) rotation about z‐axis:  
\[
e^{\,i\alpha\,\sigma_{z}}\;\sigma_{x}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\,\sigma_{z}}
=\sigma_{x}\cos(2\alpha)\;-\;\sigma_{y}\sin(2\alpha)\,.
\]

(c) rotation about x‐axis:  
\[
e^{\,i\alpha\,\sigma_{x}}\;\sigma_{y}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\,\sigma_{x}}
=\sigma_{y}\cos(2\alpha)\;-\;\sigma_{z}\sin(2\alpha)\,.
\]

---

Final answer (briefly):  
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
(a)\quad&e^{\,i\alpha\sigma_{y}}\;\sigma_{x}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\sigma_{y}}
=\sigma_{x}\cos(2\alpha)+\sigma_{z}\sin(2\alpha),\\
(b)\quad&e^{\,i\alpha\sigma_{z}}\;\sigma_{x}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\sigma_{z}}
=\sigma_{x}\cos(2\alpha)-\sigma_{y}\sin(2\alpha),\\
(c)\quad&e^{\,i\alpha\sigma_{x}}\;\sigma_{y}\;e^{-\,i\alpha\sigma_{x}}
=\sigma_{y}\cos(2\alpha)-\sigma_{z}\sin(2\alpha).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Here’s the step-by-step solution:

Given:  
Radius of thin spherical shell: \(R=1.90\;\mathrm m\)  
Applied torque: \(\tau=960\;\mathrm{N\cdot m}\)  
Angular acceleration: \(\alpha=6.20\;\mathrm{rad/s^2}\)

(a) Rotational inertia \(I\) about the central axis follows from  
\[
\tau = I\,\alpha
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
I = \frac{\tau}{\alpha}\,.
\]
Substitute values:
\[
I = \frac{960\;\mathrm{N\cdot m}}{6.20\;\mathrm{rad/s^2}}
   = 154.8\;\mathrm{kg\cdot m^2}\,.
\]

(b) For a thin spherical shell of mass \(m\) and radius \(R\),  
\[
I = \frac{2}{3}\,mR^2
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
m = \frac{3I}{2R^2}\,.
\]
Substitute \(I\) and \(R\):
\[
m = \frac{3\,(154.8\;\mathrm{kg\cdot m^2})}
           {2\,(1.90\;\mathrm m)^2}
  = 64.3\;\mathrm{kg}\,.
\]

Final Answers (to three significant figures):  
(a) \(I = 155\;\mathrm{kg\cdot m^2}\)  
(b) \(m = 64.3\;\mathrm{kg}\)

Here is a step‐by‐step solution:

1. Compute the plate area  
   \[
   A \;=\; L \times W \;=\; 5\rm\,m\times3\rm\,m \;=\;15\rm\,m^2.
   \]

2. Compute the net normal force on the plate  
   (positive when acting from the lower side toward the upper side)  
   \[
   F_N \;=\;(p_{\rm bot}-p_{\rm top})\,A
         \;=\;(50\times10^3\rm\,Pa - 70\times10^3\rm\,Pa)\times15\rm\,m^2
         \;=\;-300\times10^3\rm\,N.
   \]
   Its magnitude is \(300\rm\,kN\) and it acts normal to the plate (downward).

3. Resolve \(F_N\) into a component parallel to the free‐stream (the pressure drag \(F_D\)).  
   If the plate is inclined by \(\alpha=15^\circ\) to the flow, the normal makes an angle \(90^\circ+\alpha\) with the flow, so  
   \[
   F_D \;=\;|F_N|\;\sin\alpha
         \;=\;300\times10^3\rm\,N\;\sin15^\circ
         \;\approx\;7.76\times10^4\rm\,N.
   \]

Final answers (brief):

• Plate area: \(A=15\rm\,m^2\)  
• Net normal force: \(F_N=-300\rm\,kN\) (magnitude \(300\rm\,kN\))
